-- | Describes an instance's Amazon EBS volumes.
--   
--   This call accepts only one resource-identifying parameter.
--   
--   <b>Required Permissions</b>: To use this action, an IAM user must have
--   a Show, Deploy, or Manage permissions level for the stack, or an
--   attached policy that explicitly grants permissions. For more
--   information about user permissions, see <a>Managing User
--   Permissions</a>.
module Network.AWS.OpsWorks.DescribeVolumes

-- | <i>See:</i> <a>newDescribeVolumes</a> smart constructor.
data DescribeVolumes
DescribeVolumes' :: Maybe Text -> Maybe [Text] -> Maybe Text -> Maybe Text -> DescribeVolumes

-- | The instance ID. If you use this parameter, <tt>DescribeVolumes</tt>
--   returns descriptions of the volumes associated with the specified
--   instance.
[$sel:instanceId:DescribeVolumes'] :: DescribeVolumes -> Maybe Text

-- | Am array of volume IDs. If you use this parameter,
--   <tt>DescribeVolumes</tt> returns descriptions of the specified
--   volumes. Otherwise, it returns a description of every volume.
[$sel:volumeIds:DescribeVolumes'] :: DescribeVolumes -> Maybe [Text]

-- | The RAID array ID. If you use this parameter, <tt>DescribeVolumes</tt>
--   returns descriptions of the volumes associated with the specified RAID
--   array.
[$sel:raidArrayId:DescribeVolumes'] :: DescribeVolumes -> Maybe Text

-- | A stack ID. The action describes the stack's registered Amazon EBS
--   volumes.
[$sel:stackId:DescribeVolumes'] :: DescribeVolumes -> Maybe Text

-- | Create a value of <a>DescribeVolumes</a> with all optional fields
--   omitted.
--   
--   Use <a>generic-lens</a> or <a>optics</a> to modify other optional
--   fields.
--   
--   The following record fields are available, with the corresponding
--   lenses provided for backwards compatibility:
--   
--   <a>$sel:instanceId:DescribeVolumes'</a>,
--   <a>describeVolumes_instanceId</a> - The instance ID. If you use this
--   parameter, <tt>DescribeVolumes</tt> returns descriptions of the
--   volumes associated with the specified instance.
--   
--   <a>$sel:volumeIds:DescribeVolumes'</a>,
--   <a>describeVolumes_volumeIds</a> - Am array of volume IDs. If you use
--   this parameter, <tt>DescribeVolumes</tt> returns descriptions of the
--   specified volumes. Otherwise, it returns a description of every
--   volume.
--   
--   <a>$sel:raidArrayId:DescribeVolumes'</a>,
--   <a>describeVolumes_raidArrayId</a> - The RAID array ID. If you use
--   this parameter, <tt>DescribeVolumes</tt> returns descriptions of the
--   volumes associated with the specified RAID array.
--   
--   <a>$sel:stackId:DescribeVolumes'</a>, <a>describeVolumes_stackId</a> -
--   A stack ID. The action describes the stack's registered Amazon EBS
--   volumes.
newDescribeVolumes :: DescribeVolumes

-- | The instance ID. If you use this parameter, <tt>DescribeVolumes</tt>
--   returns descriptions of the volumes associated with the specified
--   instance.
describeVolumes_instanceId :: Lens' DescribeVolumes (Maybe Text)

-- | Am array of volume IDs. If you use this parameter,
--   <tt>DescribeVolumes</tt> returns descriptions of the specified
--   volumes. Otherwise, it returns a description of every volume.
describeVolumes_volumeIds :: Lens' DescribeVolumes (Maybe [Text])

-- | The RAID array ID. If you use this parameter, <tt>DescribeVolumes</tt>
--   returns descriptions of the volumes associated with the specified RAID
--   array.
describeVolumes_raidArrayId :: Lens' DescribeVolumes (Maybe Text)

-- | A stack ID. The action describes the stack's registered Amazon EBS
--   volumes.
describeVolumes_stackId :: Lens' DescribeVolumes (Maybe Text)

-- | Contains the response to a <tt>DescribeVolumes</tt> request.
--   
--   <i>See:</i> <a>newDescribeVolumesResponse</a> smart constructor.
data DescribeVolumesResponse
DescribeVolumesResponse' :: Maybe [Volume] -> Int -> DescribeVolumesResponse

-- | An array of volume IDs.
[$sel:volumes:DescribeVolumesResponse'] :: DescribeVolumesResponse -> Maybe [Volume]

-- | The response's http status code.
[$sel:httpStatus:DescribeVolumesResponse'] :: DescribeVolumesResponse -> Int

-- | Create a value of <a>DescribeVolumesResponse</a> with all optional
--   fields omitted.
--   
--   Use <a>generic-lens</a> or <a>optics</a> to modify other optional
--   fields.
--   
--   The following record fields are available, with the corresponding
--   lenses provided for backwards compatibility:
--   
--   <a>$sel:volumes:DescribeVolumesResponse'</a>,
--   <a>describeVolumesResponse_volumes</a> - An array of volume IDs.
--   
--   <a>$sel:httpStatus:DescribeVolumesResponse'</a>,
--   <a>describeVolumesResponse_httpStatus</a> - The response's http status
--   code.
newDescribeVolumesResponse :: Int -> DescribeVolumesResponse

-- | An array of volume IDs.
describeVolumesResponse_volumes :: Lens' DescribeVolumesResponse (Maybe [Volume])

describeVolumesResponse_httpStatus :: Lens' DescribeVolumesResponse Int

--   errors. Otherwise, it returns a description of every error.

-- | Describes the permissions for a specified stack.
--   
--   <b>Required Permissions</b>: To use this action, an IAM user must have
--   a Manage permissions level for the stack, or an attached policy that
--   explicitly grants permissions. For more information on user
--   permissions, see <a>Managing User Permissions</a>.
module Network.AWS.OpsWorks.DescribePermissions

-- | <i>See:</i> <a>newDescribePermissions</a> smart constructor.
data DescribePermissions
DescribePermissions' :: Maybe Text -> Maybe Text -> DescribePermissions

-- | The user's IAM ARN. This can also be a federated user's ARN. For more
--   information about IAM ARNs, see <a>Using Identifiers</a>.
[$sel:iamUserArn:DescribePermissions'] :: DescribePermissions -> Maybe Text

-- | The stack ID.
[$sel:stackId:DescribePermissions'] :: DescribePermissions -> Maybe Text

-- | Create a value of <a>DescribePermissions</a> with all optional fields
--   omitted.
--   
--   Use <a>generic-lens</a> or <a>optics</a> to modify other optional
--   fields.
--   
--   The following record fields are available, with the corresponding
--   lenses provided for backwards compatibility:
--   
--   <a>$sel:iamUserArn:DescribePermissions'</a>,
--   <a>describePermissions_iamUserArn</a> - The user's IAM ARN. This can
--   also be a federated user's ARN. For more information about IAM ARNs,
--   see <a>Using Identifiers</a>.
--   
--   <a>$sel:stackId:DescribePermissions'</a>,
--   <a>describePermissions_stackId</a> - The stack ID.
newDescribePermissions :: DescribePermissions

-- | The user's IAM ARN. This can also be a federated user's ARN. For more
--   information about IAM ARNs, see <a>Using Identifiers</a>.
describePermissions_iamUserArn :: Lens' DescribePermissions (Maybe Text)

-- | The stack ID.
describePermissions_stackId :: Lens' DescribePermissions (Maybe Text)

-- | Contains the response to a <tt>DescribePermissions</tt> request.
--   
--   <i>See:</i> <a>newDescribePermissionsResponse</a> smart constructor.
data DescribePermissionsResponse
DescribePermissionsResponse' :: Maybe [Permission] -> Int -> DescribePermissionsResponse

-- | An array of <tt>Permission</tt> objects that describe the stack
--   permissions.
--   
--   <ul>
--   <li>If the request object contains only a stack ID, the array contains
--   a <tt>Permission</tt> object with permissions for each of the stack
--   IAM ARNs.</li>
--   <li>If the request object contains only an IAM ARN, the array contains
--   a <tt>Permission</tt> object with permissions for each of the user's
--   stack IDs.</li>
--   <li>If the request contains a stack ID and an IAM ARN, the array
--   contains a single <tt>Permission</tt> object with permissions for the
--   specified stack and IAM ARN.</li>
--   </ul>
[$sel:permissions:DescribePermissionsResponse'] :: DescribePermissionsResponse -> Maybe [Permission]

-- | The response's http status code.
[$sel:httpStatus:DescribePermissionsResponse'] :: DescribePermissionsResponse -> Int

-- | Create a value of <a>DescribePermissionsResponse</a> with all optional
--   fields omitted.
--   
--   Use <a>generic-lens</a> or <a>optics</a> to modify other optional
--   fields.
--   
--   The following record fields are available, with the corresponding
--   lenses provided for backwards compatibility:
--   
--   <a>$sel:permissions:DescribePermissionsResponse'</a>,
--   <a>describePermissionsResponse_permissions</a> - An array of
--   <tt>Permission</tt> objects that describe the stack permissions.
--   
--   <ul>
--   <li>If the request object contains only a stack ID, the array contains
--   a <tt>Permission</tt> object with permissions for each of the stack
--   IAM ARNs.</li>
--   <li>If the request object contains only an IAM ARN, the array contains
--   a <tt>Permission</tt> object with permissions for each of the user's
--   stack IDs.</li>
--   <li>If the request contains a stack ID and an IAM ARN, the array
--   contains a single <tt>Permission</tt> object with permissions for the
--   specified stack and IAM ARN.</li>
--   </ul>
--   
--   <a>$sel:httpStatus:DescribePermissionsResponse'</a>,
--   <a>describePermissionsResponse_httpStatus</a> - The response's http
--   status code.
newDescribePermissionsResponse :: Int -> DescribePermissionsResponse

-- | An array of <tt>Permission</tt> objects that describe the stack
--   permissions.
--   
--   <ul>
--   <li>If the request object contains only a stack ID, the array contains
--   a <tt>Permission</tt> object with permissions for each of the stack
--   IAM ARNs.</li>
--   <li>If the request object contains only an IAM ARN, the array contains
--   a <tt>Permission</tt> object with permissions for each of the user's
--   stack IDs.</li>
--   <li>If the request contains a stack ID and an IAM ARN, the array
--   contains a single <tt>Permission</tt> object with permissions for the
--   specified stack and IAM ARN.</li>
--   </ul>
describePermissionsResponse_permissions :: Lens' DescribePermissionsResponse (Maybe [Permission])

describePermissionsResponse_httpStatus :: Lens' DescribePermissionsResponse Int

-- | Requests a description of one or more layers in a specified stack.
--   
--   This call accepts only one resource-identifying parameter.
--   
--   <b>Required Permissions</b>: To use this action, an IAM user must have
--   a Show, Deploy, or Manage permissions level for the stack, or an
--   attached policy that explicitly grants permissions. For more
--   information about user permissions, see <a>Managing User
--   Permissions</a>.
module Network.AWS.OpsWorks.DescribeLayers

-- | <i>See:</i> <a>newDescribeLayers</a> smart constructor.
data DescribeLayers
DescribeLayers' :: Maybe [Text] -> Maybe Text -> DescribeLayers

-- | An array of layer IDs that specify the layers to be described. If you
--   omit this parameter, <tt>DescribeLayers</tt> returns a description of
--   every layer in the specified stack.
[$sel:layerIds:DescribeLayers'] :: DescribeLayers -> Maybe [Text]

[$sel:stackId:DescribeLayers'] :: DescribeLayers -> Maybe Text

--   lenses provided for backwards compatibility:
--

--   An array of layer IDs that specify the layers to be described. If you
--   omit this parameter, <tt>DescribeLayers</tt> returns a description of
--   every layer in the specified stack.
--   
--   <a>$sel:stackId:DescribeLayers'</a>, <a>describeLayers_stackId</a> -
--   The stack ID.
newDescribeLayers :: DescribeLayers

--   every layer in the specified stack.

-- | Requests a description of a set of instances.
--   
--   This call accepts only one resource-identifying parameter.
--   
--   <b>Required Permissions</b>: To use this action, an IAM user must have
--   a Show, Deploy, or Manage permissions level for the stack, or an
--   attached policy that explicitly grants permissions. For more
--   information about user permissions, see <a>Managing User
--   Permissions</a>.
module Network.AWS.OpsWorks.DescribeInstances

-- | <i>See:</i> <a>newDescribeInstances</a> smart constructor.
data DescribeInstances
DescribeInstances' :: Maybe [Text] -> Maybe Text -> Maybe Text -> DescribeInstances

-- | An array of instance IDs to be described. If you use this parameter,
--   <tt>DescribeInstances</tt> returns a description of the specified
--   instances. Otherwise, it returns a description of every instance.
[$sel:instanceIds:DescribeInstances'] :: DescribeInstances -> Maybe [Text]

-- | A stack ID. If you use this parameter, <tt>DescribeInstances</tt>
--   returns descriptions of the instances associated with the specified
--   stack.
[$sel:stackId:DescribeInstances'] :: DescribeInstances -> Maybe Text

-- | A layer ID. If you use this parameter, <tt>DescribeInstances</tt>
--   returns descriptions of the instances associated with the specified
--   layer.
[$sel:layerId:DescribeInstances'] :: DescribeInstances -> Maybe Text

-- | Create a value of <a>DescribeInstances</a> with all optional fields
--   omitted.
--   
--   Use <a>generic-lens</a> or <a>optics</a> to modify other optional
--   fields.
--   
--   The following record fields are available, with the corresponding
--   lenses provided for backwards compatibility:
--   
--   <a>$sel:instanceIds:DescribeInstances'</a>,
--   <a>describeInstances_instanceIds</a> - An array of instance IDs to be
--   described. If you use this parameter, <tt>DescribeInstances</tt>
--   returns a description of the specified instances. Otherwise, it
--   returns a description of every instance.
--   
--   <a>$sel:stackId:DescribeInstances'</a>,
--   <a>describeInstances_stackId</a> - A stack ID. If you use this
--   parameter, <tt>DescribeInstances</tt> returns descriptions of the
--   instances associated with the specified stack.
--   
--   <a>$sel:layerId:DescribeInstances'</a>,
--   <a>describeInstances_layerId</a> - A layer ID. If you use this
--   parameter, <tt>DescribeInstances</tt> returns descriptions of the
--   instances associated with the specified layer.
newDescribeInstances :: DescribeInstances

-- | An array of instance IDs to be described. If you use this parameter,
--   <tt>DescribeInstances</tt> returns a description of the specified
--   instances. Otherwise, it returns a description of every instance.
describeInstances_instanceIds :: Lens' DescribeInstances (Maybe [Text])

-- | A stack ID. If you use this parameter, <tt>DescribeInstances</tt>
--   returns descriptions of the instances associated with the specified
--   stack.
describeInstances_stackId :: Lens' DescribeInstances (Maybe Text)

-- | A layer ID. If you use this parameter, <tt>DescribeInstances</tt>
--   returns descriptions of the instances associated with the specified
--   layer.
describeInstances_layerId :: Lens' DescribeInstances (Maybe Text)

-- | Contains the response to a <tt>DescribeInstances</tt> request.
--   
--   <i>See:</i> <a>newDescribeInstancesResponse</a> smart constructor.
data DescribeInstancesResponse
DescribeInstancesResponse' :: Maybe [Instance] -> Int -> DescribeInstancesResponse

-- | An array of <tt>Instance</tt> objects that describe the instances.
[$sel:instances:DescribeInstancesResponse'] :: DescribeInstancesResponse -> Maybe [Instance]

-- | The response's http status code.
[$sel:httpStatus:DescribeInstancesResponse'] :: DescribeInstancesResponse -> Int

-- | Create a value of <a>DescribeInstancesResponse</a> with all optional
--   fields omitted.
--   
--   Use <a>generic-lens</a> or <a>optics</a> to modify other optional
--   fields.
--   
--   The following record fields are available, with the corresponding
--   lenses provided for backwards compatibility:
--   
--   <a>$sel:instances:DescribeInstancesResponse'</a>,
--   <a>describeInstancesResponse_instances</a> - An array of
--   <tt>Instance</tt> objects that describe the instances.
--   
--   <a>$sel:httpStatus:DescribeInstancesResponse'</a>,
--   <a>describeInstancesResponse_httpStatus</a> - The response's http
--   status code.
newDescribeInstancesResponse :: Int -> DescribeInstancesResponse

-- | An array of <tt>Instance</tt> objects that describe the instances.
describeInstancesResponse_instances :: Lens' DescribeInstancesResponse (Maybe [Instance])

-- | The response's http status code.
describeInstancesResponse_httpStatus :: Lens' DescribeInstancesResponse Int

-- | Describes Amazon ECS clusters that are registered with a stack. If you
--   specify only a stack ID, you can use the <tt>MaxResults</tt> and
--   <tt>NextToken</tt> parameters to paginate the response. However, AWS
--   OpsWorks Stacks currently supports only one cluster per layer, so the
--   result set has a maximum of one element.
--   
--   <b>Required Permissions</b>: To use this action, an IAM user must have
--   a Show, Deploy, or Manage permissions level for the stack or an
--   attached policy that explicitly grants permission. For more
--   information about user permissions, see <a>Managing User
--   Permissions</a>.
--   
--   This call accepts only one resource-identifying parameter.
--   
--   This operation returns paginated results.
module Network.AWS.OpsWorks.DescribeEcsClusters

-- | <i>See:</i> <a>newDescribeEcsClusters</a> smart constructor.
data DescribeEcsClusters
DescribeEcsClusters' :: Maybe Text -> Maybe Text -> Maybe Int -> Maybe [Text] -> DescribeEcsClusters

-- | If the previous paginated request did not return all of the remaining
--   results, the response object's<tt>NextToken</tt> parameter value is
--   set to a token. To retrieve the next set of results, call
--   <tt>DescribeEcsClusters</tt> again and assign that token to the
--   request object's <tt>NextToken</tt> parameter. If there are no
--   remaining results, the previous response object's <tt>NextToken</tt>
--   parameter is set to <tt>null</tt>.
[$sel:nextToken:DescribeEcsClusters'] :: DescribeEcsClusters -> Maybe Text

-- | A stack ID. <tt>DescribeEcsClusters</tt> returns a description of the
--   cluster that is registered with the stack.
[$sel:stackId:DescribeEcsClusters'] :: DescribeEcsClusters -> Maybe Text

-- | To receive a paginated response, use this parameter to specify the
--   maximum number of results to be returned with a single call. If the
--   number of available results exceeds this maximum, the response
--   includes a <tt>NextToken</tt> value that you can assign to the
--   <tt>NextToken</tt> request parameter to get the next set of results.
[$sel:maxResults:DescribeEcsClusters'] :: DescribeEcsClusters -> Maybe Int

-- | A list of ARNs, one for each cluster to be described.
[$sel:ecsClusterArns:DescribeEcsClusters'] :: DescribeEcsClusters -> Maybe [Text]

-- | Create a value of <a>DescribeEcsClusters</a> with all optional fields
--   omitted.
--   
--   Use <a>generic-lens</a> or <a>optics</a> to modify other optional
--   fields.
--   
--   The following record fields are available, with the corresponding
--   lenses provided for backwards compatibility:
--   
--   <a>$sel:nextToken:DescribeEcsClusters'</a>,
--   <a>describeEcsClusters_nextToken</a> - If the previous paginated
--   request did not return all of the remaining results, the response
--   object's<tt>NextToken</tt> parameter value is set to a token. To
--   retrieve the next set of results, call <tt>DescribeEcsClusters</tt>
--   again and assign that token to the request object's <tt>NextToken</tt>
--   parameter. If there are no remaining results, the previous response
--   object's <tt>NextToken</tt> parameter is set to <tt>null</tt>.
--   
--   <a>$sel:stackId:DescribeEcsClusters'</a>,
--   <a>describeEcsClusters_stackId</a> - A stack ID.
--   <tt>DescribeEcsClusters</tt> returns a description of the cluster that
--   is registered with the stack.
--   
--   <a>$sel:maxResults:DescribeEcsClusters'</a>,
--   <a>describeEcsClusters_maxResults</a> - To receive a paginated
--   response, use this parameter to specify the maximum number of results
--   to be returned with a single call. If the number of available results
--   exceeds this maximum, the response includes a <tt>NextToken</tt> value
--   that you can assign to the <tt>NextToken</tt> request parameter to get
--   the next set of results.
--   
--   <a>$sel:ecsClusterArns:DescribeEcsClusters'</a>,
--   <a>describeEcsClusters_ecsClusterArns</a> - A list of ARNs, one for
--   each cluster to be described.
newDescribeEcsClusters :: DescribeEcsClusters

-- | If the previous paginated request did not return all of the remaining
--   results, the response object's<tt>NextToken</tt> parameter value is
--   set to a token. To retrieve the next set of results, call
--   <tt>DescribeEcsClusters</tt> again and assign that token to the
--   request object's <tt>NextToken</tt> parameter. If there are no
--   remaining results, the previous response object's <tt>NextToken</tt>
--   parameter is set to <tt>null</tt>.
describeEcsClusters_nextToken :: Lens' DescribeEcsClusters (Maybe Text)

-- | A stack ID. <tt>DescribeEcsClusters</tt> returns a description of the
--   cluster that is registered with the stack.
describeEcsClusters_stackId :: Lens' DescribeEcsClusters (Maybe Text)

-- | To receive a paginated response, use this parameter to specify the
--   maximum number of results to be returned with a single call. If the
--   number of available results exceeds this maximum, the response
--   includes a <tt>NextToken</tt> value that you can assign to the
--   <tt>NextToken</tt> request parameter to get the next set of results.

data DescribeEcsClustersResponse
DescribeEcsClustersResponse' :: Maybe Text -> Maybe [EcsCluster] -> Int -> DescribeEcsClustersResponse

-- | If a paginated request does not return all of the remaining results,
--   this parameter is set to a token that you can assign to the request
--   object's <tt>NextToken</tt> parameter to retrieve the next set of
--   results. If the previous paginated request returned all of the
--   remaining results, this parameter is set to <tt>null</tt>.

--   descriptions.

--   lenses provided for backwards compatibility:
--   
--   <a>$sel:nextToken:DescribeEcsClusters'</a>,
--   <a>describeEcsClustersResponse_nextToken</a> - If a paginated request
--   does not return all of the remaining results, this parameter is set to
--   a token that you can assign to the request object's <tt>NextToken</tt>
--   parameter to retrieve the next set of results. If the previous
--   paginated request returned all of the remaining results, this
--   parameter is set to <tt>null</tt>.
--   
--   <a>$sel:ecsClusters:DescribeEcsClustersResponse'</a>,
--   <a>describeEcsClustersResponse_ecsClusters</a> - A list of
--   <tt>EcsCluster</tt> objects containing the cluster descriptions.
--   
--   <a>$sel:httpStatus:DescribeEcsClustersResponse'</a>,
--   <a>describeEcsClustersResponse_httpStatus</a> - The response's http
--   status code.
newDescribeEcsClustersResponse :: Int -> DescribeEcsClustersResponse

-- | If a paginated request does not return all of the remaining results,
--   this parameter is set to a token that you can assign to the request
--   object's <tt>NextToken</tt> parameter to retrieve the next set of
--   results. If the previous paginated request returned all of the
--   remaining results, this parameter is set to <tt>null</tt>.
describeEcsClustersResponse_nextToken :: Lens' DescribeEcsClustersResponse (Maybe Text)

-- | A list of <tt>EcsCluster</tt> objects containing the cluster
--   descriptions.
describeEcsClustersResponse_ecsClusters :: Lens' DescribeEcsClustersResponse (Maybe [EcsCluster])

-- | The response's http status code.
describeEcsClustersResponse_httpStatus :: Lens' DescribeEcsClustersResponse Int

-- | Describes the available AWS OpsWorks Stacks agent versions. You must
--   specify a stack ID or a configuration manager.
--   <tt>DescribeAgentVersions</tt> returns a list of available agent
--   versions for the specified stack or configuration manager.
module Network.AWS.OpsWorks.DescribeAgentVersions

-- | <i>See:</i> <a>newDescribeAgentVersions</a> smart constructor.
data DescribeAgentVersions

--   manager.

--   <a>describeAgentVersions_stackId</a> - The stack ID.

--   Note that this value is the complete version number, not the
--   abbreviated number used by the console.
[$sel:agentVersions:DescribeAgentVersionsResponse'] :: DescribeAgentVersionsResponse -> Maybe [AgentVersion]

-- | The response's http status code.
[$sel:httpStatus:DescribeAgentVersionsResponse'] :: DescribeAgentVersionsResponse -> Int

--   used by the console.

--   status code.

--   abbreviated number used by the console.

-- | Deregisters an Amazon EBS volume. The volume can then be registered by
--   another stack. For more information, see <a>Resource Management</a>.
--   
--   <b>Required Permissions</b>: To use this action, an IAM user must have
--   a Manage permissions level for the stack, or an attached policy that
--   explicitly grants permissions. For more information on user
--   permissions, see <a>Managing User Permissions</a>.
module Network.AWS.OpsWorks.DeregisterVolume

-- | <i>See:</i> <a>newDeregisterVolume</a> smart constructor.
data DeregisterVolume
DeregisterVolume' :: Text -> DeregisterVolume

-- | The AWS OpsWorks Stacks volume ID, which is the GUID that AWS OpsWorks
--   Stacks assigned to the instance when you registered the volume with
--   the stack, not the Amazon EC2 volume ID.

--   when you registered the volume with the stack, not the Amazon EC2
--   volume ID.

-- | Deregister a registered Amazon EC2 or on-premises instance. This

--   a Manage permissions level for the stack or an attached policy that
--   explicitly grants permissions. For more information on user
--   permissions, see <a>Managing User Permissions</a>.

-- | Deletes a specified instance, which terminates the associated Amazon
--   EC2 instance. You must stop an instance before you can delete it.
--   
--   For more information, see <a>Deleting Instances</a>.
--   
--   <b>Required Permissions</b>: To use this action, an IAM user must have
--   a Manage permissions level for the stack, or an attached policy that
--   explicitly grants permissions. For more information on user
--   permissions, see <a>Managing User Permissions</a>.
module Network.AWS.OpsWorks.DeleteInstance

-- | <i>See:</i> <a>newDeleteInstance</a> smart constructor.
data DeleteInstance
DeleteInstance' :: Maybe Bool -> Maybe Bool -> Text -> DeleteInstance

-- | Whether to delete the instance's Amazon EBS volumes.
[$sel:deleteVolumes:DeleteInstance'] :: DeleteInstance -> Maybe Bool

-- | Whether to delete the instance Elastic IP address.
[$sel:deleteElasticIp:DeleteInstance'] :: DeleteInstance -> Maybe Bool

-- | The instance ID.
[$sel:instanceId:DeleteInstance'] :: DeleteInstance -> Text

-- | Create a value of <a>DeleteInstance</a> with all optional fields
--   omitted.
--   
--   Use <a>generic-lens</a> or <a>optics</a> to modify other optional
--   fields.
--   
--   The following record fields are available, with the corresponding
--   lenses provided for backwards compatibility:
--   
--   <a>$sel:deleteVolumes:DeleteInstance'</a>,
--   <a>deleteInstance_deleteVolumes</a> - Whether to delete the instance's
--   Amazon EBS volumes.
--   
--   <a>$sel:deleteElasticIp:DeleteInstance'</a>,
--   <a>deleteInstance_deleteElasticIp</a> - Whether to delete the instance
--   Elastic IP address.
--   
--   <a>$sel:instanceId:DeleteInstance'</a>,
--   <a>deleteInstance_instanceId</a> - The instance ID.
newDeleteInstance :: Text -> DeleteInstance

-- | Whether to delete the instance's Amazon EBS volumes.
deleteInstance_deleteVolumes :: Lens' DeleteInstance (Maybe Bool)

-- | Whether to delete the instance Elastic IP address.
deleteInstance_deleteElasticIp :: Lens' DeleteInstance (Maybe Bool)

-- | The instance ID.
deleteInstance_instanceId :: Lens' DeleteInstance Text

-- | Creates a new user profile.
--   
--   <b>Required Permissions</b>: To use this action, an IAM user must have
--   an attached policy that explicitly grants permissions. For more
--   information about user permissions, see <a>Managing User
--   Permissions</a>.
module Network.AWS.OpsWorks.CreateUserProfile

-- | <i>See:</i> <a>newCreateUserProfile</a> smart constructor.
data CreateUserProfile
CreateUserProfile' :: Maybe Bool -> Maybe Text -> Maybe Text -> Text -> CreateUserProfile

-- | Whether users can specify their own SSH public key through the My
--   Settings page. For more information, see <a>Setting an IAM User's
--   Public SSH Key</a>.
[$sel:allowSelfManagement:CreateUserProfile'] :: CreateUserProfile -> Maybe Bool

-- | The user's public SSH key.
[$sel:sshPublicKey:CreateUserProfile'] :: CreateUserProfile -> Maybe Text

-- | The user's SSH user name. The allowable characters are [a-z], [A-Z],
--   [0-9], '-', and '_'. If the specified name includes other punctuation
--   marks, AWS OpsWorks Stacks removes them. For example, <tt>my.name</tt>
--   will be changed to <tt>myname</tt>. If you do not specify an SSH user
--   name, AWS OpsWorks Stacks generates one from the IAM user name.
[$sel:sshUsername:CreateUserProfile'] :: CreateUserProfile -> Maybe Text

-- | The user's IAM ARN; this can also be a federated user's ARN.
[$sel:iamUserArn:CreateUserProfile'] :: CreateUserProfile -> Text

-- | Create a value of <a>CreateUserProfile</a> with all optional fields
--   omitted.
--   
--   Use <a>generic-lens</a> or <a>optics</a> to modify other optional
--   fields.

--   The following record fields are available, with the corresponding

--   more information, see <a>Setting an IAM User's Public SSH Key</a>.

--   <a>$sel:sshPublicKey:CreateUserProfile'</a>,

--   
--   <a>$sel:sshUsername:CreateUserProfile'</a>,

--   specified name includes other punctuation marks, AWS OpsWorks Stacks
--   removes them. For example, <tt>my.name</tt> will be changed to

-- | Creates a new stack. For more information, see <a>Create a New
--   Stack</a>.
--   
--   <b>Required Permissions</b>: To use this action, an IAM user must have
--   an attached policy that explicitly grants permissions. For more
--   information about user permissions, see <a>Managing User
--   Permissions</a>.
module Network.AWS.OpsWorks.CreateStack

-- | <i>See:</i> <a>newCreateStack</a> smart constructor.
data CreateStack
CreateStack' :: Maybe RootDeviceType -> Maybe Text -> Maybe ChefConfiguration -> Maybe Text -> Maybe Text -> Maybe Text -> Maybe Source -> Maybe Text -> Maybe (HashMap StackAttributesKeys (Maybe Text)) -> Maybe Text -> Maybe Bool -> Maybe Bool -> Maybe Text -> Maybe StackConfigurationManager -> Maybe Text -> Text -> Text -> Text -> Text -> CreateStack

-- | The default root device type. This value is the default for all
--   instances in the stack, but you can override it when you create an
--   instance. The default option is <tt>instance-store</tt>. For more
--   information, see <a>Storage for the Root Device</a>.
[$sel:defaultRootDeviceType:CreateStack'] :: CreateStack -> Maybe RootDeviceType

-- | The ID of the VPC that the stack is to be launched into. The VPC must
--   be in the stack's region. All instances are launched into this VPC.
--   You cannot change the ID later.
--   
--   <ul>
--   <li>If your account supports EC2-Classic, the default value is <tt>no
--   VPC</tt>.</li>
--   <li>If your account does not support EC2-Classic, the default value is
--   the default VPC for the specified region.</li>
--   </ul>
--   
--   If the VPC ID corresponds to a default VPC and you have specified
--   either the <tt>DefaultAvailabilityZone</tt> or the
--   <tt>DefaultSubnetId</tt> parameter only, AWS OpsWorks Stacks infers
--   the value of the other parameter. If you specify neither parameter,
--   AWS OpsWorks Stacks sets these parameters to the first valid
--   Availability Zone for the specified region and the corresponding
--   default VPC subnet ID, respectively.
--   
--   If you specify a nondefault VPC ID, note the following:
--   
--   <ul>
--   <li>It must belong to a VPC in your account that is in the specified
--   region.</li>
--   <li>You must specify a value for <tt>DefaultSubnetId</tt>.</li>
--   </ul>
--   
--   For more information about how to use AWS OpsWorks Stacks with a VPC,
--   see <a>Running a Stack in a VPC</a>. For more information about
--   default VPC and EC2-Classic, see <a>Supported Platforms</a>.
[$sel:vpcId:CreateStack'] :: CreateStack -> Maybe Text

-- | A <tt>ChefConfiguration</tt> object that specifies whether to enable
--   Berkshelf and the Berkshelf version on Chef 11.10 stacks. For more
--   information, see <a>Create a New Stack</a>.
[$sel:chefConfiguration:CreateStack'] :: CreateStack -> Maybe ChefConfiguration

-- | The default AWS OpsWorks Stacks agent version. You have the following
--   options:
--   
--   <ul>
--   <li>Auto-update - Set this parameter to <tt>LATEST</tt>. AWS OpsWorks
--   Stacks automatically installs new agent versions on the stack's
--   instances as soon as they are available.</li>
--   <li>Fixed version - Set this parameter to your preferred agent
--   version. To update the agent version, you must edit the stack
--   configuration and specify a new version. AWS OpsWorks Stacks then
--   automatically installs that version on the stack's instances.</li>
--   </ul>
--   
--   The default setting is the most recent release of the agent. To
--   specify an agent version, you must use the complete version number,
--   not the abbreviated number shown on the console. For a list of
--   available agent version numbers, call DescribeAgentVersions.
--   AgentVersion cannot be set to Chef 12.2.
--   
--   You can also specify an agent version when you create or update an
--   instance, which overrides the stack's default setting.
[$sel:agentVersion:CreateStack'] :: CreateStack -> Maybe Text

-- | A default Amazon EC2 key pair name. The default value is none. If you
--   specify a key pair name, AWS OpsWorks installs the public key on the
--   instance and you can use the private key with an SSH client to log in
--   to the instance. For more information, see <a>Using SSH to Communicate
--   with an Instance</a> and <a>Managing SSH Access</a>. You can override
--   this setting by specifying a different key pair, or no key pair, when
--   you <a>create an instance</a>.
[$sel:defaultSshKeyName:CreateStack'] :: CreateStack -> Maybe Text

-- | A string that contains user-defined, custom JSON. It can be used to
--   override the corresponding default stack configuration attribute
--   values or to pass data to recipes. The string should be in the
--   following format:
--   
--   <pre>
--   "{\"key1\": \"value1\", \"key2\": \"value2\",...}"
--   </pre>
--   
--   For more information about custom JSON, see <a>Use Custom JSON to
--   Modify the Stack Configuration Attributes</a>.
[$sel:customJson:CreateStack'] :: CreateStack -> Maybe Text

-- | Contains the information required to retrieve an app or cookbook from
--   a repository. For more information, see <a>Adding Apps</a> or
--   <a>Cookbooks and Recipes</a>.
[$sel:customCookbooksSource:CreateStack'] :: CreateStack -> Maybe Source

-- | The stack's default Availability Zone, which must be in the specified
--   region. For more information, see <a>Regions and Endpoints</a>. If you
--   also specify a value for <tt>DefaultSubnetId</tt>, the subnet must be
--   in the same zone. For more information, see the <tt>VpcId</tt>
--   parameter description.
[$sel:defaultAvailabilityZone:CreateStack'] :: CreateStack -> Maybe Text

-- | One or more user-defined key-value pairs to be added to the stack
--   attributes.
[$sel:attributes:CreateStack'] :: CreateStack -> Maybe (HashMap StackAttributesKeys (Maybe Text))

-- | The stack's default operating system, which is installed on every
--   instance unless you specify a different operating system when you
--   create the instance. You can specify one of the following.
--   
--   <ul>
--   <li>A supported Linux operating system: An Amazon Linux version, such
--   as <tt>Amazon Linux 2018.03</tt>, <tt>Amazon Linux 2017.09</tt>,
--   <tt>Amazon Linux 2017.03</tt>, <tt>Amazon Linux 2016.09</tt>,
--   <tt>Amazon Linux 2016.03</tt>, <tt>Amazon Linux 2015.09</tt>, or
--   <tt>Amazon Linux 2015.03</tt>.</li>
--   <li>A supported Ubuntu operating system, such as <tt>Ubuntu 16.04
--   LTS</tt>, <tt>Ubuntu 14.04 LTS</tt>, or <tt>Ubuntu 12.04
--   LTS</tt>.</li>
--   <li><pre>CentOS Linux 7</pre></li>
--   <li><pre>Red Hat Enterprise Linux 7</pre></li>
--   <li>A supported Windows operating system, such as <tt>Microsoft
--   Windows Server 2012 R2 Base</tt>, <tt>Microsoft Windows Server 2012 R2
--   with SQL Server Express</tt>, <tt>Microsoft Windows Server 2012 R2
--   with SQL Server Standard</tt>, or <tt>Microsoft Windows Server 2012 R2
--   with SQL Server Web</tt>.</li>
--   <li>A custom AMI: <tt>Custom</tt>. You specify the custom AMI you want
--   to use when you create instances. For more information, see <a>Using
--   Custom AMIs</a>.</li>
--   </ul>
--   
--   The default option is the current Amazon Linux version. For more
--   information about supported operating systems, see <a>AWS OpsWorks
--   Stacks Operating Systems</a>.
[$sel:defaultOs:CreateStack'] :: CreateStack -> Maybe Text

-- | Whether to associate the AWS OpsWorks Stacks built-in security groups
--   with the stack's layers.
--   
--   AWS OpsWorks Stacks provides a standard set of built-in security
--   groups, one for each layer, which are associated with layers by
--   default. With <tt>UseOpsworksSecurityGroups</tt> you can instead
--   provide your own custom security groups.
--   <tt>UseOpsworksSecurityGroups</tt> has the following settings:
--   
--   <ul>
--   <li>True - AWS OpsWorks Stacks automatically associates the
--   appropriate built-in security group with each layer (default setting).
--   You can associate additional security groups with a layer after you
--   create it, but you cannot delete the built-in security group.</li>
--   <li>False - AWS OpsWorks Stacks does not associate built-in security
--   groups with layers. You must create appropriate EC2 security groups
--   and associate a security group with each layer that you create.
--   However, you can still manually associate a built-in security group
--   with a layer on creation; custom security groups are required only for
--   those layers that need custom settings.</li>
--   </ul>
--   
--   For more information, see <a>Create a New Stack</a>.
[$sel:useOpsworksSecurityGroups:CreateStack'] :: CreateStack -> Maybe Bool

-- | Whether the stack uses custom cookbooks.
[$sel:useCustomCookbooks:CreateStack'] :: CreateStack -> Maybe Bool

-- | The stack's default VPC subnet ID. This parameter is required if you
--   specify a value for the <tt>VpcId</tt> parameter. All instances are
--   launched into this subnet unless you specify otherwise when you create
--   the instance. If you also specify a value for
--   <tt>DefaultAvailabilityZone</tt>, the subnet must be in that zone. For
--   information on default values and when this parameter is required, see
--   the <tt>VpcId</tt> parameter description.
[$sel:defaultSubnetId:CreateStack'] :: CreateStack -> Maybe Text

-- | The configuration manager. When you create a stack we recommend that
--   you use the configuration manager to specify the Chef version: 12,
--   11.10, or 11.4 for Linux stacks, or 12.2 for Windows stacks. The
--   default value for Linux stacks is currently 12.
[$sel:configurationManager:CreateStack'] :: CreateStack -> Maybe StackConfigurationManager

-- | The stack's host name theme, with spaces replaced by underscores. The
--   theme is used to generate host names for the stack's instances. By
--   default, <tt>HostnameTheme</tt> is set to <tt>Layer_Dependent</tt>,
--   which creates host names by appending integers to the layer's short
--   name. The other themes are:
--   
--   <ul>
--   <li><pre>Baked_Goods</pre></li>
--   <li><pre>Clouds</pre></li>
--   <li><pre>Europe_Cities</pre></li>
--   <li><pre>Fruits</pre></li>
--   <li><pre>Greek_Deities_and_Titans</pre></li>
--   <li><pre>Legendary_creatures_from_Japan</pre></li>
--   <li><pre>Planets_and_Moons</pre></li>
--   <li><pre>Roman_Deities</pre></li>
--   <li><pre>Scottish_Islands</pre></li>
--   <li><pre>US_Cities</pre></li>
--   <li><pre>Wild_Cats</pre></li>
--   </ul>
--   
--   To obtain a generated host name, call <tt>GetHostNameSuggestion</tt>,
--   which returns a host name based on the current theme.
[$sel:hostnameTheme:CreateStack'] :: CreateStack -> Maybe Text

-- | The stack name.
[$sel:name:CreateStack'] :: CreateStack -> Text

-- | The stack's AWS region, such as <tt>ap-south-1</tt>. For more
--   information about Amazon regions, see <a>Regions and Endpoints</a>.
--   
--   In the AWS CLI, this API maps to the <tt>--stack-region</tt>
--   parameter. If the <tt>--stack-region</tt> parameter and the AWS CLI
--   common parameter <tt>--region</tt> are set to the same value, the
--   stack uses a <i>regional</i> endpoint. If the <tt>--stack-region</tt>
--   parameter is not set, but the AWS CLI <tt>--region</tt> parameter is,
--   this also results in a stack with a <i>regional</i> endpoint. However,
--   if the <tt>--region</tt> parameter is set to <tt>us-east-1</tt>, and
--   the <tt>--stack-region</tt> parameter is set to one of the following,
--   then the stack uses a legacy or <i>classic</i> region: <tt>us-west-1,
--   us-west-2, sa-east-1, eu-central-1, eu-west-1, ap-northeast-1,
--   ap-southeast-1, ap-southeast-2</tt>. In this case, the actual API
--   endpoint of the stack is in <tt>us-east-1</tt>. Only the preceding
--   regions are supported as classic regions in the <tt>us-east-1</tt> API
--   endpoint. Because it is a best practice to choose the regional
--   endpoint that is closest to where you manage AWS, we recommend that
--   you use regional endpoints for new stacks. The AWS CLI common
--   <tt>--region</tt> parameter always specifies a regional API endpoint;
--   it cannot be used to specify a classic AWS OpsWorks Stacks region.
[$sel:region:CreateStack'] :: CreateStack -> Text

-- | The stack's AWS Identity and Access Management (IAM) role, which
--   allows AWS OpsWorks Stacks to work with AWS resources on your behalf.
--   You must set this parameter to the Amazon Resource Name (ARN) for an
--   existing IAM role. For more information about IAM ARNs, see <a>Using
--   Identifiers</a>.
[$sel:serviceRoleArn:CreateStack'] :: CreateStack -> Text

-- | The Amazon Resource Name (ARN) of an IAM profile that is the default
--   profile for all of the stack's EC2 instances. For more information
--   about IAM ARNs, see <a>Using Identifiers</a>.
[$sel:defaultInstanceProfileArn:CreateStack'] :: CreateStack -> Text

-- | Create a value of <a>CreateStack</a> with all optional fields omitted.
--   
--   Use <a>generic-lens</a> or <a>optics</a> to modify other optional
--   fields.
--   
--   The following record fields are available, with the corresponding
--   lenses provided for backwards compatibility:
--   
--   <a>$sel:defaultRootDeviceType:CreateStack'</a>,
--   <a>createStack_defaultRootDeviceType</a> - The default root device
--   type. This value is the default for all instances in the stack, but
--   you can override it when you create an instance. The default option is
--   <tt>instance-store</tt>. For more information, see <a>Storage for the
--   Root Device</a>.
--   
--   <a>$sel:vpcId:CreateStack'</a>, <a>createStack_vpcId</a> - The ID of
--   the VPC that the stack is to be launched into. The VPC must be in the
--   stack's region. All instances are launched into this VPC. You cannot
--   change the ID later.
--   
--   <ul>
--   <li>If your account supports EC2-Classic, the default value is <tt>no
--   VPC</tt>.</li>
--   <li>If your account does not support EC2-Classic, the default value is
--   the default VPC for the specified region.</li>
--   </ul>
--   
--   If the VPC ID corresponds to a default VPC and you have specified
--   either the <tt>DefaultAvailabilityZone</tt> or the
--   <tt>DefaultSubnetId</tt> parameter only, AWS OpsWorks Stacks infers
--   the value of the other parameter. If you specify neither parameter,
--   AWS OpsWorks Stacks sets these parameters to the first valid
--   Availability Zone for the specified region and the corresponding
--   default VPC subnet ID, respectively.
--   
--   If you specify a nondefault VPC ID, note the following:
--   
--   <ul>
--   <li>It must belong to a VPC in your account that is in the specified
--   region.</li>
--   <li>You must specify a value for <tt>DefaultSubnetId</tt>.</li>
--   </ul>
--   
--   For more information about how to use AWS OpsWorks Stacks with a VPC,
--   see <a>Running a Stack in a VPC</a>. For more information about
--   default VPC and EC2-Classic, see <a>Supported Platforms</a>.
--   
--   <a>$sel:chefConfiguration:CreateStack'</a>,
--   <a>createStack_chefConfiguration</a> - A <tt>ChefConfiguration</tt>
--   object that specifies whether to enable Berkshelf and the Berkshelf
--   version on Chef 11.10 stacks. For more information, see <a>Create a
--   New Stack</a>.
--   
--   <a>$sel:agentVersion:CreateStack'</a>, <a>createStack_agentVersion</a>
--   - The default AWS OpsWorks Stacks agent version. You have the
--   following options:
--   
--   <ul>
--   <li>Auto-update - Set this parameter to <tt>LATEST</tt>. AWS OpsWorks
--   Stacks automatically installs new agent versions on the stack's
--   instances as soon as they are available.</li>
--   <li>Fixed version - Set this parameter to your preferred agent
--   version. To update the agent version, you must edit the stack
--   configuration and specify a new version. AWS OpsWorks Stacks then
--   automatically installs that version on the stack's instances.</li>
--   </ul>
--   
--   The default setting is the most recent release of the agent. To
--   specify an agent version, you must use the complete version number,
--   not the abbreviated number shown on the console. For a list of
--   available agent version numbers, call DescribeAgentVersions.
--   AgentVersion cannot be set to Chef 12.2.
--   
--   You can also specify an agent version when you create or update an
--   instance, which overrides the stack's default setting.
--   
--   <a>$sel:defaultSshKeyName:CreateStack'</a>,
--   <a>createStack_defaultSshKeyName</a> - A default Amazon EC2 key pair
--   name. The default value is none. If you specify a key pair name, AWS
--   OpsWorks installs the public key on the instance and you can use the
--   private key with an SSH client to log in to the instance. For more
--   information, see <a>Using SSH to Communicate with an Instance</a> and
--   <a>Managing SSH Access</a>. You can override this setting by
--   specifying a different key pair, or no key pair, when you <a>create an
--   instance</a>.
--   
--   <a>$sel:customJson:CreateStack'</a>, <a>createStack_customJson</a> - A
--   string that contains user-defined, custom JSON. It can be used to
--   override the corresponding default stack configuration attribute
--   values or to pass data to recipes. The string should be in the
--   following format:
--   
--   <pre>
--   "{\"key1\": \"value1\", \"key2\": \"value2\",...}"
--   </pre>
--   
--   For more information about custom JSON, see <a>Use Custom JSON to
--   Modify the Stack Configuration Attributes</a>.
--   
--   <a>$sel:customCookbooksSource:CreateStack'</a>,
--   <a>createStack_customCookbooksSource</a> - Contains the information
--   required to retrieve an app or cookbook from a repository. For more
--   information, see <a>Adding Apps</a> or <a>Cookbooks and Recipes</a>.
--   
--   <a>$sel:defaultAvailabilityZone:CreateStack'</a>,
--   <a>createStack_defaultAvailabilityZone</a> - The stack's default
--   Availability Zone, which must be in the specified region. For more
--   information, see <a>Regions and Endpoints</a>. If you also specify a
--   value for <tt>DefaultSubnetId</tt>, the subnet must be in the same
--   zone. For more information, see the <tt>VpcId</tt> parameter
--   description.
--   
--   <a>$sel:attributes:CreateStack'</a>, <a>createStack_attributes</a> -
--   One or more user-defined key-value pairs to be added to the stack
--   attributes.
--   
--   <a>$sel:defaultOs:CreateStack'</a>, <a>createStack_defaultOs</a> - The
--   stack's default operating system, which is installed on every instance
--   unless you specify a different operating system when you create the
--   instance. You can specify one of the following.
--   
--   <ul>
--   <li>A supported Linux operating system: An Amazon Linux version, such
--   as <tt>Amazon Linux 2018.03</tt>, <tt>Amazon Linux 2017.09</tt>,
--   <tt>Amazon Linux 2017.03</tt>, <tt>Amazon Linux 2016.09</tt>,
--   <tt>Amazon Linux 2016.03</tt>, <tt>Amazon Linux 2015.09</tt>, or
--   <tt>Amazon Linux 2015.03</tt>.</li>
--   <li>A supported Ubuntu operating system, such as <tt>Ubuntu 16.04
--   LTS</tt>, <tt>Ubuntu 14.04 LTS</tt>, or <tt>Ubuntu 12.04
--   LTS</tt>.</li>
--   <li><pre>CentOS Linux 7</pre></li>
--   <li><pre>Red Hat Enterprise Linux 7</pre></li>
--   <li>A supported Windows operating system, such as <tt>Microsoft
--   Windows Server 2012 R2 Base</tt>, <tt>Microsoft Windows Server 2012 R2
--   with SQL Server Express</tt>, <tt>Microsoft Windows Server 2012 R2
--   with SQL Server Standard</tt>, or <tt>Microsoft Windows Server 2012 R2
--   with SQL Server Web</tt>.</li>
--   <li>A custom AMI: <tt>Custom</tt>. You specify the custom AMI you want
--   to use when you create instances. For more information, see <a>Using
--   Custom AMIs</a>.</li>
--   </ul>
--   
--   The default option is the current Amazon Linux version. For more
--   information about supported operating systems, see <a>AWS OpsWorks
--   Stacks Operating Systems</a>.
--   
--   <a>$sel:useOpsworksSecurityGroups:CreateStack'</a>,
--   <a>createStack_useOpsworksSecurityGroups</a> - Whether to associate
--   the AWS OpsWorks Stacks built-in security groups with the stack's
--   layers.
--   
--   AWS OpsWorks Stacks provides a standard set of built-in security
--   groups, one for each layer, which are associated with layers by
--   default. With <tt>UseOpsworksSecurityGroups</tt> you can instead
--   provide your own custom security groups.
--   <tt>UseOpsworksSecurityGroups</tt> has the following settings:
--   
--   <ul>
--   <li>True - AWS OpsWorks Stacks automatically associates the
--   appropriate built-in security group with each layer (default setting).
--   You can associate additional security groups with a layer after you
--   create it, but you cannot delete the built-in security group.</li>
--   <li>False - AWS OpsWorks Stacks does not associate built-in security
--   groups with layers. You must create appropriate EC2 security groups
--   and associate a security group with each layer that you create.
--   However, you can still manually associate a built-in security group
--   with a layer on creation; custom security groups are required only for
--   those layers that need custom settings.</li>
--   </ul>
--   
--   For more information, see <a>Create a New Stack</a>.
--   
--   <a>$sel:useCustomCookbooks:CreateStack'</a>,
--   <a>createStack_useCustomCookbooks</a> - Whether the stack uses custom
--   cookbooks.
--   
--   <a>$sel:defaultSubnetId:CreateStack'</a>,
--   <a>createStack_defaultSubnetId</a> - The stack's default VPC subnet
--   ID. This parameter is required if you specify a value for the
--   <tt>VpcId</tt> parameter. All instances are launched into this subnet
--   unless you specify otherwise when you create the instance. If you also
--   specify a value for <tt>DefaultAvailabilityZone</tt>, the subnet must
--   be in that zone. For information on default values and when this
--   parameter is required, see the <tt>VpcId</tt> parameter description.
--   
--   <a>$sel:configurationManager:CreateStack'</a>,
--   <a>createStack_configurationManager</a> - The configuration manager.
--   When you create a stack we recommend that you use the configuration
--   manager to specify the Chef version: 12, 11.10, or 11.4 for Linux
--   stacks, or 12.2 for Windows stacks. The default value for Linux stacks
--   is currently 12.
--   
--   <a>$sel:hostnameTheme:CreateStack'</a>,
--   <a>createStack_hostnameTheme</a> - The stack's host name theme, with
--   spaces replaced by underscores. The theme is used to generate host
--   names for the stack's instances. By default, <tt>HostnameTheme</tt> is
--   set to <tt>Layer_Dependent</tt>, which creates host names by appending
--   integers to the layer's short name. The other themes are:
--   
--   <ul>
--   <li><pre>Baked_Goods</pre></li>
--   <li><pre>Clouds</pre></li>
--   <li><pre>Europe_Cities</pre></li>
--   <li><pre>Fruits</pre></li>
--   <li><pre>Greek_Deities_and_Titans</pre></li>
--   <li><pre>Legendary_creatures_from_Japan</pre></li>
--   <li><pre>Planets_and_Moons</pre></li>
--   <li><pre>Roman_Deities</pre></li>
--   <li><pre>Scottish_Islands</pre></li>
--   <li><pre>US_Cities</pre></li>
--   <li><pre>Wild_Cats</pre></li>
--   </ul>
--   
--   To obtain a generated host name, call <tt>GetHostNameSuggestion</tt>,
--   which returns a host name based on the current theme.
--   
--   <a>$sel:name:CreateStack'</a>, <a>createStack_name</a> - The stack
--   name.
--   
--   <a>$sel:region:CreateStack'</a>, <a>createStack_region</a> - The
--   stack's AWS region, such as <tt>ap-south-1</tt>. For more information
--   about Amazon regions, see <a>Regions and Endpoints</a>.
--   
--   In the AWS CLI, this API maps to the <tt>--stack-region</tt>
--   parameter. If the <tt>--stack-region</tt> parameter and the AWS CLI
--   common parameter <tt>--region</tt> are set to the same value, the
--   stack uses a <i>regional</i> endpoint. If the <tt>--stack-region</tt>
--   parameter is not set, but the AWS CLI <tt>--region</tt> parameter is,
--   this also results in a stack with a <i>regional</i> endpoint. However,
--   if the <tt>--region</tt> parameter is set to <tt>us-east-1</tt>, and
--   the <tt>--stack-region</tt> parameter is set to one of the following,
--   then the stack uses a legacy or <i>classic</i> region: <tt>us-west-1,
--   us-west-2, sa-east-1, eu-central-1, eu-west-1, ap-northeast-1,
--   ap-southeast-1, ap-southeast-2</tt>. In this case, the actual API
--   endpoint of the stack is in <tt>us-east-1</tt>. Only the preceding
--   regions are supported as classic regions in the <tt>us-east-1</tt> API
--   endpoint. Because it is a best practice to choose the regional
--   endpoint that is closest to where you manage AWS, we recommend that
--   you use regional endpoints for new stacks. The AWS CLI common
--   <tt>--region</tt> parameter always specifies a regional API endpoint;
--   it cannot be used to specify a classic AWS OpsWorks Stacks region.
--   
--   <a>$sel:serviceRoleArn:CreateStack'</a>,
--   <a>createStack_serviceRoleArn</a> - The stack's AWS Identity and
--   Access Management (IAM) role, which allows AWS OpsWorks Stacks to work
--   with AWS resources on your behalf. You must set this parameter to the
--   Amazon Resource Name (ARN) for an existing IAM role. For more
--   information about IAM ARNs, see <a>Using Identifiers</a>.
--   
--   <a>$sel:defaultInstanceProfileArn:CreateStack'</a>,
--   <a>createStack_defaultInstanceProfileArn</a> - The Amazon Resource
--   Name (ARN) of an IAM profile that is the default profile for all of
--   the stack's EC2 instances. For more information about IAM ARNs, see
--   <a>Using Identifiers</a>.
newCreateStack :: Text -> Text -> Text -> Text -> CreateStack

-- | The default root device type. This value is the default for all
--   instances in the stack, but you can override it when you create an
--   instance. The default option is <tt>instance-store</tt>. For more
--   information, see <a>Storage for the Root Device</a>.
createStack_defaultRootDeviceType :: Lens' CreateStack (Maybe RootDeviceType)

-- | The ID of the VPC that the stack is to be launched into. The VPC must
--   be in the stack's region. All instances are launched into this VPC.
--   You cannot change the ID later.
--   
--   <ul>
--   <li>If your account supports EC2-Classic, the default value is <tt>no
--   VPC</tt>.</li>
--   <li>If your account does not support EC2-Classic, the default value is
--   the default VPC for the specified region.</li>
--   </ul>
--   
--   If the VPC ID corresponds to a default VPC and you have specified
--   either the <tt>DefaultAvailabilityZone</tt> or the
--   <tt>DefaultSubnetId</tt> parameter only, AWS OpsWorks Stacks infers
--   the value of the other parameter. If you specify neither parameter,
--   AWS OpsWorks Stacks sets these parameters to the first valid
--   Availability Zone for the specified region and the corresponding
--   default VPC subnet ID, respectively.
--   
--   If you specify a nondefault VPC ID, note the following:
--   
--   <ul>
--   <li>It must belong to a VPC in your account that is in the specified
--   region.</li>
--   <li>You must specify a value for <tt>DefaultSubnetId</tt>.</li>
--   </ul>
--   
--   For more information about how to use AWS OpsWorks Stacks with a VPC,
--   see <a>Running a Stack in a VPC</a>. For more information about
--   default VPC and EC2-Classic, see <a>Supported Platforms</a>.
createStack_vpcId :: Lens' CreateStack (Maybe Text)

-- | A <tt>ChefConfiguration</tt> object that specifies whether to enable
--   Berkshelf and the Berkshelf version on Chef 11.10 stacks. For more
--   information, see <a>Create a New Stack</a>.
createStack_chefConfiguration :: Lens' CreateStack (Maybe ChefConfiguration)

-- | The default AWS OpsWorks Stacks agent version. You have the following
--   options:
--   
--   <ul>
--   <li>Auto-update - Set this parameter to <tt>LATEST</tt>. AWS OpsWorks
--   Stacks automatically installs new agent versions on the stack's
--   instances as soon as they are available.</li>
--   <li>Fixed version - Set this parameter to your preferred agent
--   version. To update the agent version, you must edit the stack
--   configuration and specify a new version. AWS OpsWorks Stacks then
--   automatically installs that version on the stack's instances.</li>
--   </ul>
--   
--   The default setting is the most recent release of the agent. To
--   specify an agent version, you must use the complete version number,
--   not the abbreviated number shown on the console. For a list of
--   available agent version numbers, call DescribeAgentVersions.
--   AgentVersion cannot be set to Chef 12.2.
--   
--   You can also specify an agent version when you create or update an
--   instance, which overrides the stack's default setting.
createStack_agentVersion :: Lens' CreateStack (Maybe Text)

-- | A default Amazon EC2 key pair name. The default value is none. If you
--   specify a key pair name, AWS OpsWorks installs the public key on the
--   instance and you can use the private key with an SSH client to log in
--   to the instance. For more information, see <a>Using SSH to Communicate
--   with an Instance</a> and <a>Managing SSH Access</a>. You can override
--   this setting by specifying a different key pair, or no key pair, when
--   you <a>create an instance</a>.
createStack_defaultSshKeyName :: Lens' CreateStack (Maybe Text)

-- | A string that contains user-defined, custom JSON. It can be used to
--   override the corresponding default stack configuration attribute
--   values or to pass data to recipes. The string should be in the
--   following format:
--   
--   <pre>
--   "{\"key1\": \"value1\", \"key2\": \"value2\",...}"
--   </pre>
--   
--   For more information about custom JSON, see <a>Use Custom JSON to
--   Modify the Stack Configuration Attributes</a>.
createStack_customJson :: Lens' CreateStack (Maybe Text)

-- | Contains the information required to retrieve an app or cookbook from
--   a repository. For more information, see <a>Adding Apps</a> or
--   <a>Cookbooks and Recipes</a>.
createStack_customCookbooksSource :: Lens' CreateStack (Maybe Source)

-- | The stack's default Availability Zone, which must be in the specified
--   region. For more information, see <a>Regions and Endpoints</a>. If you
--   also specify a value for <tt>DefaultSubnetId</tt>, the subnet must be
--   in the same zone. For more information, see the <tt>VpcId</tt>
--   parameter description.
createStack_defaultAvailabilityZone :: Lens' CreateStack (Maybe Text)

-- | One or more user-defined key-value pairs to be added to the stack
--   attributes.
createStack_attributes :: Lens' CreateStack (Maybe (HashMap StackAttributesKeys (Maybe Text)))

-- | The stack's default operating system, which is installed on every
--   instance unless you specify a different operating system when you
--   create the instance. You can specify one of the following.
--   
--   <ul>
--   <li>A supported Linux operating system: An Amazon Linux version, such
--   as <tt>Amazon Linux 2018.03</tt>, <tt>Amazon Linux 2017.09</tt>,
--   <tt>Amazon Linux 2017.03</tt>, <tt>Amazon Linux 2016.09</tt>,
--   <tt>Amazon Linux 2016.03</tt>, <tt>Amazon Linux 2015.09</tt>, or
--   <tt>Amazon Linux 2015.03</tt>.</li>
--   <li>A supported Ubuntu operating system, such as <tt>Ubuntu 16.04
--   LTS</tt>, <tt>Ubuntu 14.04 LTS</tt>, or <tt>Ubuntu 12.04
--   LTS</tt>.</li>
--   <li><pre>CentOS Linux 7</pre></li>
--   <li><pre>Red Hat Enterprise Linux 7</pre></li>
--   <li>A supported Windows operating system, such as <tt>Microsoft
--   Windows Server 2012 R2 Base</tt>, <tt>Microsoft Windows Server 2012 R2
--   with SQL Server Express</tt>, <tt>Microsoft Windows Server 2012 R2
--   with SQL Server Standard</tt>, or <tt>Microsoft Windows Server 2012 R2
--   with SQL Server Web</tt>.</li>
--   <li>A custom AMI: <tt>Custom</tt>. You specify the custom AMI you want
--   to use when you create instances. For more information, see <a>Using
--   Custom AMIs</a>.</li>
--   </ul>
--   
--   The default option is the current Amazon Linux version. For more
--   information about supported operating systems, see <a>AWS OpsWorks
--   Stacks Operating Systems</a>.
createStack_defaultOs :: Lens' CreateStack (Maybe Text)

-- | Whether to associate the AWS OpsWorks Stacks built-in security groups
--   with the stack's layers.
--   
--   AWS OpsWorks Stacks provides a standard set of built-in security
--   groups, one for each layer, which are associated with layers by
--   default. With <tt>UseOpsworksSecurityGroups</tt> you can instead
--   provide your own custom security groups.
--   <tt>UseOpsworksSecurityGroups</tt> has the following settings:
--   
--   <ul>
--   <li>True - AWS OpsWorks Stacks automatically associates the
--   appropriate built-in security group with each layer (default setting).
--   You can associate additional security groups with a layer after you
--   create it, but you cannot delete the built-in security group.</li>
--   <li>False - AWS OpsWorks Stacks does not associate built-in security
--   groups with layers. You must create appropriate EC2 security groups
--   and associate a security group with each layer that you create.
--   However, you can still manually associate a built-in security group
--   with a layer on creation; custom security groups are required only for
--   those layers that need custom settings.</li>
--   </ul>
--   
--   For more information, see <a>Create a New Stack</a>.
createStack_useOpsworksSecurityGroups :: Lens' CreateStack (Maybe Bool)

-- | Whether the stack uses custom cookbooks.
createStack_useCustomCookbooks :: Lens' CreateStack (Maybe Bool)

-- | The stack's default VPC subnet ID. This parameter is required if you
--   specify a value for the <tt>VpcId</tt> parameter. All instances are
--   launched into this subnet unless you specify otherwise when you create
--   the instance. If you also specify a value for
--   <tt>DefaultAvailabilityZone</tt>, the subnet must be in that zone. For
--   information on default values and when this parameter is required, see
--   the <tt>VpcId</tt> parameter description.
createStack_defaultSubnetId :: Lens' CreateStack (Maybe Text)

-- | The configuration manager. When you create a stack we recommend that
--   you use the configuration manager to specify the Chef version: 12,
--   11.10, or 11.4 for Linux stacks, or 12.2 for Windows stacks. The
--   default value for Linux stacks is currently 12.
createStack_configurationManager :: Lens' CreateStack (Maybe StackConfigurationManager)

-- | The stack's host name theme, with spaces replaced by underscores. The
--   theme is used to generate host names for the stack's instances. By
--   default, <tt>HostnameTheme</tt> is set to <tt>Layer_Dependent</tt>,
--   which creates host names by appending integers to the layer's short
--   name. The other themes are:
--   
--   <ul>
--   <li><pre>Baked_Goods</pre></li>
--   <li><pre>Clouds</pre></li>
--   <li><pre>Europe_Cities</pre></li>
--   <li><pre>Fruits</pre></li>
--   <li><pre>Greek_Deities_and_Titans</pre></li>
--   <li><pre>Legendary_creatures_from_Japan</pre></li>
--   <li><pre>Planets_and_Moons</pre></li>
--   <li><pre>Roman_Deities</pre></li>
--   <li><pre>Scottish_Islands</pre></li>
--   <li><pre>US_Cities</pre></li>
--   <li><pre>Wild_Cats</pre></li>
--   </ul>
--   
--   To obtain a generated host name, call <tt>GetHostNameSuggestion</tt>,
--   which returns a host name based on the current theme.
createStack_hostnameTheme :: Lens' CreateStack (Maybe Text)

-- | The stack name.
createStack_name :: Lens' CreateStack Text

-- | The stack's AWS region, such as <tt>ap-south-1</tt>. For more
--   information about Amazon regions, see <a>Regions and Endpoints</a>.
--   
--   In the AWS CLI, this API maps to the <tt>--stack-region</tt>
--   parameter. If the <tt>--stack-region</tt> parameter and the AWS CLI
--   common parameter <tt>--region</tt> are set to the same value, the
--   stack uses a <i>regional</i> endpoint. If the <tt>--stack-region</tt>
--   parameter is not set, but the AWS CLI <tt>--region</tt> parameter is,
--   this also results in a stack with a <i>regional</i> endpoint. However,
--   if the <tt>--region</tt> parameter is set to <tt>us-east-1</tt>, and
--   the <tt>--stack-region</tt> parameter is set to one of the following,
--   then the stack uses a legacy or <i>classic</i> region: <tt>us-west-1,
--   us-west-2, sa-east-1, eu-central-1, eu-west-1, ap-northeast-1,
--   ap-southeast-1, ap-southeast-2</tt>. In this case, the actual API
--   endpoint of the stack is in <tt>us-east-1</tt>. Only the preceding
--   regions are supported as classic regions in the <tt>us-east-1</tt> API
--   endpoint. Because it is a best practice to choose the regional
--   endpoint that is closest to where you manage AWS, we recommend that
--   you use regional endpoints for new stacks. The AWS CLI common
--   <tt>--region</tt> parameter always specifies a regional API endpoint;
--   it cannot be used to specify a classic AWS OpsWorks Stacks region.
createStack_region :: Lens' CreateStack Text

-- | The stack's AWS Identity and Access Management (IAM) role, which
--   allows AWS OpsWorks Stacks to work with AWS resources on your behalf.
--   You must set this parameter to the Amazon Resource Name (ARN) for an
--   existing IAM role. For more information about IAM ARNs, see <a>Using
--   Identifiers</a>.
createStack_serviceRoleArn :: Lens' CreateStack Text

-- | The Amazon Resource Name (ARN) of an IAM profile that is the default
--   profile for all of the stack's EC2 instances. For more information
--   about IAM ARNs, see <a>Using Identifiers</a>.
createStack_defaultInstanceProfileArn :: Lens' CreateStack Text

-- | Contains the response to a <tt>CreateStack</tt> request.
--   
--   <i>See:</i> <a>newCreateStackResponse</a> smart constructor.
data CreateStackResponse
CreateStackResponse' :: Maybe Text -> Int -> CreateStackResponse

-- | The stack ID, which is an opaque string that you use to identify the
--   stack when performing actions such as <tt>DescribeStacks</tt>.
[$sel:stackId:CreateStackResponse'] :: CreateStackResponse -> Maybe Text

-- | The response's http status code.
[$sel:httpStatus:CreateStackResponse'] :: CreateStackResponse -> Int

-- | Create a value of <a>CreateStackResponse</a> with all optional fields
--   omitted.
--   
--   Use <a>generic-lens</a> or <a>optics</a> to modify other optional
--   fields.
--   
--   The following record fields are available, with the corresponding
--   lenses provided for backwards compatibility:
--   
--   <a>$sel:stackId:CreateStackResponse'</a>,
--   <a>createStackResponse_stackId</a> - The stack ID, which is an opaque
--   string that you use to identify the stack when performing actions such
--   as <tt>DescribeStacks</tt>.
--   
--   <a>$sel:httpStatus:CreateStackResponse'</a>,
--   <a>createStackResponse_httpStatus</a> - The response's http status
--   code.
newCreateStackResponse :: Int -> CreateStackResponse

-- | The stack ID, which is an opaque string that you use to identify the
--   stack when performing actions such as <tt>DescribeStacks</tt>.
createStackResponse_stackId :: Lens' CreateStackResponse (Maybe Text)

-- | The response's http status code.
createStackResponse_httpStatus :: Lens' CreateStackResponse Int
instance GHC.Generics.Generic Network.AWS.OpsWorks.CreateStack.CreateStack
instance GHC.Show.Show Network.AWS.OpsWorks.CreateStack.CreateStack
instance GHC.Read.Read Network.AWS.OpsWorks.CreateStack.CreateStack
instance GHC.Classes.Eq Network.AWS.OpsWorks.CreateStack.CreateStack
instance GHC.Generics.Generic Network.AWS.OpsWorks.CreateStack.CreateStackResponse
instance GHC.Show.Show Network.AWS.OpsWorks.CreateStack.CreateStackResponse
instance GHC.Read.Read Network.AWS.OpsWorks.CreateStack.CreateStackResponse
instance GHC.Classes.Eq Network.AWS.OpsWorks.CreateStack.CreateStackResponse
instance Network.AWS.Types.AWSRequest Network.AWS.OpsWorks.CreateStack.CreateStack
instance Control.DeepSeq.NFData Network.AWS.OpsWorks.CreateStack.CreateStackResponse
instance Data.Hashable.Class.Hashable Network.AWS.OpsWorks.CreateStack.CreateStack
instance Control.DeepSeq.NFData Network.AWS.OpsWorks.CreateStack.CreateStack
instance Network.AWS.Data.Headers.ToHeaders Network.AWS.OpsWorks.CreateStack.CreateStack
instance Data.Aeson.Types.ToJSON.ToJSON Network.AWS.OpsWorks.CreateStack.CreateStack
instance Network.AWS.Data.Path.ToPath Network.AWS.OpsWorks.CreateStack.CreateStack
instance Network.AWS.Data.Query.ToQuery Network.AWS.OpsWorks.CreateStack.CreateStack


-- | Creates a layer. For more information, see <a>How to Create a
--   Layer</a>.
--   
--   You should use <b>CreateLayer</b> for noncustom layer types such as
--   PHP App Server only if the stack does not have an existing layer of
--   that type. A stack can have at most one instance of each noncustom
--   layer; if you attempt to create a second instance, <b>CreateLayer</b>
--   fails. A stack can have an arbitrary number of custom layers, so you
--   can call <b>CreateLayer</b> as many times as you like for that layer
--   type.
--   
--   <b>Required Permissions</b>: To use this action, an IAM user must have
--   a Manage permissions level for the stack, or an attached policy that
--   explicitly grants permissions. For more information on user
--   permissions, see <a>Managing User Permissions</a>.
module Network.AWS.OpsWorks.CreateLayer

-- | <i>See:</i> <a>newCreateLayer</a> smart constructor.
data CreateLayer
CreateLayer' :: Maybe Text -> Maybe [Text] -> Maybe Bool -> Maybe CloudWatchLogsConfiguration -> Maybe LifecycleEventConfiguration -> Maybe Recipes -> Maybe Text -> Maybe [VolumeConfiguration] -> Maybe Bool -> Maybe [Text] -> Maybe (HashMap LayerAttributesKeys (Maybe Text)) -> Maybe Bool -> Maybe Bool -> Maybe Bool -> Text -> LayerType -> Text -> Text -> CreateLayer

-- | The ARN of an IAM profile to be used for the layer's EC2 instances.
--   For more information about IAM ARNs, see <a>Using Identifiers</a>.
[$sel:customInstanceProfileArn:CreateLayer'] :: CreateLayer -> Maybe Text

-- | An array containing the layer custom security group IDs.
[$sel:customSecurityGroupIds:CreateLayer'] :: CreateLayer -> Maybe [Text]

-- | Whether to install operating system and package updates when the
--   instance boots. The default value is <tt>true</tt>. To control when
--   updates are installed, set this value to <tt>false</tt>. You must then
--   update your instances manually by using CreateDeployment to run the
--   <tt>update_dependencies</tt> stack command or by manually running
--   <tt>yum</tt> (Amazon Linux) or <tt>apt-get</tt> (Ubuntu) on the
--   instances.
--   
--   To ensure that your instances have the latest security updates, we
--   strongly recommend using the default value of <tt>true</tt>.
[$sel:installUpdatesOnBoot:CreateLayer'] :: CreateLayer -> Maybe Bool

-- | Specifies CloudWatch Logs configuration options for the layer. For
--   more information, see CloudWatchLogsLogStream.
[$sel:cloudWatchLogsConfiguration:CreateLayer'] :: CreateLayer -> Maybe CloudWatchLogsConfiguration

-- | A <tt>LifeCycleEventConfiguration</tt> object that you can use to
--   configure the Shutdown event to specify an execution timeout and
--   enable or disable Elastic Load Balancer connection draining.
[$sel:lifecycleEventConfiguration:CreateLayer'] :: CreateLayer -> Maybe LifecycleEventConfiguration

-- | A <tt>LayerCustomRecipes</tt> object that specifies the layer custom
--   recipes.
[$sel:customRecipes:CreateLayer'] :: CreateLayer -> Maybe Recipes

-- | A JSON-formatted string containing custom stack configuration and
--   deployment attributes to be installed on the layer's instances. For
--   more information, see <a>Using Custom JSON</a>. This feature is
--   supported as of version 1.7.42 of the AWS CLI.
[$sel:customJson:CreateLayer'] :: CreateLayer -> Maybe Text

-- | A <tt>VolumeConfigurations</tt> object that describes the layer's
--   Amazon EBS volumes.
[$sel:volumeConfigurations:CreateLayer'] :: CreateLayer -> Maybe [VolumeConfiguration]

-- | Whether to disable auto healing for the layer.
[$sel:enableAutoHealing:CreateLayer'] :: CreateLayer -> Maybe Bool

-- | An array of <tt>Package</tt> objects that describes the layer
--   packages.
[$sel:packages:CreateLayer'] :: CreateLayer -> Maybe [Text]

-- | One or more user-defined key-value pairs to be added to the stack
--   attributes.
--   
--   To create a cluster layer, set the <tt>EcsClusterArn</tt> attribute to
--   the cluster's ARN.
[$sel:attributes:CreateLayer'] :: CreateLayer -> Maybe (HashMap LayerAttributesKeys (Maybe Text))

-- | For stacks that are running in a VPC, whether to automatically assign
--   a public IP address to the layer's instances. For more information,
--   see <a>How to Edit a Layer</a>.
[$sel:autoAssignPublicIps:CreateLayer'] :: CreateLayer -> Maybe Bool

-- | Whether to use Amazon EBS-optimized instances.
[$sel:useEbsOptimizedInstances:CreateLayer'] :: CreateLayer -> Maybe Bool

-- | Whether to automatically assign an <a>Elastic IP address</a> to the
--   layer's instances. For more information, see <a>How to Edit a
--   Layer</a>.
[$sel:autoAssignElasticIps:CreateLayer'] :: CreateLayer -> Maybe Bool

-- | The layer stack ID.
[$sel:stackId:CreateLayer'] :: CreateLayer -> Text

-- | The layer type. A stack cannot have more than one built-in layer of
--   the same type. It can have any number of custom layers. Built-in
--   layers are not available in Chef 12 stacks.
[$sel:type':CreateLayer'] :: CreateLayer -> LayerType

-- | The layer name, which is used by the console.
[$sel:name:CreateLayer'] :: CreateLayer -> Text

-- | For custom layers only, use this parameter to specify the layer's
--   short name, which is used internally by AWS OpsWorks Stacks and by
--   Chef recipes. The short name is also used as the name for the
--   directory where your app files are installed. It can have a maximum of
--   200 characters, which are limited to the alphanumeric characters, '-',
--   '_', and '.'.
--   
--   The built-in layers' short names are defined by AWS OpsWorks Stacks.
--   For more information, see the <a>Layer Reference</a>.
[$sel:shortname:CreateLayer'] :: CreateLayer -> Text

-- | Create a value of <a>CreateLayer</a> with all optional fields omitted.
--
