-- | Creates an instance in a specified stack. For more information, see
--   <a>Adding an Instance to a Layer</a>.
--   
--   <b>Required Permissions</b>: To use this action, an IAM user must have
--   a Manage permissions level for the stack, or an attached policy that
--   explicitly grants permissions. For more information on user
--   permissions, see <a>Managing User Permissions</a>.
module Network.AWS.OpsWorks.CreateInstance

-- | <i>See:</i> <a>newCreateInstance</a> smart constructor.
data CreateInstance
CreateInstance' :: Maybe Bool -> Maybe Text -> Maybe Text -> Maybe Text -> Maybe Text -> Maybe Text -> Maybe Bool -> Maybe Text -> Maybe Text -> Maybe Text -> Maybe AutoScalingType -> Maybe Architecture -> Maybe Text -> Maybe RootDeviceType -> Maybe [BlockDeviceMapping] -> Text -> [Text] -> Text -> CreateInstance

-- | Whether to install operating system and package updates when the
--   instance boots. The default value is <tt>true</tt>. To control when
--   updates are installed, set this value to <tt>false</tt>. You must then
--   update your instances manually by using CreateDeployment to run the
--   <tt>update_dependencies</tt> stack command or by manually running
--   <tt>yum</tt> (Amazon Linux) or <tt>apt-get</tt> (Ubuntu) on the
--   instances.
--   
--   We strongly recommend using the default value of <tt>true</tt> to
--   ensure that your instances have the latest security updates.
[$sel:installUpdatesOnBoot:CreateInstance'] :: CreateInstance -> Maybe Bool

-- | The instance's virtualization type, <tt>paravirtual</tt> or
--   <tt>hvm</tt>.
[$sel:virtualizationType:CreateInstance'] :: CreateInstance -> Maybe Text

-- | The instance host name.
[$sel:hostname:CreateInstance'] :: CreateInstance -> Maybe Text

-- | The instance's Amazon EC2 key-pair name.
[$sel:sshKeyName:CreateInstance'] :: CreateInstance -> Maybe Text

-- | The default AWS OpsWorks Stacks agent version. You have the following
--   options:
--   
--   <ul>
--   <li><tt>INHERIT</tt> - Use the stack's default agent version
--   setting.</li>
--   <li><i>version_number</i> - Use the specified agent version. This
--   value overrides the stack's default setting. To update the agent
--   version, edit the instance configuration and specify a new version.
--   AWS OpsWorks Stacks then automatically installs that version on the
--   instance.</li>
--   </ul>
--   
--   The default setting is <tt>INHERIT</tt>. To specify an agent version,
--   you must use the complete version number, not the abbreviated number
--   shown on the console. For a list of available agent version numbers,
--   call DescribeAgentVersions. AgentVersion cannot be set to Chef 12.2.
[$sel:agentVersion:CreateInstance'] :: CreateInstance -> Maybe Text

-- | The ID of the instance's subnet. If the stack is running in a VPC, you
--   can use this parameter to override the stack's default subnet ID value
--   and direct AWS OpsWorks Stacks to launch the instance in a different
--   subnet.
[$sel:subnetId:CreateInstance'] :: CreateInstance -> Maybe Text

-- | Whether to create an Amazon EBS-optimized instance.
[$sel:ebsOptimized:CreateInstance'] :: CreateInstance -> Maybe Bool

-- | The instance's operating system, which must be set to one of the
--   following.
--   
--   <ul>
--   <li>A supported Linux operating system: An Amazon Linux version, such
--   as <tt>Amazon Linux 2018.03</tt>, <tt>Amazon Linux 2017.09</tt>,
--   <tt>Amazon Linux 2017.03</tt>, <tt>Amazon Linux 2016.09</tt>,
--   <tt>Amazon Linux 2016.03</tt>, <tt>Amazon Linux 2015.09</tt>, or
--   <tt>Amazon Linux 2015.03</tt>.</li>
--   <li>A supported Ubuntu operating system, such as <tt>Ubuntu 16.04
--   LTS</tt>, <tt>Ubuntu 14.04 LTS</tt>, or <tt>Ubuntu 12.04
--   LTS</tt>.</li>
--   <li><pre>CentOS Linux 7</pre></li>
--   <li><pre>Red Hat Enterprise Linux 7</pre></li>
--   <li>A supported Windows operating system, such as <tt>Microsoft
--   Windows Server 2012 R2 Base</tt>, <tt>Microsoft Windows Server 2012 R2
--   with SQL Server Express</tt>, <tt>Microsoft Windows Server 2012 R2
--   with SQL Server Standard</tt>, or <tt>Microsoft Windows Server 2012 R2
--   with SQL Server Web</tt>.</li>
--   <li>A custom AMI: <tt>Custom</tt>.</li>
--   </ul>
--   
--   For more information about the supported operating systems, see <a>AWS
--   OpsWorks Stacks Operating Systems</a>.
--   
--   The default option is the current Amazon Linux version. If you set
--   this parameter to <tt>Custom</tt>, you must use the CreateInstance
--   action's AmiId parameter to specify the custom AMI that you want to
--   use. Block device mappings are not supported if the value is
--   <tt>Custom</tt>. For more information about supported operating
--   systems, see <a>Operating Systems</a>For more information about how to
--   use custom AMIs with AWS OpsWorks Stacks, see <a>Using Custom
--   AMIs</a>.
[$sel:os:CreateInstance'] :: CreateInstance -> Maybe Text

-- | The instance Availability Zone. For more information, see <a>Regions
--   and Endpoints</a>.
[$sel:availabilityZone:CreateInstance'] :: CreateInstance -> Maybe Text

-- | The instance's tenancy option. The default option is no tenancy, or if
--   the instance is running in a VPC, inherit tenancy settings from the
--   VPC. The following are valid values for this parameter:
--   <tt>dedicated</tt>, <tt>default</tt>, or <tt>host</tt>. Because there
--   are costs associated with changes in tenancy options, we recommend
--   that you research tenancy options before choosing them for your
--   instances. For more information about dedicated hosts, see
--   <a>Dedicated Hosts Overview</a> and <a>Amazon EC2 Dedicated Hosts</a>.
--   For more information about dedicated instances, see <a>Dedicated
--   Instances</a> and <a>Amazon EC2 Dedicated Instances</a>.
[$sel:tenancy:CreateInstance'] :: CreateInstance -> Maybe Text

-- | For load-based or time-based instances, the type. Windows stacks can
--   use only time-based instances.
[$sel:autoScalingType:CreateInstance'] :: CreateInstance -> Maybe AutoScalingType

-- | The instance architecture. The default option is <tt>x86_64</tt>.
--   Instance types do not necessarily support both architectures. For a
--   list of the architectures that are supported by the different instance
--   types, see <a>Instance Families and Types</a>.
[$sel:architecture:CreateInstance'] :: CreateInstance -> Maybe Architecture

-- | A custom AMI ID to be used to create the instance. The AMI should be
--   based on one of the supported operating systems. For more information,
--   see <a>Using Custom AMIs</a>.
--   
--   If you specify a custom AMI, you must set <tt>Os</tt> to
--   <tt>Custom</tt>.
[$sel:amiId:CreateInstance'] :: CreateInstance -> Maybe Text

-- | The instance root device type. For more information, see <a>Storage
--   for the Root Device</a>.
[$sel:rootDeviceType:CreateInstance'] :: CreateInstance -> Maybe RootDeviceType

-- | An array of <tt>BlockDeviceMapping</tt> objects that specify the
--   instance's block devices. For more information, see <a>Block Device
--   Mapping</a>. Note that block device mappings are not supported for
--   custom AMIs.
[$sel:blockDeviceMappings:CreateInstance'] :: CreateInstance -> Maybe [BlockDeviceMapping]

-- | The stack ID.
[$sel:stackId:CreateInstance'] :: CreateInstance -> Text

-- | An array that contains the instance's layer IDs.
[$sel:layerIds:CreateInstance'] :: CreateInstance -> [Text]

-- | The instance type, such as <tt>t2.micro</tt>. For a list of supported
--   instance types, open the stack in the console, choose
--   <b>Instances</b>, and choose <b>+ Instance</b>. The <b>Size</b> list
--   contains the currently supported types. For more information, see
--   <a>Instance Families and Types</a>. The parameter values that you use
--   to specify the various types are in the <b>API Name</b> column of the
--   <b>Available Instance Types</b> table.
[$sel:instanceType:CreateInstance'] :: CreateInstance -> Text

-- | Create a value of <a>CreateInstance</a> with all optional fields
--   omitted.
--   
--   Use <a>generic-lens</a> or <a>optics</a> to modify other optional
--   fields.
--   
--   The following record fields are available, with the corresponding
--   lenses provided for backwards compatibility:
--   
--   <a>$sel:installUpdatesOnBoot:CreateInstance'</a>,
--   <a>createInstance_installUpdatesOnBoot</a> - Whether to install
--   operating system and package updates when the instance boots. The
--   default value is <tt>true</tt>. To control when updates are installed,
--   set this value to <tt>false</tt>. You must then update your instances
--   manually by using CreateDeployment to run the
--   <tt>update_dependencies</tt> stack command or by manually running
--   <tt>yum</tt> (Amazon Linux) or <tt>apt-get</tt> (Ubuntu) on the
--   instances.
--   
--   We strongly recommend using the default value of <tt>true</tt> to
--   ensure that your instances have the latest security updates.
--   
--   <a>$sel:virtualizationType:CreateInstance'</a>,
--   <a>createInstance_virtualizationType</a> - The instance's
--   virtualization type, <tt>paravirtual</tt> or <tt>hvm</tt>.
--   
--   <a>$sel:hostname:CreateInstance'</a>, <a>createInstance_hostname</a> -
--   The instance host name.
--   
--   <a>$sel:sshKeyName:CreateInstance'</a>,
--   <a>createInstance_sshKeyName</a> - The instance's Amazon EC2 key-pair
--   name.
--   
--   <a>$sel:agentVersion:CreateInstance'</a>,
--   <a>createInstance_agentVersion</a> - The default AWS OpsWorks Stacks
--   agent version. You have the following options:
--   
--   <ul>
--   <li><tt>INHERIT</tt> - Use the stack's default agent version
--   setting.</li>
--   <li><i>version_number</i> - Use the specified agent version. This
--   value overrides the stack's default setting. To update the agent
--   version, edit the instance configuration and specify a new version.
--   AWS OpsWorks Stacks then automatically installs that version on the
--   instance.</li>
--   </ul>
--   
--   The default setting is <tt>INHERIT</tt>. To specify an agent version,
--   you must use the complete version number, not the abbreviated number
--   shown on the console. For a list of available agent version numbers,
--   call DescribeAgentVersions. AgentVersion cannot be set to Chef 12.2.
--   
--   <a>$sel:subnetId:CreateInstance'</a>, <a>createInstance_subnetId</a> -
--   The ID of the instance's subnet. If the stack is running in a VPC, you
--   can use this parameter to override the stack's default subnet ID value
--   and direct AWS OpsWorks Stacks to launch the instance in a different
--   subnet.
--   
--   <a>$sel:ebsOptimized:CreateInstance'</a>,
--   <a>createInstance_ebsOptimized</a> - Whether to create an Amazon
--   EBS-optimized instance.
--   
--   <a>$sel:os:CreateInstance'</a>, <a>createInstance_os</a> - The
--   instance's operating system, which must be set to one of the
--   following.
--   
--   <ul>
--   <li>A supported Linux operating system: An Amazon Linux version, such
--   as <tt>Amazon Linux 2018.03</tt>, <tt>Amazon Linux 2017.09</tt>,
--   <tt>Amazon Linux 2017.03</tt>, <tt>Amazon Linux 2016.09</tt>,
--   <tt>Amazon Linux 2016.03</tt>, <tt>Amazon Linux 2015.09</tt>, or
--   <tt>Amazon Linux 2015.03</tt>.</li>
--   <li>A supported Ubuntu operating system, such as <tt>Ubuntu 16.04
--   LTS</tt>, <tt>Ubuntu 14.04 LTS</tt>, or <tt>Ubuntu 12.04
--   LTS</tt>.</li>
--   <li><pre>CentOS Linux 7</pre></li>
--   <li><pre>Red Hat Enterprise Linux 7</pre></li>
--   <li>A supported Windows operating system, such as <tt>Microsoft
--   Windows Server 2012 R2 Base</tt>, <tt>Microsoft Windows Server 2012 R2
--   with SQL Server Express</tt>, <tt>Microsoft Windows Server 2012 R2
--   with SQL Server Standard</tt>, or <tt>Microsoft Windows Server 2012 R2
--   with SQL Server Web</tt>.</li>
--   <li>A custom AMI: <tt>Custom</tt>.</li>
--   </ul>
--   
--   For more information about the supported operating systems, see <a>AWS
--   OpsWorks Stacks Operating Systems</a>.
--   
--   The default option is the current Amazon Linux version. If you set
--   this parameter to <tt>Custom</tt>, you must use the CreateInstance
--   action's AmiId parameter to specify the custom AMI that you want to
--   use. Block device mappings are not supported if the value is
--   <tt>Custom</tt>. For more information about supported operating
--   systems, see <a>Operating Systems</a>For more information about how to
--   use custom AMIs with AWS OpsWorks Stacks, see <a>Using Custom
--   AMIs</a>.
--   
--   <a>$sel:availabilityZone:CreateInstance'</a>,
--   <a>createInstance_availabilityZone</a> - The instance Availability
--   Zone. For more information, see <a>Regions and Endpoints</a>.
--   
--   <a>$sel:tenancy:CreateInstance'</a>, <a>createInstance_tenancy</a> -
--   The instance's tenancy option. The default option is no tenancy, or if
--   the instance is running in a VPC, inherit tenancy settings from the
--   VPC. The following are valid values for this parameter:
--   <tt>dedicated</tt>, <tt>default</tt>, or <tt>host</tt>. Because there
--   are costs associated with changes in tenancy options, we recommend
--   that you research tenancy options before choosing them for your
--   instances. For more information about dedicated hosts, see
--   <a>Dedicated Hosts Overview</a> and <a>Amazon EC2 Dedicated Hosts</a>.
--   For more information about dedicated instances, see <a>Dedicated
--   Instances</a> and <a>Amazon EC2 Dedicated Instances</a>.
--   
--   <a>$sel:autoScalingType:CreateInstance'</a>,
--   <a>createInstance_autoScalingType</a> - For load-based or time-based
--   instances, the type. Windows stacks can use only time-based instances.
--   
--   <a>$sel:architecture:CreateInstance'</a>,
--   <a>createInstance_architecture</a> - The instance architecture. The
--   default option is <tt>x86_64</tt>. Instance types do not necessarily
--   support both architectures. For a list of the architectures that are
--   supported by the different instance types, see <a>Instance Families
--   and Types</a>.
--   
--   <a>$sel:amiId:CreateInstance'</a>, <a>createInstance_amiId</a> - A
--   custom AMI ID to be used to create the instance. The AMI should be
--   based on one of the supported operating systems. For more information,
--   see <a>Using Custom AMIs</a>.
--   
--   If you specify a custom AMI, you must set <tt>Os</tt> to
--   <tt>Custom</tt>.
--   
--   <a>$sel:rootDeviceType:CreateInstance'</a>,
--   <a>createInstance_rootDeviceType</a> - The instance root device type.
--   For more information, see <a>Storage for the Root Device</a>.
--   
--   <a>$sel:blockDeviceMappings:CreateInstance'</a>,
--   <a>createInstance_blockDeviceMappings</a> - An array of
--   <tt>BlockDeviceMapping</tt> objects that specify the instance's block
--   devices. For more information, see <a>Block Device Mapping</a>. Note
--   that block device mappings are not supported for custom AMIs.
--   
--   <a>$sel:stackId:CreateInstance'</a>, <a>createInstance_stackId</a> -
--   The stack ID.
--   
--   <a>$sel:layerIds:CreateInstance'</a>, <a>createInstance_layerIds</a> -
--   An array that contains the instance's layer IDs.
--   
--   <a>$sel:instanceType:CreateInstance'</a>,
--   <a>createInstance_instanceType</a> - The instance type, such as
--   <tt>t2.micro</tt>. For a list of supported instance types, open the
--   stack in the console, choose <b>Instances</b>, and choose <b>+
--   Instance</b>. The <b>Size</b> list contains the currently supported
--   types. For more information, see <a>Instance Families and Types</a>.
--   The parameter values that you use to specify the various types are in
--   the <b>API Name</b> column of the <b>Available Instance Types</b>
--   table.
newCreateInstance :: Text -> Text -> CreateInstance

-- | Whether to install operating system and package updates when the
--   instance boots. The default value is <tt>true</tt>. To control when
--   updates are installed, set this value to <tt>false</tt>. You must then
--   update your instances manually by using CreateDeployment to run the
--   <tt>update_dependencies</tt> stack command or by manually running
--   <tt>yum</tt> (Amazon Linux) or <tt>apt-get</tt> (Ubuntu) on the
--   instances.
--   
--   We strongly recommend using the default value of <tt>true</tt> to
--   ensure that your instances have the latest security updates.
createInstance_installUpdatesOnBoot :: Lens' CreateInstance (Maybe Bool)

-- | The instance's virtualization type, <tt>paravirtual</tt> or
--   <tt>hvm</tt>.
createInstance_virtualizationType :: Lens' CreateInstance (Maybe Text)

-- | The instance host name.
createInstance_hostname :: Lens' CreateInstance (Maybe Text)

-- | The instance's Amazon EC2 key-pair name.
createInstance_sshKeyName :: Lens' CreateInstance (Maybe Text)

-- | The default AWS OpsWorks Stacks agent version. You have the following
--   options:
--   
--   <ul>
--   <li><tt>INHERIT</tt> - Use the stack's default agent version
--   setting.</li>
--   <li><i>version_number</i> - Use the specified agent version. This
--   value overrides the stack's default setting. To update the agent
--   version, edit the instance configuration and specify a new version.
--   AWS OpsWorks Stacks then automatically installs that version on the
--   instance.</li>
--   </ul>
--   
--   The default setting is <tt>INHERIT</tt>. To specify an agent version,
--   you must use the complete version number, not the abbreviated number
--   shown on the console. For a list of available agent version numbers,
--   call DescribeAgentVersions. AgentVersion cannot be set to Chef 12.2.
createInstance_agentVersion :: Lens' CreateInstance (Maybe Text)

-- | The ID of the instance's subnet. If the stack is running in a VPC, you
--   can use this parameter to override the stack's default subnet ID value
--   and direct AWS OpsWorks Stacks to launch the instance in a different
--   subnet.
createInstance_subnetId :: Lens' CreateInstance (Maybe Text)

-- | Whether to create an Amazon EBS-optimized instance.
createInstance_ebsOptimized :: Lens' CreateInstance (Maybe Bool)

-- | The instance's operating system, which must be set to one of the
--   following.
--   
--   <ul>
--   <li>A supported Linux operating system: An Amazon Linux version, such
--   as <tt>Amazon Linux 2018.03</tt>, <tt>Amazon Linux 2017.09</tt>,
--   <tt>Amazon Linux 2017.03</tt>, <tt>Amazon Linux 2016.09</tt>,
--   <tt>Amazon Linux 2016.03</tt>, <tt>Amazon Linux 2015.09</tt>, or
--   <tt>Amazon Linux 2015.03</tt>.</li>
--   <li>A supported Ubuntu operating system, such as <tt>Ubuntu 16.04
--   LTS</tt>, <tt>Ubuntu 14.04 LTS</tt>, or <tt>Ubuntu 12.04
--   LTS</tt>.</li>
--   <li><pre>CentOS Linux 7</pre></li>
--   <li><pre>Red Hat Enterprise Linux 7</pre></li>
--   <li>A supported Windows operating system, such as <tt>Microsoft
--   Windows Server 2012 R2 Base</tt>, <tt>Microsoft Windows Server 2012 R2
--   with SQL Server Express</tt>, <tt>Microsoft Windows Server 2012 R2
--   with SQL Server Standard</tt>, or <tt>Microsoft Windows Server 2012 R2
--   with SQL Server Web</tt>.</li>
--   <li>A custom AMI: <tt>Custom</tt>.</li>
--   </ul>
--   
--   For more information about the supported operating systems, see <a>AWS
--   OpsWorks Stacks Operating Systems</a>.
--   
--   The default option is the current Amazon Linux version. If you set
--   this parameter to <tt>Custom</tt>, you must use the CreateInstance
--   action's AmiId parameter to specify the custom AMI that you want to
--   use. Block device mappings are not supported if the value is
--   <tt>Custom</tt>. For more information about supported operating
--   systems, see <a>Operating Systems</a>For more information about how to
--   use custom AMIs with AWS OpsWorks Stacks, see <a>Using Custom
--   AMIs</a>.
createInstance_os :: Lens' CreateInstance (Maybe Text)

-- | The instance Availability Zone. For more information, see <a>Regions
--   and Endpoints</a>.
createInstance_availabilityZone :: Lens' CreateInstance (Maybe Text)

-- | The instance's tenancy option. The default option is no tenancy, or if
--   the instance is running in a VPC, inherit tenancy settings from the
--   VPC. The following are valid values for this parameter:
--   <tt>dedicated</tt>, <tt>default</tt>, or <tt>host</tt>. Because there
--   are costs associated with changes in tenancy options, we recommend
--   that you research tenancy options before choosing them for your
--   instances. For more information about dedicated hosts, see
--   <a>Dedicated Hosts Overview</a> and <a>Amazon EC2 Dedicated Hosts</a>.
--   For more information about dedicated instances, see <a>Dedicated
--   Instances</a> and <a>Amazon EC2 Dedicated Instances</a>.
createInstance_tenancy :: Lens' CreateInstance (Maybe Text)

-- | For load-based or time-based instances, the type. Windows stacks can
--   use only time-based instances.
createInstance_autoScalingType :: Lens' CreateInstance (Maybe AutoScalingType)

-- | The instance architecture. The default option is <tt>x86_64</tt>.
--   Instance types do not necessarily support both architectures. For a
--   list of the architectures that are supported by the different instance
--   types, see <a>Instance Families and Types</a>.
createInstance_architecture :: Lens' CreateInstance (Maybe Architecture)

-- | A custom AMI ID to be used to create the instance. The AMI should be
--   based on one of the supported operating systems. For more information,
--   see <a>Using Custom AMIs</a>.
--   
--   If you specify a custom AMI, you must set <tt>Os</tt> to
--   <tt>Custom</tt>.
createInstance_amiId :: Lens' CreateInstance (Maybe Text)

-- | The instance root device type. For more information, see <a>Storage
--   for the Root Device</a>.
createInstance_rootDeviceType :: Lens' CreateInstance (Maybe RootDeviceType)

-- | An array of <tt>BlockDeviceMapping</tt> objects that specify the
--   instance's block devices. For more information, see <a>Block Device
--   Mapping</a>. Note that block device mappings are not supported for
--   custom AMIs.
createInstance_blockDeviceMappings :: Lens' CreateInstance (Maybe [BlockDeviceMapping])

-- | The stack ID.
createInstance_stackId :: Lens' CreateInstance Text

-- | An array that contains the instance's layer IDs.
createInstance_layerIds :: Lens' CreateInstance [Text]

-- | The instance type, such as <tt>t2.micro</tt>. For a list of supported
--   instance types, open the stack in the console, choose
--   <b>Instances</b>, and choose <b>+ Instance</b>. The <b>Size</b> list
--   contains the currently supported types. For more information, see
--   <a>Instance Families and Types</a>. The parameter values that you use
--   to specify the various types are in the <b>API Name</b> column of the
--   <b>Available Instance Types</b> table.
createInstance_instanceType :: Lens' CreateInstance Text

data CreateInstanceResponse
CreateInstanceResponse' :: Maybe Text -> Int -> CreateInstanceResponse

-- | The instance ID.
[$sel:instanceId:CreateInstanceResponse'] :: CreateInstanceResponse -> Maybe Text

-- | The response's http status code.
[$sel:httpStatus:CreateInstanceResponse'] :: CreateInstanceResponse -> Int

--   
--   <a>$sel:httpStatus:CreateInstanceResponse'</a>,
--   <a>createInstanceResponse_httpStatus</a> - The response's http status
--   code.
newCreateInstanceResponse :: Int -> CreateInstanceResponse

createInstanceResponse_instanceId :: Lens' CreateInstanceResponse (Maybe Text)

-- | The response's http status code.
createInstanceResponse_httpStatus :: Lens' CreateInstanceResponse Int

-- | Runs deployment or stack commands. For more information, see
--   <a>Deploying Apps</a> and <a>Run Stack Commands</a>.
--   
--   <b>Required Permissions</b>: To use this action, an IAM user must have
--   a Deploy or Manage permissions level for the stack, or an attached
--   policy that explicitly grants permissions. For more information on
--   user permissions, see <a>Managing User Permissions</a>.
module Network.AWS.OpsWorks.CreateDeployment

-- | <i>See:</i> <a>newCreateDeployment</a> smart constructor.
data CreateDeployment
CreateDeployment' :: Maybe Text -> Maybe Text -> Maybe [Text] -> Maybe [Text] -> Maybe Text -> Text -> DeploymentCommand -> CreateDeployment

-- | A string that contains user-defined, custom JSON. You can use this
--   parameter to override some corresponding default stack configuration
--   JSON values. The string should be in the following format:
--   
--   <pre>
--   "{\"key1\": \"value1\", \"key2\": \"value2\",...}"
--   </pre>
--   
--   For more information about custom JSON, see <a>Use Custom JSON to
--   Modify the Stack Configuration Attributes</a> and <a>Overriding
--   Attributes With Custom JSON</a>.
[$sel:customJson:CreateDeployment'] :: CreateDeployment -> Maybe Text

-- | The app ID. This parameter is required for app deployments, but not
--   for other deployment commands.
[$sel:appId:CreateDeployment'] :: CreateDeployment -> Maybe Text

-- | The instance IDs for the deployment targets.
[$sel:instanceIds:CreateDeployment'] :: CreateDeployment -> Maybe [Text]

-- | The layer IDs for the deployment targets.
[$sel:layerIds:CreateDeployment'] :: CreateDeployment -> Maybe [Text]

-- | A user-defined comment.
[$sel:comment:CreateDeployment'] :: CreateDeployment -> Maybe Text

-- | The stack ID.
[$sel:stackId:CreateDeployment'] :: CreateDeployment -> Text

-- | A <tt>DeploymentCommand</tt> object that specifies the deployment
--   command and any associated arguments.
[$sel:command:CreateDeployment'] :: CreateDeployment -> DeploymentCommand

-- | Create a value of <a>CreateDeployment</a> with all optional fields
--   omitted.
--

--   fields.

--   lenses provided for backwards compatibility:

--   user-defined, custom JSON. You can use this parameter to override some
--   corresponding default stack configuration JSON values. The string
--   should be in the following format:
--   
--   <pre>
--   "{\"key1\": \"value1\", \"key2\": \"value2\",...}"
--   </pre>
--   
--   For more information about custom JSON, see <a>Use Custom JSON to
--   Modify the Stack Configuration Attributes</a> and <a>Overriding
--   Attributes With Custom JSON</a>.
--   
--   <a>$sel:appId:CreateDeployment'</a>, <a>createDeployment_appId</a> -
--   The app ID. This parameter is required for app deployments, but not
--   for other deployment commands.
--   
--   <a>$sel:instanceIds:CreateDeployment'</a>,

--   deployment targets.
--

--   targets.
--   
--   <a>$sel:comment:CreateDeployment'</a>, <a>createDeployment_comment</a>
--   - A user-defined comment.
--   
--   <a>$sel:stackId:CreateDeployment'</a>, <a>createDeployment_stackId</a>
--   - The stack ID.
--   
--   <a>$sel:command:CreateDeployment'</a>, <a>createDeployment_command</a>
--   - A <tt>DeploymentCommand</tt> object that specifies the deployment
--   command and any associated arguments.
newCreateDeployment :: Text -> DeploymentCommand -> CreateDeployment

-- | A string that contains user-defined, custom JSON. You can use this
--   parameter to override some corresponding default stack configuration
--   JSON values. The string should be in the following format:
--   
--   <pre>
--   "{\"key1\": \"value1\", \"key2\": \"value2\",...}"

--   Modify the Stack Configuration Attributes</a> and <a>Overriding
--   Attributes With Custom JSON</a>.

--   for other deployment commands.
createDeployment_appId :: Lens' CreateDeployment (Maybe Text)

createDeployment_instanceIds :: Lens' CreateDeployment (Maybe [Text])

createDeployment_layerIds :: Lens' CreateDeployment (Maybe [Text])

--   command and any associated arguments.

-- | Creates an app for a specified stack. For more information, see
--   <a>Creating Apps</a>.
--   
--   <b>Required Permissions</b>: To use this action, an IAM user must have
--   a Manage permissions level for the stack, or an attached policy that
--   explicitly grants permissions. For more information on user
--   permissions, see <a>Managing User Permissions</a>.
module Network.AWS.OpsWorks.CreateApp

-- | <i>See:</i> <a>newCreateApp</a> smart constructor.
data CreateApp
CreateApp' :: Maybe SslConfiguration -> Maybe [EnvironmentVariable] -> Maybe Bool -> Maybe Text -> Maybe [DataSource] -> Maybe Source -> Maybe (HashMap AppAttributesKeys Text) -> Maybe [Text] -> Maybe Text -> Text -> Text -> AppType -> CreateApp

-- | An <tt>SslConfiguration</tt> object with the SSL configuration.
[$sel:sslConfiguration:CreateApp'] :: CreateApp -> Maybe SslConfiguration

-- | An array of <tt>EnvironmentVariable</tt> objects that specify
--   environment variables to be associated with the app. After you deploy
--   the app, these variables are defined on the associated app server
--   instance. For more information, see <a>Environment Variables</a>.
--   
--   There is no specific limit on the number of environment variables.
--   However, the size of the associated data structure - which includes
--   the variables' names, values, and protected flag values - cannot
--   exceed 20 KB. This limit should accommodate most if not all use cases.
--   Exceeding it will cause an exception with the message, "Environment:
--   is too large (maximum is 20KB)."
--   
--   If you have specified one or more environment variables, you cannot
--   modify the stack's Chef version.
[$sel:environment:CreateApp'] :: CreateApp -> Maybe [EnvironmentVariable]

-- | Whether to enable SSL for the app.
[$sel:enableSsl:CreateApp'] :: CreateApp -> Maybe Bool

-- | The app's short name.
[$sel:shortname:CreateApp'] :: CreateApp -> Maybe Text

-- | The app's data source.
[$sel:dataSources:CreateApp'] :: CreateApp -> Maybe [DataSource]

-- | A <tt>Source</tt> object that specifies the app repository.
[$sel:appSource:CreateApp'] :: CreateApp -> Maybe Source

-- | One or more user-defined key/value pairs to be added to the stack
--   attributes.
[$sel:attributes:CreateApp'] :: CreateApp -> Maybe (HashMap AppAttributesKeys Text)

-- | The app virtual host settings, with multiple domains separated by
--   commas. For example: <tt>'www.example.com, example.com'</tt>
[$sel:domains:CreateApp'] :: CreateApp -> Maybe [Text]

-- | A description of the app.
[$sel:description:CreateApp'] :: CreateApp -> Maybe Text

-- | The stack ID.
[$sel:stackId:CreateApp'] :: CreateApp -> Text

-- | The app name.
[$sel:name:CreateApp'] :: CreateApp -> Text

-- | The app type. Each supported type is associated with a particular
--   layer. For example, PHP applications are associated with a PHP layer.
--   AWS OpsWorks Stacks deploys an application to those instances that are
--   members of the corresponding layer. If your app isn't one of the
--   standard types, or you prefer to implement your own Deploy recipes,
--   specify <tt>other</tt>.
[$sel:type':CreateApp'] :: CreateApp -> AppType

-- | Create a value of <a>CreateApp</a> with all optional fields omitted.
--   
--   Use <a>generic-lens</a> or <a>optics</a> to modify other optional
--   fields.
--   
--   The following record fields are available, with the corresponding
--   lenses provided for backwards compatibility:
--   
--   <a>$sel:sslConfiguration:CreateApp'</a>,
--   <a>createApp_sslConfiguration</a> - An <tt>SslConfiguration</tt>
--   object with the SSL configuration.
--   
--   <a>$sel:environment:CreateApp'</a>, <a>createApp_environment</a> - An
--   array of <tt>EnvironmentVariable</tt> objects that specify environment
--   variables to be associated with the app. After you deploy the app,
--   these variables are defined on the associated app server instance. For
--   more information, see <a>Environment Variables</a>.
--   
--   There is no specific limit on the number of environment variables.
--   However, the size of the associated data structure - which includes
--   the variables' names, values, and protected flag values - cannot
--   exceed 20 KB. This limit should accommodate most if not all use cases.
--   Exceeding it will cause an exception with the message, "Environment:
--   is too large (maximum is 20KB)."
--   
--   If you have specified one or more environment variables, you cannot
--   modify the stack's Chef version.
--   
--   <a>$sel:enableSsl:CreateApp'</a>, <a>createApp_enableSsl</a> - Whether
--   to enable SSL for the app.
--   
--   <a>$sel:shortname:CreateApp'</a>, <a>createApp_shortname</a> - The
--   app's short name.
--   
--   <a>$sel:dataSources:CreateApp'</a>, <a>createApp_dataSources</a> - The
--   app's data source.
--   
--   <a>$sel:appSource:CreateApp'</a>, <a>createApp_appSource</a> - A
--   <tt>Source</tt> object that specifies the app repository.
--   
--   <a>$sel:attributes:CreateApp'</a>, <a>createApp_attributes</a> - One
--   or more user-defined key/value pairs to be added to the stack
--   attributes.
--   
--   <a>$sel:domains:CreateApp'</a>, <a>createApp_domains</a> - The app
--   virtual host settings, with multiple domains separated by commas. For
--   example: <tt>'www.example.com, example.com'</tt>
--   
--   <a>$sel:description:CreateApp'</a>, <a>createApp_description</a> - A
--   description of the app.
--   
--   <a>$sel:stackId:CreateApp'</a>, <a>createApp_stackId</a> - The stack
--   ID.
--   
--   <a>$sel:name:CreateApp'</a>, <a>createApp_name</a> - The app name.
--   
--   <a>$sel:type':CreateApp'</a>, <a>createApp_type</a> - The app type.
--   Each supported type is associated with a particular layer. For
--   example, PHP applications are associated with a PHP layer. AWS
--   OpsWorks Stacks deploys an application to those instances that are
--   members of the corresponding layer. If your app isn't one of the
--   standard types, or you prefer to implement your own Deploy recipes,
--   specify <tt>other</tt>.
newCreateApp :: Text -> Text -> AppType -> CreateApp

-- | An <tt>SslConfiguration</tt> object with the SSL configuration.
createApp_sslConfiguration :: Lens' CreateApp (Maybe SslConfiguration)

-- | An array of <tt>EnvironmentVariable</tt> objects that specify
--   environment variables to be associated with the app. After you deploy
--   the app, these variables are defined on the associated app server
--   instance. For more information, see <a>Environment Variables</a>.
--   
--   There is no specific limit on the number of environment variables.
--   However, the size of the associated data structure - which includes
--   the variables' names, values, and protected flag values - cannot
--   exceed 20 KB. This limit should accommodate most if not all use cases.
--   Exceeding it will cause an exception with the message, "Environment:
--   is too large (maximum is 20KB)."
--   
--   If you have specified one or more environment variables, you cannot
--   modify the stack's Chef version.
createApp_environment :: Lens' CreateApp (Maybe [EnvironmentVariable])

-- | Whether to enable SSL for the app.
createApp_enableSsl :: Lens' CreateApp (Maybe Bool)

-- | The app's short name.
createApp_shortname :: Lens' CreateApp (Maybe Text)

-- | The app's data source.
createApp_dataSources :: Lens' CreateApp (Maybe [DataSource])

-- | A <tt>Source</tt> object that specifies the app repository.
createApp_appSource :: Lens' CreateApp (Maybe Source)

-- | One or more user-defined key/value pairs to be added to the stack
--   attributes.
createApp_attributes :: Lens' CreateApp (Maybe (HashMap AppAttributesKeys Text))

-- | The app virtual host settings, with multiple domains separated by
--   commas. For example: <tt>'www.example.com, example.com'</tt>
createApp_domains :: Lens' CreateApp (Maybe [Text])

-- | A description of the app.
createApp_description :: Lens' CreateApp (Maybe Text)

-- | The stack ID.
createApp_stackId :: Lens' CreateApp Text

-- | The app name.
createApp_name :: Lens' CreateApp Text

-- | The app type. Each supported type is associated with a particular
--   layer. For example, PHP applications are associated with a PHP layer.
--   AWS OpsWorks Stacks deploys an application to those instances that are
--   members of the corresponding layer. If your app isn't one of the
--   standard types, or you prefer to implement your own Deploy recipes,
--   specify <tt>other</tt>.
createApp_type :: Lens' CreateApp AppType

-- | Contains the response to a <tt>CreateApp</tt> request.
--   
--   <i>See:</i> <a>newCreateAppResponse</a> smart constructor.
data CreateAppResponse
CreateAppResponse' :: Maybe Text -> Int -> CreateAppResponse

-- | The app ID.
[$sel:appId:CreateAppResponse'] :: CreateAppResponse -> Maybe Text

-- | The response's http status code.
[$sel:httpStatus:CreateAppResponse'] :: CreateAppResponse -> Int

-- | Create a value of <a>CreateAppResponse</a> with all optional fields
--   omitted.
--   
--   Use <a>generic-lens</a> or <a>optics</a> to modify other optional
--   fields.
--   
--   The following record fields are available, with the corresponding
--   lenses provided for backwards compatibility:
--   
--   <a>$sel:appId:CreateAppResponse'</a>, <a>createAppResponse_appId</a> -
--   The app ID.
--   
--   <a>$sel:httpStatus:CreateAppResponse'</a>,
--   <a>createAppResponse_httpStatus</a> - The response's http status code.
newCreateAppResponse :: Int -> CreateAppResponse

-- | The app ID.
createAppResponse_appId :: Lens' CreateAppResponse (Maybe Text)

-- | The response's http status code.
createAppResponse_httpStatus :: Lens' CreateAppResponse Int
instance GHC.Generics.Generic Network.AWS.OpsWorks.CreateApp.CreateApp
instance GHC.Show.Show Network.AWS.OpsWorks.CreateApp.CreateApp
instance GHC.Read.Read Network.AWS.OpsWorks.CreateApp.CreateApp
instance GHC.Classes.Eq Network.AWS.OpsWorks.CreateApp.CreateApp
instance GHC.Generics.Generic Network.AWS.OpsWorks.CreateApp.CreateAppResponse
instance GHC.Show.Show Network.AWS.OpsWorks.CreateApp.CreateAppResponse
instance GHC.Read.Read Network.AWS.OpsWorks.CreateApp.CreateAppResponse
instance GHC.Classes.Eq Network.AWS.OpsWorks.CreateApp.CreateAppResponse
instance Network.AWS.Types.AWSRequest Network.AWS.OpsWorks.CreateApp.CreateApp
instance Control.DeepSeq.NFData Network.AWS.OpsWorks.CreateApp.CreateAppResponse

instance Control.DeepSeq.NFData Network.AWS.OpsWorks.CreateApp.CreateApp
instance Network.AWS.Data.Headers.ToHeaders Network.AWS.OpsWorks.CreateApp.CreateApp
instance Data.Aeson.Types.ToJSON.ToJSON Network.AWS.OpsWorks.CreateApp.CreateApp
instance Network.AWS.Data.Path.ToPath Network.AWS.OpsWorks.CreateApp.CreateApp
instance Network.AWS.Data.Query.ToQuery Network.AWS.OpsWorks.CreateApp.CreateApp


-- | Creates a clone of a specified stack. For more information, see
--   <a>Clone a Stack</a>. By default, all parameters are set to the values
--   used by the parent stack.
--   
--   <b>Required Permissions</b>: To use this action, an IAM user must have
--   an attached policy that explicitly grants permissions. For more
--   information about user permissions, see <a>Managing User
--   Permissions</a>.
module Network.AWS.OpsWorks.CloneStack

-- | <i>See:</i> <a>newCloneStack</a> smart constructor.
data CloneStack
CloneStack' :: Maybe Text -> Maybe [Text] -> Maybe RootDeviceType -> Maybe Text -> Maybe ChefConfiguration -> Maybe Text -> Maybe Text -> Maybe Text -> Maybe Bool -> Maybe Source -> Maybe Text -> Maybe (HashMap StackAttributesKeys (Maybe Text)) -> Maybe Text -> Maybe Text -> Maybe Bool -> Maybe Bool -> Maybe Text -> Maybe Text -> Maybe StackConfigurationManager -> Maybe Text -> Text -> Text -> CloneStack

-- | The Amazon Resource Name (ARN) of an IAM profile that is the default
--   profile for all of the stack's EC2 instances. For more information
--   about IAM ARNs, see <a>Using Identifiers</a>.
[$sel:defaultInstanceProfileArn:CloneStack'] :: CloneStack -> Maybe Text

-- | A list of source stack app IDs to be included in the cloned stack.
[$sel:cloneAppIds:CloneStack'] :: CloneStack -> Maybe [Text]

-- | The default root device type. This value is used by default for all
--   instances in the cloned stack, but you can override it when you create
--   an instance. For more information, see <a>Storage for the Root
--   Device</a>.
[$sel:defaultRootDeviceType:CloneStack'] :: CloneStack -> Maybe RootDeviceType

-- | The ID of the VPC that the cloned stack is to be launched into. It
--   must be in the specified region. All instances are launched into this
--   VPC, and you cannot change the ID later.
--   
--   <ul>
--   <li>If your account supports EC2 Classic, the default value is no
--   VPC.</li>
--   <li>If your account does not support EC2 Classic, the default value is
--   the default VPC for the specified region.</li>
--   </ul>
--   
--   If the VPC ID corresponds to a default VPC and you have specified
--   either the <tt>DefaultAvailabilityZone</tt> or the
--   <tt>DefaultSubnetId</tt> parameter only, AWS OpsWorks Stacks infers
--   the value of the other parameter. If you specify neither parameter,
--   AWS OpsWorks Stacks sets these parameters to the first valid
--   Availability Zone for the specified region and the corresponding
--   default VPC subnet ID, respectively.
--   
--   If you specify a nondefault VPC ID, note the following:
--   
--   <ul>
--   <li>It must belong to a VPC in your account that is in the specified
--   region.</li>
--   <li>You must specify a value for <tt>DefaultSubnetId</tt>.</li>
--   </ul>
--   
--   For more information about how to use AWS OpsWorks Stacks with a VPC,
--   see <a>Running a Stack in a VPC</a>. For more information about
--   default VPC and EC2 Classic, see <a>Supported Platforms</a>.
[$sel:vpcId:CloneStack'] :: CloneStack -> Maybe Text

-- | A <tt>ChefConfiguration</tt> object that specifies whether to enable
--   Berkshelf and the Berkshelf version on Chef 11.10 stacks. For more
--   information, see <a>Create a New Stack</a>.
[$sel:chefConfiguration:CloneStack'] :: CloneStack -> Maybe ChefConfiguration

-- | The default AWS OpsWorks Stacks agent version. You have the following
--   options:
--   
--   <ul>
--   <li>Auto-update - Set this parameter to <tt>LATEST</tt>. AWS OpsWorks
--   Stacks automatically installs new agent versions on the stack's
--   instances as soon as they are available.</li>
--   <li>Fixed version - Set this parameter to your preferred agent
--   version. To update the agent version, you must edit the stack
--   configuration and specify a new version. AWS OpsWorks Stacks then
--   automatically installs that version on the stack's instances.</li>
--   </ul>
--   
--   The default setting is <tt>LATEST</tt>. To specify an agent version,
--   you must use the complete version number, not the abbreviated number
--   shown on the console. For a list of available agent version numbers,
--   call DescribeAgentVersions. AgentVersion cannot be set to Chef 12.2.
--   
--   You can also specify an agent version when you create or update an
--   instance, which overrides the stack's default setting.
[$sel:agentVersion:CloneStack'] :: CloneStack -> Maybe Text

-- | A default Amazon EC2 key pair name. The default value is none. If you
--   specify a key pair name, AWS OpsWorks installs the public key on the
--   instance and you can use the private key with an SSH client to log in
--   to the instance. For more information, see <a>Using SSH to Communicate
--   with an Instance</a> and <a>Managing SSH Access</a>. You can override
--   this setting by specifying a different key pair, or no key pair, when
--   you <a>create an instance</a>.
[$sel:defaultSshKeyName:CloneStack'] :: CloneStack -> Maybe Text

-- | A string that contains user-defined, custom JSON. It is used to
--   override the corresponding default stack configuration JSON values.
--   The string should be in the following format:
--   
--   <pre>
--   "{\"key1\": \"value1\", \"key2\": \"value2\",...}"
--   </pre>
--   
--   For more information about custom JSON, see <a>Use Custom JSON to
--   Modify the Stack Configuration Attributes</a>
[$sel:customJson:CloneStack'] :: CloneStack -> Maybe Text

-- | Whether to clone the source stack's permissions.
[$sel:clonePermissions:CloneStack'] :: CloneStack -> Maybe Bool

-- | Contains the information required to retrieve an app or cookbook from
--   a repository. For more information, see <a>Adding Apps</a> or
--   <a>Cookbooks and Recipes</a>.
[$sel:customCookbooksSource:CloneStack'] :: CloneStack -> Maybe Source

-- | The cloned stack's default Availability Zone, which must be in the
--   specified region. For more information, see <a>Regions and
--   Endpoints</a>. If you also specify a value for
--   <tt>DefaultSubnetId</tt>, the subnet must be in the same zone. For
--   more information, see the <tt>VpcId</tt> parameter description.
[$sel:defaultAvailabilityZone:CloneStack'] :: CloneStack -> Maybe Text

-- | A list of stack attributes and values as key/value pairs to be added
--   to the cloned stack.
[$sel:attributes:CloneStack'] :: CloneStack -> Maybe (HashMap StackAttributesKeys (Maybe Text))

-- | The cloned stack name.
[$sel:name:CloneStack'] :: CloneStack -> Maybe Text

-- | The stack's operating system, which must be set to one of the
--   following.
--   
--   <ul>
--   <li>A supported Linux operating system: An Amazon Linux version, such
--   as <tt>Amazon Linux 2018.03</tt>, <tt>Amazon Linux 2017.09</tt>,
--   <tt>Amazon Linux 2017.03</tt>, <tt>Amazon Linux 2016.09</tt>,
--   <tt>Amazon Linux 2016.03</tt>, <tt>Amazon Linux 2015.09</tt>, or
--   <tt>Amazon Linux 2015.03</tt>.</li>
--   <li>A supported Ubuntu operating system, such as <tt>Ubuntu 16.04
--   LTS</tt>, <tt>Ubuntu 14.04 LTS</tt>, or <tt>Ubuntu 12.04
--   LTS</tt>.</li>
--   <li><pre>CentOS Linux 7</pre></li>
--   <li><pre>Red Hat Enterprise Linux 7</pre></li>
--   <li><tt>Microsoft Windows Server 2012 R2 Base</tt>, <tt>Microsoft
--   Windows Server 2012 R2 with SQL Server Express</tt>, <tt>Microsoft
--   Windows Server 2012 R2 with SQL Server Standard</tt>, or <tt>Microsoft
--   Windows Server 2012 R2 with SQL Server Web</tt>.</li>
--   <li>A custom AMI: <tt>Custom</tt>. You specify the custom AMI you want
--   to use when you create instances. For more information about how to
--   use custom AMIs with OpsWorks, see <a>Using Custom AMIs</a>.</li>
--   </ul>
--   
--   The default option is the parent stack's operating system. For more
--   information about supported operating systems, see <a>AWS OpsWorks
--   Stacks Operating Systems</a>.
--   
--   You can specify a different Linux operating system for the cloned
--   stack, but you cannot change from Linux to Windows or Windows to
--   Linux.
[$sel:defaultOs:CloneStack'] :: CloneStack -> Maybe Text

-- | Whether to associate the AWS OpsWorks Stacks built-in security groups
--   with the stack's layers.
--   
--   AWS OpsWorks Stacks provides a standard set of built-in security
--   groups, one for each layer, which are associated with layers by
--   default. With <tt>UseOpsworksSecurityGroups</tt> you can instead
--   provide your own custom security groups.
--   <tt>UseOpsworksSecurityGroups</tt> has the following settings:
--   
--   <ul>
--   <li>True - AWS OpsWorks Stacks automatically associates the
--   appropriate built-in security group with each layer (default setting).
--   You can associate additional security groups with a layer after you
--   create it but you cannot delete the built-in security group.</li>
--   <li>False - AWS OpsWorks Stacks does not associate built-in security
--   groups with layers. You must create appropriate Amazon Elastic Compute
--   Cloud (Amazon EC2) security groups and associate a security group with
--   each layer that you create. However, you can still manually associate
--   a built-in security group with a layer on creation; custom security
--   groups are required only for those layers that need custom
--   settings.</li>
--   </ul>
--   
--   For more information, see <a>Create a New Stack</a>.
[$sel:useOpsworksSecurityGroups:CloneStack'] :: CloneStack -> Maybe Bool

-- | Whether to use custom cookbooks.
[$sel:useCustomCookbooks:CloneStack'] :: CloneStack -> Maybe Bool

-- | The stack's default VPC subnet ID. This parameter is required if you
--   specify a value for the <tt>VpcId</tt> parameter. All instances are
--   launched into this subnet unless you specify otherwise when you create
--   the instance. If you also specify a value for
--   <tt>DefaultAvailabilityZone</tt>, the subnet must be in that zone. For
--   information on default values and when this parameter is required, see
--   the <tt>VpcId</tt> parameter description.
[$sel:defaultSubnetId:CloneStack'] :: CloneStack -> Maybe Text

-- | The cloned stack AWS region, such as "ap-northeast-2". For more
--   information about AWS regions, see <a>Regions and Endpoints</a>.
[$sel:region:CloneStack'] :: CloneStack -> Maybe Text

-- | The configuration manager. When you clone a stack we recommend that
--   you use the configuration manager to specify the Chef version: 12,
--   11.10, or 11.4 for Linux stacks, or 12.2 for Windows stacks. The
--   default value for Linux stacks is currently 12.
[$sel:configurationManager:CloneStack'] :: CloneStack -> Maybe StackConfigurationManager

-- | The stack's host name theme, with spaces are replaced by underscores.
--   The theme is used to generate host names for the stack's instances. By
--   default, <tt>HostnameTheme</tt> is set to <tt>Layer_Dependent</tt>,
--   which creates host names by appending integers to the layer's short
--   name. The other themes are:
--   
--   <ul>
--   <li><pre>Baked_Goods</pre></li>
--   <li><pre>Clouds</pre></li>
--   <li><pre>Europe_Cities</pre></li>
--   <li><pre>Fruits</pre></li>
--   <li><pre>Greek_Deities_and_Titans</pre></li>
--   <li><pre>Legendary_creatures_from_Japan</pre></li>
--   <li><pre>Planets_and_Moons</pre></li>
--   <li><pre>Roman_Deities</pre></li>
--   <li><pre>Scottish_Islands</pre></li>
--   <li><pre>US_Cities</pre></li>
--   <li><pre>Wild_Cats</pre></li>
--   </ul>
--   
--   To obtain a generated host name, call <tt>GetHostNameSuggestion</tt>,
--   which returns a host name based on the current theme.
[$sel:hostnameTheme:CloneStack'] :: CloneStack -> Maybe Text

-- | The source stack ID.
[$sel:sourceStackId:CloneStack'] :: CloneStack -> Text

-- | The stack AWS Identity and Access Management (IAM) role, which allows
--   AWS OpsWorks Stacks to work with AWS resources on your behalf. You
--   must set this parameter to the Amazon Resource Name (ARN) for an
--   existing IAM role. If you create a stack by using the AWS OpsWorks
--   Stacks console, it creates the role for you. You can obtain an
--   existing stack's IAM ARN programmatically by calling
--   DescribePermissions. For more information about IAM ARNs, see <a>Using
--   Identifiers</a>.
--   
--   You must set this parameter to a valid service role ARN or the action
--   will fail; there is no default value. You can specify the source
--   stack's service role ARN, if you prefer, but you must do so
--   explicitly.
[$sel:serviceRoleArn:CloneStack'] :: CloneStack -> Text

-- | Create a value of <a>CloneStack</a> with all optional fields omitted.
--   
--   Use <a>generic-lens</a> or <a>optics</a> to modify other optional
--   fields.
--   
--   The following record fields are available, with the corresponding
--   lenses provided for backwards compatibility:
--   
--   <a>$sel:defaultInstanceProfileArn:CloneStack'</a>,
--   <a>cloneStack_defaultInstanceProfileArn</a> - The Amazon Resource Name
--   (ARN) of an IAM profile that is the default profile for all of the
--   stack's EC2 instances. For more information about IAM ARNs, see
--   <a>Using Identifiers</a>.
--   
--   <a>$sel:cloneAppIds:CloneStack'</a>, <a>cloneStack_cloneAppIds</a> - A
--   list of source stack app IDs to be included in the cloned stack.
--   
--   <a>$sel:defaultRootDeviceType:CloneStack'</a>,
--   <a>cloneStack_defaultRootDeviceType</a> - The default root device
--   type. This value is used by default for all instances in the cloned
--   stack, but you can override it when you create an instance. For more
--   information, see <a>Storage for the Root Device</a>.
--   
--   <a>$sel:vpcId:CloneStack'</a>, <a>cloneStack_vpcId</a> - The ID of the
--   VPC that the cloned stack is to be launched into. It must be in the
--   specified region. All instances are launched into this VPC, and you
--   cannot change the ID later.
--   
--   <ul>
--   <li>If your account supports EC2 Classic, the default value is no
--   VPC.</li>
--   <li>If your account does not support EC2 Classic, the default value is
--   the default VPC for the specified region.</li>
--   </ul>
--   
--   If the VPC ID corresponds to a default VPC and you have specified
--   either the <tt>DefaultAvailabilityZone</tt> or the
--   <tt>DefaultSubnetId</tt> parameter only, AWS OpsWorks Stacks infers
--   the value of the other parameter. If you specify neither parameter,
--   AWS OpsWorks Stacks sets these parameters to the first valid
--   Availability Zone for the specified region and the corresponding
--   default VPC subnet ID, respectively.
--   
--   If you specify a nondefault VPC ID, note the following:
--   
--   <ul>
--   <li>It must belong to a VPC in your account that is in the specified
--   region.</li>
--   <li>You must specify a value for <tt>DefaultSubnetId</tt>.</li>
--   </ul>
--   
--   For more information about how to use AWS OpsWorks Stacks with a VPC,
--   see <a>Running a Stack in a VPC</a>. For more information about
--   default VPC and EC2 Classic, see <a>Supported Platforms</a>.
--   
--   <a>$sel:chefConfiguration:CloneStack'</a>,
--   <a>cloneStack_chefConfiguration</a> - A <tt>ChefConfiguration</tt>
--   object that specifies whether to enable Berkshelf and the Berkshelf
--   version on Chef 11.10 stacks. For more information, see <a>Create a
--   New Stack</a>.
--   
--   <a>$sel:agentVersion:CloneStack'</a>, <a>cloneStack_agentVersion</a> -
--   The default AWS OpsWorks Stacks agent version. You have the following
--   options:
--   
--   <ul>
--   <li>Auto-update - Set this parameter to <tt>LATEST</tt>. AWS OpsWorks
--   Stacks automatically installs new agent versions on the stack's
--   instances as soon as they are available.</li>
--   <li>Fixed version - Set this parameter to your preferred agent
--   version. To update the agent version, you must edit the stack
--   configuration and specify a new version. AWS OpsWorks Stacks then
--   automatically installs that version on the stack's instances.</li>
--   </ul>
--   
--   The default setting is <tt>LATEST</tt>. To specify an agent version,
--   you must use the complete version number, not the abbreviated number
--   shown on the console. For a list of available agent version numbers,
--   call DescribeAgentVersions. AgentVersion cannot be set to Chef 12.2.
--   
--   You can also specify an agent version when you create or update an
--   instance, which overrides the stack's default setting.
--   
--   <a>$sel:defaultSshKeyName:CloneStack'</a>,
--   <a>cloneStack_defaultSshKeyName</a> - A default Amazon EC2 key pair
--   name. The default value is none. If you specify a key pair name, AWS
--   OpsWorks installs the public key on the instance and you can use the
--   private key with an SSH client to log in to the instance. For more
--   information, see <a>Using SSH to Communicate with an Instance</a> and
--   <a>Managing SSH Access</a>. You can override this setting by
--   specifying a different key pair, or no key pair, when you <a>create an
--   instance</a>.
--   
--   <a>$sel:customJson:CloneStack'</a>, <a>cloneStack_customJson</a> - A
--   string that contains user-defined, custom JSON. It is used to override
--   the corresponding default stack configuration JSON values. The string
--   should be in the following format:
--   
--   <pre>
--   "{\"key1\": \"value1\", \"key2\": \"value2\",...}"
--   </pre>
--   
--   For more information about custom JSON, see <a>Use Custom JSON to
--   Modify the Stack Configuration Attributes</a>
--   
--   <a>$sel:clonePermissions:CloneStack'</a>,
--   <a>cloneStack_clonePermissions</a> - Whether to clone the source
--   stack's permissions.
--   
--   <a>$sel:customCookbooksSource:CloneStack'</a>,
--   <a>cloneStack_customCookbooksSource</a> - Contains the information
--   required to retrieve an app or cookbook from a repository. For more
--   information, see <a>Adding Apps</a> or <a>Cookbooks and Recipes</a>.
--   
--   <a>$sel:defaultAvailabilityZone:CloneStack'</a>,
--   <a>cloneStack_defaultAvailabilityZone</a> - The cloned stack's default
--   Availability Zone, which must be in the specified region. For more
--   information, see <a>Regions and Endpoints</a>. If you also specify a
--   value for <tt>DefaultSubnetId</tt>, the subnet must be in the same
--   zone. For more information, see the <tt>VpcId</tt> parameter
--   description.
--   
--   <a>$sel:attributes:CloneStack'</a>, <a>cloneStack_attributes</a> - A
--   list of stack attributes and values as key/value pairs to be added to
--   the cloned stack.
--   
--   <a>$sel:name:CloneStack'</a>, <a>cloneStack_name</a> - The cloned
--   stack name.
--   
--   <a>$sel:defaultOs:CloneStack'</a>, <a>cloneStack_defaultOs</a> - The
--   stack's operating system, which must be set to one of the following.
--   
--   <ul>
--   <li>A supported Linux operating system: An Amazon Linux version, such
--   as <tt>Amazon Linux 2018.03</tt>, <tt>Amazon Linux 2017.09</tt>,
--   <tt>Amazon Linux 2017.03</tt>, <tt>Amazon Linux 2016.09</tt>,
--   <tt>Amazon Linux 2016.03</tt>, <tt>Amazon Linux 2015.09</tt>, or
--   <tt>Amazon Linux 2015.03</tt>.</li>
--   <li>A supported Ubuntu operating system, such as <tt>Ubuntu 16.04
--   LTS</tt>, <tt>Ubuntu 14.04 LTS</tt>, or <tt>Ubuntu 12.04
--   LTS</tt>.</li>
--   <li><pre>CentOS Linux 7</pre></li>
--   <li><pre>Red Hat Enterprise Linux 7</pre></li>
--   <li><tt>Microsoft Windows Server 2012 R2 Base</tt>, <tt>Microsoft
--   Windows Server 2012 R2 with SQL Server Express</tt>, <tt>Microsoft
--   Windows Server 2012 R2 with SQL Server Standard</tt>, or <tt>Microsoft
--   Windows Server 2012 R2 with SQL Server Web</tt>.</li>
--   <li>A custom AMI: <tt>Custom</tt>. You specify the custom AMI you want
--   to use when you create instances. For more information about how to
--   use custom AMIs with OpsWorks, see <a>Using Custom AMIs</a>.</li>
--   </ul>
--   
--   The default option is the parent stack's operating system. For more
--   information about supported operating systems, see <a>AWS OpsWorks
--   Stacks Operating Systems</a>.
--   
--   You can specify a different Linux operating system for the cloned
--   stack, but you cannot change from Linux to Windows or Windows to
--   Linux.
--   
--   <a>$sel:useOpsworksSecurityGroups:CloneStack'</a>,
--   <a>cloneStack_useOpsworksSecurityGroups</a> - Whether to associate the
--   AWS OpsWorks Stacks built-in security groups with the stack's layers.
--   
--   AWS OpsWorks Stacks provides a standard set of built-in security
--   groups, one for each layer, which are associated with layers by
--   default. With <tt>UseOpsworksSecurityGroups</tt> you can instead
--   provide your own custom security groups.
--   <tt>UseOpsworksSecurityGroups</tt> has the following settings:
--   
--   <ul>
--   <li>True - AWS OpsWorks Stacks automatically associates the
--   appropriate built-in security group with each layer (default setting).
--   You can associate additional security groups with a layer after you
--   create it but you cannot delete the built-in security group.</li>
--   <li>False - AWS OpsWorks Stacks does not associate built-in security
--   groups with layers. You must create appropriate Amazon Elastic Compute
--   Cloud (Amazon EC2) security groups and associate a security group with
--   each layer that you create. However, you can still manually associate
--   a built-in security group with a layer on creation; custom security
--   groups are required only for those layers that need custom
--   settings.</li>
--   </ul>
--   
--   For more information, see <a>Create a New Stack</a>.
--   
--   <a>$sel:useCustomCookbooks:CloneStack'</a>,
--   <a>cloneStack_useCustomCookbooks</a> - Whether to use custom
--   cookbooks.
--   
--   <a>$sel:defaultSubnetId:CloneStack'</a>,
--   <a>cloneStack_defaultSubnetId</a> - The stack's default VPC subnet ID.
--   This parameter is required if you specify a value for the
--   <tt>VpcId</tt> parameter. All instances are launched into this subnet
--   unless you specify otherwise when you create the instance. If you also
--   specify a value for <tt>DefaultAvailabilityZone</tt>, the subnet must
--   be in that zone. For information on default values and when this
--   parameter is required, see the <tt>VpcId</tt> parameter description.
--   
--   <a>$sel:region:CloneStack'</a>, <a>cloneStack_region</a> - The cloned
--   stack AWS region, such as "ap-northeast-2". For more information about
--   AWS regions, see <a>Regions and Endpoints</a>.
--   
--   <a>$sel:configurationManager:CloneStack'</a>,
--   <a>cloneStack_configurationManager</a> - The configuration manager.
--   When you clone a stack we recommend that you use the configuration
--   manager to specify the Chef version: 12, 11.10, or 11.4 for Linux
--   stacks, or 12.2 for Windows stacks. The default value for Linux stacks
--   is currently 12.
--   
--   <a>$sel:hostnameTheme:CloneStack'</a>, <a>cloneStack_hostnameTheme</a>
--   - The stack's host name theme, with spaces are replaced by
--   underscores. The theme is used to generate host names for the stack's
--   instances. By default, <tt>HostnameTheme</tt> is set to
--   <tt>Layer_Dependent</tt>, which creates host names by appending
--   integers to the layer's short name. The other themes are:
--   
--   <ul>
--   <li><pre>Baked_Goods</pre></li>
--   <li><pre>Clouds</pre></li>
--   <li><pre>Europe_Cities</pre></li>
--   <li><pre>Fruits</pre></li>
--   <li><pre>Greek_Deities_and_Titans</pre></li>
--   <li><pre>Legendary_creatures_from_Japan</pre></li>
--   <li><pre>Planets_and_Moons</pre></li>
--   <li><pre>Roman_Deities</pre></li>
--   <li><pre>Scottish_Islands</pre></li>
--   <li><pre>US_Cities</pre></li>
--   <li><pre>Wild_Cats</pre></li>
--   </ul>
--   
--   To obtain a generated host name, call <tt>GetHostNameSuggestion</tt>,
--   which returns a host name based on the current theme.
--   
--   <a>$sel:sourceStackId:CloneStack'</a>, <a>cloneStack_sourceStackId</a>
--   - The source stack ID.
--   
--   <a>$sel:serviceRoleArn:CloneStack'</a>,
--   <a>cloneStack_serviceRoleArn</a> - The stack AWS Identity and Access
--   Management (IAM) role, which allows AWS OpsWorks Stacks to work with
--   AWS resources on your behalf. You must set this parameter to the
--   Amazon Resource Name (ARN) for an existing IAM role. If you create a
--   stack by using the AWS OpsWorks Stacks console, it creates the role
--   for you. You can obtain an existing stack's IAM ARN programmatically
--   by calling DescribePermissions. For more information about IAM ARNs,
--   see <a>Using Identifiers</a>.
--   
--   You must set this parameter to a valid service role ARN or the action
--   will fail; there is no default value. You can specify the source
--   stack's service role ARN, if you prefer, but you must do so
--   explicitly.
newCloneStack :: Text -> Text -> CloneStack

-- | The Amazon Resource Name (ARN) of an IAM profile that is the default
--   profile for all of the stack's EC2 instances. For more information
--   about IAM ARNs, see <a>Using Identifiers</a>.
cloneStack_defaultInstanceProfileArn :: Lens' CloneStack (Maybe Text)

-- | A list of source stack app IDs to be included in the cloned stack.
cloneStack_cloneAppIds :: Lens' CloneStack (Maybe [Text])

-- | The default root device type. This value is used by default for all
--   instances in the cloned stack, but you can override it when you create
--   an instance. For more information, see <a>Storage for the Root
--   Device</a>.
cloneStack_defaultRootDeviceType :: Lens' CloneStack (Maybe RootDeviceType)

-- | The ID of the VPC that the cloned stack is to be launched into. It
--   must be in the specified region. All instances are launched into this
--   VPC, and you cannot change the ID later.
--   
--   <ul>
--   <li>If your account supports EC2 Classic, the default value is no
--   VPC.</li>
--   <li>If your account does not support EC2 Classic, the default value is
--   the default VPC for the specified region.</li>
--   </ul>
--   
--   If the VPC ID corresponds to a default VPC and you have specified
--   either the <tt>DefaultAvailabilityZone</tt> or the
--   <tt>DefaultSubnetId</tt> parameter only, AWS OpsWorks Stacks infers
--   the value of the other parameter. If you specify neither parameter,
--   AWS OpsWorks Stacks sets these parameters to the first valid
--   Availability Zone for the specified region and the corresponding
--   default VPC subnet ID, respectively.
--   
--   If you specify a nondefault VPC ID, note the following:
--   
--   <ul>
--   <li>It must belong to a VPC in your account that is in the specified
--   region.</li>
--   <li>You must specify a value for <tt>DefaultSubnetId</tt>.</li>
--   </ul>
--   
--   For more information about how to use AWS OpsWorks Stacks with a VPC,
--   see <a>Running a Stack in a VPC</a>. For more information about
--   default VPC and EC2 Classic, see <a>Supported Platforms</a>.
cloneStack_vpcId :: Lens' CloneStack (Maybe Text)

-- | A <tt>ChefConfiguration</tt> object that specifies whether to enable
--   Berkshelf and the Berkshelf version on Chef 11.10 stacks. For more
--   information, see <a>Create a New Stack</a>.
cloneStack_chefConfiguration :: Lens' CloneStack (Maybe ChefConfiguration)

-- | The default AWS OpsWorks Stacks agent version. You have the following
--   options:
--   
--   <ul>
--   <li>Auto-update - Set this parameter to <tt>LATEST</tt>. AWS OpsWorks
--   Stacks automatically installs new agent versions on the stack's
--   instances as soon as they are available.</li>
--   <li>Fixed version - Set this parameter to your preferred agent
--   version. To update the agent version, you must edit the stack
--   configuration and specify a new version. AWS OpsWorks Stacks then
--   automatically installs that version on the stack's instances.</li>
--   </ul>
--   
--   The default setting is <tt>LATEST</tt>. To specify an agent version,
--   you must use the complete version number, not the abbreviated number
--   shown on the console. For a list of available agent version numbers,
--   call DescribeAgentVersions. AgentVersion cannot be set to Chef 12.2.
--   
--   You can also specify an agent version when you create or update an
--   instance, which overrides the stack's default setting.
cloneStack_agentVersion :: Lens' CloneStack (Maybe Text)

-- | A default Amazon EC2 key pair name. The default value is none. If you
--   specify a key pair name, AWS OpsWorks installs the public key on the
--   instance and you can use the private key with an SSH client to log in
--   to the instance. For more information, see <a>Using SSH to Communicate
--   with an Instance</a> and <a>Managing SSH Access</a>. You can override
--   this setting by specifying a different key pair, or no key pair, when
--   you <a>create an instance</a>.
cloneStack_defaultSshKeyName :: Lens' CloneStack (Maybe Text)

-- | A string that contains user-defined, custom JSON. It is used to
--   override the corresponding default stack configuration JSON values.
--   The string should be in the following format:
--   
--   <pre>
--   "{\"key1\": \"value1\", \"key2\": \"value2\",...}"
--   </pre>
--   
--   For more information about custom JSON, see <a>Use Custom JSON to
--   Modify the Stack Configuration Attributes</a>
cloneStack_customJson :: Lens' CloneStack (Maybe Text)

-- | Whether to clone the source stack's permissions.
cloneStack_clonePermissions :: Lens' CloneStack (Maybe Bool)

-- | Contains the information required to retrieve an app or cookbook from
--   a repository. For more information, see <a>Adding Apps</a> or
--   <a>Cookbooks and Recipes</a>.
cloneStack_customCookbooksSource :: Lens' CloneStack (Maybe Source)

-- | The cloned stack's default Availability Zone, which must be in the
--   specified region. For more information, see <a>Regions and
--   Endpoints</a>. If you also specify a value for
--   <tt>DefaultSubnetId</tt>, the subnet must be in the same zone. For
--   more information, see the <tt>VpcId</tt> parameter description.
cloneStack_defaultAvailabilityZone :: Lens' CloneStack (Maybe Text)

-- | A list of stack attributes and values as key/value pairs to be added
--   to the cloned stack.
cloneStack_attributes :: Lens' CloneStack (Maybe (HashMap StackAttributesKeys (Maybe Text)))

-- | The cloned stack name.
cloneStack_name :: Lens' CloneStack (Maybe Text)

-- | The stack's operating system, which must be set to one of the
--   following.
--   
--   <ul>
--   <li>A supported Linux operating system: An Amazon Linux version, such
--   as <tt>Amazon Linux 2018.03</tt>, <tt>Amazon Linux 2017.09</tt>,
--   <tt>Amazon Linux 2017.03</tt>, <tt>Amazon Linux 2016.09</tt>,
--   <tt>Amazon Linux 2016.03</tt>, <tt>Amazon Linux 2015.09</tt>, or
--   <tt>Amazon Linux 2015.03</tt>.</li>
--   <li>A supported Ubuntu operating system, such as <tt>Ubuntu 16.04
--   LTS</tt>, <tt>Ubuntu 14.04 LTS</tt>, or <tt>Ubuntu 12.04
--   LTS</tt>.</li>
--   <li><pre>CentOS Linux 7</pre></li>
--   <li><pre>Red Hat Enterprise Linux 7</pre></li>
--   <li><tt>Microsoft Windows Server 2012 R2 Base</tt>, <tt>Microsoft
--   Windows Server 2012 R2 with SQL Server Express</tt>, <tt>Microsoft
--   Windows Server 2012 R2 with SQL Server Standard</tt>, or <tt>Microsoft
--   Windows Server 2012 R2 with SQL Server Web</tt>.</li>
--   <li>A custom AMI: <tt>Custom</tt>. You specify the custom AMI you want
--   to use when you create instances. For more information about how to
--   use custom AMIs with OpsWorks, see <a>Using Custom AMIs</a>.</li>
--   </ul>
--   
--   The default option is the parent stack's operating system. For more
--   information about supported operating systems, see <a>AWS OpsWorks
--   Stacks Operating Systems</a>.
--   
--   You can specify a different Linux operating system for the cloned
--   stack, but you cannot change from Linux to Windows or Windows to
--   Linux.
cloneStack_defaultOs :: Lens' CloneStack (Maybe Text)

-- | Whether to associate the AWS OpsWorks Stacks built-in security groups
--   with the stack's layers.
--   
--   AWS OpsWorks Stacks provides a standard set of built-in security
--   groups, one for each layer, which are associated with layers by
--   default. With <tt>UseOpsworksSecurityGroups</tt> you can instead
--   provide your own custom security groups.
--   <tt>UseOpsworksSecurityGroups</tt> has the following settings:
--   
--   <ul>
--   <li>True - AWS OpsWorks Stacks automatically associates the
--   appropriate built-in security group with each layer (default setting).
--   You can associate additional security groups with a layer after you
--   create it but you cannot delete the built-in security group.</li>
--   <li>False - AWS OpsWorks Stacks does not associate built-in security
--   groups with layers. You must create appropriate Amazon Elastic Compute
--   Cloud (Amazon EC2) security groups and associate a security group with
--   each layer that you create. However, you can still manually associate
--   a built-in security group with a layer on creation; custom security
--   groups are required only for those layers that need custom
--   settings.</li>
--   </ul>
--   
--   For more information, see <a>Create a New Stack</a>.
cloneStack_useOpsworksSecurityGroups :: Lens' CloneStack (Maybe Bool)

-- | Whether to use custom cookbooks.
cloneStack_useCustomCookbooks :: Lens' CloneStack (Maybe Bool)

-- | The stack's default VPC subnet ID. This parameter is required if you
--   specify a value for the <tt>VpcId</tt> parameter. All instances are
--   launched into this subnet unless you specify otherwise when you create
--   the instance. If you also specify a value for
--   <tt>DefaultAvailabilityZone</tt>, the subnet must be in that zone. For
--   information on default values and when this parameter is required, see
--   the <tt>VpcId</tt> parameter description.
cloneStack_defaultSubnetId :: Lens' CloneStack (Maybe Text)

-- | The cloned stack AWS region, such as "ap-northeast-2". For more
--   information about AWS regions, see <a>Regions and Endpoints</a>.
cloneStack_region :: Lens' CloneStack (Maybe Text)

-- | The configuration manager. When you clone a stack we recommend that
--   you use the configuration manager to specify the Chef version: 12,
--   11.10, or 11.4 for Linux stacks, or 12.2 for Windows stacks. The
--   default value for Linux stacks is currently 12.
cloneStack_configurationManager :: Lens' CloneStack (Maybe StackConfigurationManager)

-- | The stack's host name theme, with spaces are replaced by underscores.
--   The theme is used to generate host names for the stack's instances. By
--   default, <tt>HostnameTheme</tt> is set to <tt>Layer_Dependent</tt>,
--   which creates host names by appending integers to the layer's short
--   name. The other themes are:
--   
--   <ul>
--   <li><pre>Baked_Goods</pre></li>
--   <li><pre>Clouds</pre></li>
--   <li><pre>Europe_Cities</pre></li>
--   <li><pre>Fruits</pre></li>
--   <li><pre>Greek_Deities_and_Titans</pre></li>
--   <li><pre>Legendary_creatures_from_Japan</pre></li>
--   <li><pre>Planets_and_Moons</pre></li>
--   <li><pre>Roman_Deities</pre></li>
--   <li><pre>Scottish_Islands</pre></li>
--   <li><pre>US_Cities</pre></li>
--   <li><pre>Wild_Cats</pre></li>
--   </ul>
--   
--   To obtain a generated host name, call <tt>GetHostNameSuggestion</tt>,
--   which returns a host name based on the current theme.
cloneStack_hostnameTheme :: Lens' CloneStack (Maybe Text)

-- | The source stack ID.
cloneStack_sourceStackId :: Lens' CloneStack Text

-- | The stack AWS Identity and Access Management (IAM) role, which allows
--   AWS OpsWorks Stacks to work with AWS resources on your behalf. You
--   must set this parameter to the Amazon Resource Name (ARN) for an
--   existing IAM role. If you create a stack by using the AWS OpsWorks
--   Stacks console, it creates the role for you. You can obtain an
--   existing stack's IAM ARN programmatically by calling
--   DescribePermissions. For more information about IAM ARNs, see <a>Using
--   Identifiers</a>.
--   
--   You must set this parameter to a valid service role ARN or the action
--   will fail; there is no default value. You can specify the source
--   stack's service role ARN, if you prefer, but you must do so
--   explicitly.
cloneStack_serviceRoleArn :: Lens' CloneStack Text

-- | Contains the response to a <tt>CloneStack</tt> request.
--   
--   <i>See:</i> <a>newCloneStackResponse</a> smart constructor.
data CloneStackResponse
CloneStackResponse' :: Maybe Text -> Int -> CloneStackResponse

-- | The cloned stack ID.
[$sel:stackId:CloneStackResponse'] :: CloneStackResponse -> Maybe Text

-- | The response's http status code.
[$sel:httpStatus:CloneStackResponse'] :: CloneStackResponse -> Int

-- | Create a value of <a>CloneStackResponse</a> with all optional fields
--   omitted.
--   
--   Use <a>generic-lens</a> or <a>optics</a> to modify other optional
--   fields.
--   
--   The following record fields are available, with the corresponding
--   lenses provided for backwards compatibility:
--   
--   <a>$sel:stackId:CloneStackResponse'</a>,
--   <a>cloneStackResponse_stackId</a> - The cloned stack ID.
--   
--   <a>$sel:httpStatus:CloneStackResponse'</a>,
--   <a>cloneStackResponse_httpStatus</a> - The response's http status
--   code.
newCloneStackResponse :: Int -> CloneStackResponse

-- | The cloned stack ID.
cloneStackResponse_stackId :: Lens' CloneStackResponse (Maybe Text)

-- | The response's http status code.
cloneStackResponse_httpStatus :: Lens' CloneStackResponse Int

instance GHC.Show.Show Network.AWS.OpsWorks.CloneStack.CloneStack
instance GHC.Read.Read Network.AWS.OpsWorks.CloneStack.CloneStack
instance GHC.Classes.Eq Network.AWS.OpsWorks.CloneStack.CloneStack
instance GHC.Generics.Generic Network.AWS.OpsWorks.CloneStack.CloneStackResponse
instance GHC.Show.Show Network.AWS.OpsWorks.CloneStack.CloneStackResponse
instance GHC.Read.Read Network.AWS.OpsWorks.CloneStack.CloneStackResponse
instance GHC.Classes.Eq Network.AWS.OpsWorks.CloneStack.CloneStackResponse
instance Network.AWS.Types.AWSRequest Network.AWS.OpsWorks.CloneStack.CloneStack
instance Control.DeepSeq.NFData Network.AWS.OpsWorks.CloneStack.CloneStackResponse
instance Data.Hashable.Class.Hashable Network.AWS.OpsWorks.CloneStack.CloneStack
instance Control.DeepSeq.NFData Network.AWS.OpsWorks.CloneStack.CloneStack
instance Network.AWS.Data.Headers.ToHeaders Network.AWS.OpsWorks.CloneStack.CloneStack
