instance Network.AWS.Data.Path.ToPath Network.AWS.OpsWorks.CloneStack.CloneStack
instance Network.AWS.Data.Query.ToQuery Network.AWS.OpsWorks.CloneStack.CloneStack


-- | Attaches an Elastic Load Balancing load balancer to a specified layer.
--   AWS OpsWorks Stacks does not support Application Load Balancer. You
--   can only use Classic Load Balancer with AWS OpsWorks Stacks. For more
--   information, see <a>Elastic Load Balancing</a>.
--   
--   You must create the Elastic Load Balancing instance separately, by
--   using the Elastic Load Balancing console, API, or CLI. For more
--   information, see <a>Elastic Load Balancing Developer Guide</a>.
--   
--   <b>Required Permissions</b>: To use this action, an IAM user must have
--   a Manage permissions level for the stack, or an attached policy that
--   explicitly grants permissions. For more information on user
--   permissions, see <a>Managing User Permissions</a>.
module Network.AWS.OpsWorks.AttachElasticLoadBalancer

-- | <i>See:</i> <a>newAttachElasticLoadBalancer</a> smart constructor.
data AttachElasticLoadBalancer
AttachElasticLoadBalancer' :: Text -> Text -> AttachElasticLoadBalancer

-- | The Elastic Load Balancing instance's name.
[$sel:elasticLoadBalancerName:AttachElasticLoadBalancer'] :: AttachElasticLoadBalancer -> Text

-- | The ID of the layer to which the Elastic Load Balancing instance is to
--   be attached.
[$sel:layerId:AttachElasticLoadBalancer'] :: AttachElasticLoadBalancer -> Text

-- | Create a value of <a>AttachElasticLoadBalancer</a> with all optional
--   fields omitted.
--   
--   Use <a>generic-lens</a> or <a>optics</a> to modify other optional
--   fields.
--   
--   The following record fields are available, with the corresponding
--   lenses provided for backwards compatibility:
--   
--   <a>$sel:elasticLoadBalancerName:AttachElasticLoadBalancer'</a>,
--   <a>attachElasticLoadBalancer_elasticLoadBalancerName</a> - The Elastic
--   Load Balancing instance's name.
--   
--   <a>$sel:layerId:AttachElasticLoadBalancer'</a>,
--   <a>attachElasticLoadBalancer_layerId</a> - The ID of the layer to
--   which the Elastic Load Balancing instance is to be attached.
newAttachElasticLoadBalancer :: Text -> Text -> AttachElasticLoadBalancer

-- | The Elastic Load Balancing instance's name.
attachElasticLoadBalancer_elasticLoadBalancerName :: Lens' AttachElasticLoadBalancer Text

-- | The ID of the layer to which the Elastic Load Balancing instance is to
--   be attached.
attachElasticLoadBalancer_layerId :: Lens' AttachElasticLoadBalancer Text

-- | <i>See:</i> <a>newAttachElasticLoadBalancerResponse</a> smart
--   constructor.
data AttachElasticLoadBalancerResponse
AttachElasticLoadBalancerResponse' :: AttachElasticLoadBalancerResponse

-- | Create a value of <a>AttachElasticLoadBalancerResponse</a> with all
--   optional fields omitted.
--   
--   Use <a>generic-lens</a> or <a>optics</a> to modify other optional
--   fields.
newAttachElasticLoadBalancerResponse :: AttachElasticLoadBalancerResponse
instance GHC.Generics.Generic Network.AWS.OpsWorks.AttachElasticLoadBalancer.AttachElasticLoadBalancer
instance GHC.Show.Show Network.AWS.OpsWorks.AttachElasticLoadBalancer.AttachElasticLoadBalancer
instance GHC.Read.Read Network.AWS.OpsWorks.AttachElasticLoadBalancer.AttachElasticLoadBalancer

instance Network.AWS.Types.AWSRequest Network.AWS.OpsWorks.AttachElasticLoadBalancer.AttachElasticLoadBalancer

instance Network.AWS.Data.Query.ToQuery Network.AWS.OpsWorks.AttachElasticLoadBalancer.AttachElasticLoadBalancer


-- | Associates one of the stack's registered Elastic IP addresses with a
--   specified instance. The address must first be registered with the
--   stack by calling RegisterElasticIp. For more information, see
--   <a>Resource Management</a>.
--   
--   <b>Required Permissions</b>: To use this action, an IAM user must have
--   a Manage permissions level for the stack, or an attached policy that
--   explicitly grants permissions. For more information on user
--   permissions, see <a>Managing User Permissions</a>.
module Network.AWS.OpsWorks.AssociateElasticIp

-- | <i>See:</i> <a>newAssociateElasticIp</a> smart constructor.
data AssociateElasticIp
AssociateElasticIp' :: Maybe Text -> Text -> AssociateElasticIp

-- | The instance ID.
[$sel:instanceId:AssociateElasticIp'] :: AssociateElasticIp -> Maybe Text

-- | The Elastic IP address.
[$sel:elasticIp:AssociateElasticIp'] :: AssociateElasticIp -> Text

-- | Create a value of <a>AssociateElasticIp</a> with all optional fields
--   omitted.
--   
--   Use <a>generic-lens</a> or <a>optics</a> to modify other optional
--   fields.
--   
--   The following record fields are available, with the corresponding

-- | Assigns one of the stack's registered Amazon EBS volumes to a
--   specified instance. The volume must first be registered with the stack
--   by calling RegisterVolume. After you register the volume, you must
--   call UpdateVolume to specify a mount point before calling
--   <tt>AssignVolume</tt>. For more information, see <a>Resource
--   Management</a>.
--   
--   <b>Required Permissions</b>: To use this action, an IAM user must have
--   a Manage permissions level for the stack, or an attached policy that
--   explicitly grants permissions. For more information on user
--   permissions, see <a>Managing User Permissions</a>.
module Network.AWS.OpsWorks.AssignVolume

-- | <i>See:</i> <a>newAssignVolume</a> smart constructor.
data AssignVolume
AssignVolume' :: Maybe Text -> Text -> AssignVolume

-- | The instance ID.
[$sel:instanceId:AssignVolume'] :: AssignVolume -> Maybe Text

-- | The volume ID.
[$sel:volumeId:AssignVolume'] :: AssignVolume -> Text

-- | Create a value of <a>AssignVolume</a> with all optional fields
--   omitted.
--   
--   Use <a>generic-lens</a> or <a>optics</a> to modify other optional
--   fields.
--   
--   The following record fields are available, with the corresponding
--   lenses provided for backwards compatibility:
--   
--   <a>$sel:instanceId:AssignVolume'</a>, <a>assignVolume_instanceId</a> -
--   The instance ID.
--   
--   <a>$sel:volumeId:AssignVolume'</a>, <a>assignVolume_volumeId</a> - The
--   volume ID.
newAssignVolume :: Text -> AssignVolume

-- | The instance ID.
assignVolume_instanceId :: Lens' AssignVolume (Maybe Text)

-- | The volume ID.
assignVolume_volumeId :: Lens' AssignVolume Text

--   fields.

-- | Assign a registered instance to a layer.
--   
--   <ul>
--   <li>You can assign registered on-premises instances to any layer
--   type.</li>
--   <li>You can assign registered Amazon EC2 instances only to custom
--   layers.</li>
--   <li>You cannot use this action with instances that were created with
--   AWS OpsWorks Stacks.</li>
--   </ul>
--   
--   <b>Required Permissions</b>: To use this action, an AWS Identity and
--   Access Management (IAM) user must have a Manage permissions level for
--   the stack or an attached policy that explicitly grants permissions.
--   For more information on user permissions, see <a>Managing User
--   Permissions</a>.
module Network.AWS.OpsWorks.AssignInstance

-- | <i>See:</i> <a>newAssignInstance</a> smart constructor.
data AssignInstance
AssignInstance' :: Text -> [Text] -> AssignInstance

-- | The instance ID.
[$sel:instanceId:AssignInstance'] :: AssignInstance -> Text

-- | The layer ID, which must correspond to a custom layer. You cannot
--   assign a registered instance to a built-in layer.
[$sel:layerIds:AssignInstance'] :: AssignInstance -> [Text]

-- | Create a value of <a>AssignInstance</a> with all optional fields
--   omitted.
--   
--   Use <a>generic-lens</a> or <a>optics</a> to modify other optional
--   fields.
--   
--   The following record fields are available, with the corresponding
--   lenses provided for backwards compatibility:
--   
--   <a>$sel:instanceId:AssignInstance'</a>,
--   <a>assignInstance_instanceId</a> - The instance ID.
--   
--   <a>$sel:layerIds:AssignInstance'</a>, <a>assignInstance_layerIds</a> -
--   The layer ID, which must correspond to a custom layer. You cannot
--   assign a registered instance to a built-in layer.
newAssignInstance :: Text -> AssignInstance

-- | The instance ID.
assignInstance_instanceId :: Lens' AssignInstance Text

-- | The layer ID, which must correspond to a custom layer. You cannot
--   assign a registered instance to a built-in layer.
assignInstance_layerIds :: Lens' AssignInstance [Text]

--   fields omitted.

--   Use <a>generic-lens</a> or <a>optics</a> to modify other optional
--   fields.

instance GHC.Read.Read Network.AWS.OpsWorks.AssignInstance.AssignInstance
instance GHC.Classes.Eq Network.AWS.OpsWorks.AssignInstance.AssignInstance

-- | Unassigns a registered instance from all layers that are using the
--   instance. The instance remains in the stack as an unassigned instance,
--   and can be assigned to another layer as needed. You cannot use this

--   a Manage permissions level for the stack or an attached policy that

-- | Removes tags from a specified stack or layer.

--   omitted.

--   Resource Number (ARN).

--   list of the keys of tags to be removed from a stack or layer.

-- | Updates a specified app.
--   
--   <b>Required Permissions</b>: To use this action, an IAM user must have
--   a Deploy or Manage permissions level for the stack, or an attached
--   policy that explicitly grants permissions. For more information on
--   user permissions, see <a>Managing User Permissions</a>.
module Network.AWS.OpsWorks.UpdateApp

-- | <i>See:</i> <a>newUpdateApp</a> smart constructor.
data UpdateApp
UpdateApp' :: Maybe SslConfiguration -> Maybe [EnvironmentVariable] -> Maybe Bool -> Maybe [DataSource] -> Maybe Source -> Maybe (HashMap AppAttributesKeys Text) -> Maybe Text -> Maybe AppType -> Maybe [Text] -> Maybe Text -> Text -> UpdateApp

-- | An <tt>SslConfiguration</tt> object with the SSL configuration.
[$sel:sslConfiguration:UpdateApp'] :: UpdateApp -> Maybe SslConfiguration

-- | An array of <tt>EnvironmentVariable</tt> objects that specify
--   environment variables to be associated with the app. After you deploy
--   the app, these variables are defined on the associated app server
--   instances.For more information, see <a>Environment Variables</a>.
--   
--   There is no specific limit on the number of environment variables.
--   However, the size of the associated data structure - which includes
--   the variables' names, values, and protected flag values - cannot
--   exceed 20 KB. This limit should accommodate most if not all use cases.
--   Exceeding it will cause an exception with the message, "Environment:
--   is too large (maximum is 20 KB)."
--   
--   If you have specified one or more environment variables, you cannot
--   modify the stack's Chef version.
[$sel:environment:UpdateApp'] :: UpdateApp -> Maybe [EnvironmentVariable]

-- | Whether SSL is enabled for the app.
[$sel:enableSsl:UpdateApp'] :: UpdateApp -> Maybe Bool

-- | The app's data sources.
[$sel:dataSources:UpdateApp'] :: UpdateApp -> Maybe [DataSource]

-- | A <tt>Source</tt> object that specifies the app repository.
[$sel:appSource:UpdateApp'] :: UpdateApp -> Maybe Source

-- | One or more user-defined key/value pairs to be added to the stack
--   attributes.
[$sel:attributes:UpdateApp'] :: UpdateApp -> Maybe (HashMap AppAttributesKeys Text)

-- | The app name.
[$sel:name:UpdateApp'] :: UpdateApp -> Maybe Text

-- | The app type.
[$sel:type':UpdateApp'] :: UpdateApp -> Maybe AppType

-- | The app's virtual host settings, with multiple domains separated by
--   commas. For example: <tt>'www.example.com, example.com'</tt>
[$sel:domains:UpdateApp'] :: UpdateApp -> Maybe [Text]

-- | A description of the app.
[$sel:description:UpdateApp'] :: UpdateApp -> Maybe Text

-- | The app ID.
[$sel:appId:UpdateApp'] :: UpdateApp -> Text

-- | Create a value of <a>UpdateApp</a> with all optional fields omitted.
--   
--   Use <a>generic-lens</a> or <a>optics</a> to modify other optional
--   fields.
--   
--   The following record fields are available, with the corresponding
--   lenses provided for backwards compatibility:
--   
--   <a>$sel:sslConfiguration:UpdateApp'</a>,
--   <a>updateApp_sslConfiguration</a> - An <tt>SslConfiguration</tt>
--   object with the SSL configuration.
--   
--   <a>$sel:environment:UpdateApp'</a>, <a>updateApp_environment</a> - An
--   array of <tt>EnvironmentVariable</tt> objects that specify environment
--   variables to be associated with the app. After you deploy the app,
--   these variables are defined on the associated app server instances.For
--   more information, see <a>Environment Variables</a>.
--   
--   There is no specific limit on the number of environment variables.
--   However, the size of the associated data structure - which includes
--   the variables' names, values, and protected flag values - cannot
--   exceed 20 KB. This limit should accommodate most if not all use cases.
--   Exceeding it will cause an exception with the message, "Environment:
--   is too large (maximum is 20 KB)."
--   
--   If you have specified one or more environment variables, you cannot
--   modify the stack's Chef version.
--   
--   <a>$sel:enableSsl:UpdateApp'</a>, <a>updateApp_enableSsl</a> - Whether
--   SSL is enabled for the app.
--   
--   <a>$sel:dataSources:UpdateApp'</a>, <a>updateApp_dataSources</a> - The
--   app's data sources.
--   
--   <a>$sel:appSource:UpdateApp'</a>, <a>updateApp_appSource</a> - A
--   <tt>Source</tt> object that specifies the app repository.
--   
--   <a>$sel:attributes:UpdateApp'</a>, <a>updateApp_attributes</a> - One
--   or more user-defined key/value pairs to be added to the stack
--   attributes.
--   
--   <a>$sel:name:UpdateApp'</a>, <a>updateApp_name</a> - The app name.
--   
--   <a>$sel:type':UpdateApp'</a>, <a>updateApp_type</a> - The app type.
--   
--   <a>$sel:domains:UpdateApp'</a>, <a>updateApp_domains</a> - The app's
--   virtual host settings, with multiple domains separated by commas. For
--   example: <tt>'www.example.com, example.com'</tt>
--   
--   <a>$sel:description:UpdateApp'</a>, <a>updateApp_description</a> - A
--   description of the app.
--   
--   <a>$sel:appId:UpdateApp'</a>, <a>updateApp_appId</a> - The app ID.
newUpdateApp :: Text -> UpdateApp

-- | An <tt>SslConfiguration</tt> object with the SSL configuration.
updateApp_sslConfiguration :: Lens' UpdateApp (Maybe SslConfiguration)

-- | An array of <tt>EnvironmentVariable</tt> objects that specify
--   environment variables to be associated with the app. After you deploy
--   the app, these variables are defined on the associated app server
--   instances.For more information, see <a>Environment Variables</a>.
--   
--   There is no specific limit on the number of environment variables.
--   However, the size of the associated data structure - which includes
--   the variables' names, values, and protected flag values - cannot
--   exceed 20 KB. This limit should accommodate most if not all use cases.
--   Exceeding it will cause an exception with the message, "Environment:
--   is too large (maximum is 20 KB)."
--   
--   If you have specified one or more environment variables, you cannot
--   modify the stack's Chef version.
updateApp_environment :: Lens' UpdateApp (Maybe [EnvironmentVariable])

-- | Whether SSL is enabled for the app.
updateApp_enableSsl :: Lens' UpdateApp (Maybe Bool)

-- | The app's data sources.
updateApp_dataSources :: Lens' UpdateApp (Maybe [DataSource])

-- | A <tt>Source</tt> object that specifies the app repository.
updateApp_appSource :: Lens' UpdateApp (Maybe Source)

-- | One or more user-defined key/value pairs to be added to the stack
--   attributes.
updateApp_attributes :: Lens' UpdateApp (Maybe (HashMap AppAttributesKeys Text))

-- | The app name.
updateApp_name :: Lens' UpdateApp (Maybe Text)

-- | The app type.
updateApp_type :: Lens' UpdateApp (Maybe AppType)

-- | The app's virtual host settings, with multiple domains separated by
--   commas. For example: <tt>'www.example.com, example.com'</tt>
updateApp_domains :: Lens' UpdateApp (Maybe [Text])

-- | A description of the app.
updateApp_description :: Lens' UpdateApp (Maybe Text)

-- | The app ID.
updateApp_appId :: Lens' UpdateApp Text

-- | <i>See:</i> <a>newUpdateAppResponse</a> smart constructor.
data UpdateAppResponse
UpdateAppResponse' :: UpdateAppResponse

-- | Create a value of <a>UpdateAppResponse</a> with all optional fields
--   omitted.
--   
--   Use <a>generic-lens</a> or <a>optics</a> to modify other optional
--   fields.
newUpdateAppResponse :: UpdateAppResponse
instance GHC.Generics.Generic Network.AWS.OpsWorks.UpdateApp.UpdateApp
instance GHC.Show.Show Network.AWS.OpsWorks.UpdateApp.UpdateApp
instance GHC.Read.Read Network.AWS.OpsWorks.UpdateApp.UpdateApp
instance GHC.Classes.Eq Network.AWS.OpsWorks.UpdateApp.UpdateApp
instance GHC.Generics.Generic Network.AWS.OpsWorks.UpdateApp.UpdateAppResponse
instance GHC.Show.Show Network.AWS.OpsWorks.UpdateApp.UpdateAppResponse
instance GHC.Read.Read Network.AWS.OpsWorks.UpdateApp.UpdateAppResponse
instance GHC.Classes.Eq Network.AWS.OpsWorks.UpdateApp.UpdateAppResponse
instance Network.AWS.Types.AWSRequest Network.AWS.OpsWorks.UpdateApp.UpdateApp
instance Control.DeepSeq.NFData Network.AWS.OpsWorks.UpdateApp.UpdateAppResponse
instance Data.Hashable.Class.Hashable Network.AWS.OpsWorks.UpdateApp.UpdateApp
instance Control.DeepSeq.NFData Network.AWS.OpsWorks.UpdateApp.UpdateApp
instance Network.AWS.Data.Headers.ToHeaders Network.AWS.OpsWorks.UpdateApp.UpdateApp
instance Data.Aeson.Types.ToJSON.ToJSON Network.AWS.OpsWorks.UpdateApp.UpdateApp
instance Network.AWS.Data.Path.ToPath Network.AWS.OpsWorks.UpdateApp.UpdateApp
instance Network.AWS.Data.Query.ToQuery Network.AWS.OpsWorks.UpdateApp.UpdateApp


-- | Updates a registered Elastic IP address's name. For more information,
--   see <a>Resource Management</a>.
--   
--   <b>Required Permissions</b>: To use this action, an IAM user must have
--   a Manage permissions level for the stack, or an attached policy that
--   explicitly grants permissions. For more information on user
--   permissions, see <a>Managing User Permissions</a>.
module Network.AWS.OpsWorks.UpdateElasticIp

-- | <i>See:</i> <a>newUpdateElasticIp</a> smart constructor.
data UpdateElasticIp
UpdateElasticIp' :: Maybe Text -> Text -> UpdateElasticIp

-- | The new name.
[$sel:name:UpdateElasticIp'] :: UpdateElasticIp -> Maybe Text

-- | The IP address for which you want to update the name.
[$sel:elasticIp:UpdateElasticIp'] :: UpdateElasticIp -> Text

-- | Create a value of <a>UpdateElasticIp</a> with all optional fields
--   omitted.
--   
--   Use <a>generic-lens</a> or <a>optics</a> to modify other optional
--   fields.
--   
--   The following record fields are available, with the corresponding
--   lenses provided for backwards compatibility:
--   
--   <a>$sel:name:UpdateElasticIp'</a>, <a>updateElasticIp_name</a> - The
--   new name.
--   
--   <a>$sel:elasticIp:UpdateElasticIp'</a>,
--   <a>updateElasticIp_elasticIp</a> - The IP address for which you want
--   to update the name.
newUpdateElasticIp :: Text -> UpdateElasticIp

-- | The new name.
updateElasticIp_name :: Lens' UpdateElasticIp (Maybe Text)

-- | The IP address for which you want to update the name.
updateElasticIp_elasticIp :: Lens' UpdateElasticIp Text

-- | <i>See:</i> <a>newUpdateElasticIpResponse</a> smart constructor.
data UpdateElasticIpResponse
UpdateElasticIpResponse' :: UpdateElasticIpResponse

-- | Create a value of <a>UpdateElasticIpResponse</a> with all optional
--   fields omitted.
--   
--   Use <a>generic-lens</a> or <a>optics</a> to modify other optional
--   fields.
newUpdateElasticIpResponse :: UpdateElasticIpResponse
instance GHC.Generics.Generic Network.AWS.OpsWorks.UpdateElasticIp.UpdateElasticIp
instance GHC.Show.Show Network.AWS.OpsWorks.UpdateElasticIp.UpdateElasticIp
instance GHC.Read.Read Network.AWS.OpsWorks.UpdateElasticIp.UpdateElasticIp
instance GHC.Classes.Eq Network.AWS.OpsWorks.UpdateElasticIp.UpdateElasticIp
instance GHC.Generics.Generic Network.AWS.OpsWorks.UpdateElasticIp.UpdateElasticIpResponse

-- | Updates a specified instance.
--   
--   <b>Required Permissions</b>: To use this action, an IAM user must have
--   a Manage permissions level for the stack, or an attached policy that
--   explicitly grants permissions. For more information on user
--   permissions, see <a>Managing User Permissions</a>.
module Network.AWS.OpsWorks.UpdateInstance

-- | <i>See:</i> <a>newUpdateInstance</a> smart constructor.
data UpdateInstance
UpdateInstance' :: Maybe Bool -> Maybe Text -> Maybe Text -> Maybe Text -> Maybe Text -> Maybe Bool -> Maybe Text -> Maybe AutoScalingType -> Maybe [Text] -> Maybe Architecture -> Maybe Text -> Text -> UpdateInstance

-- | Whether to install operating system and package updates when the
--   instance boots. The default value is <tt>true</tt>. To control when
--   updates are installed, set this value to <tt>false</tt>. You must then
--   update your instances manually by using CreateDeployment to run the
--   <tt>update_dependencies</tt> stack command or by manually running
--   <tt>yum</tt> (Amazon Linux) or <tt>apt-get</tt> (Ubuntu) on the
--   instances.
--   
--   We strongly recommend using the default value of <tt>true</tt>, to
--   ensure that your instances have the latest security updates.
[$sel:installUpdatesOnBoot:UpdateInstance'] :: UpdateInstance -> Maybe Bool

-- | The instance host name.
[$sel:hostname:UpdateInstance'] :: UpdateInstance -> Maybe Text

-- | The instance's Amazon EC2 key name.
[$sel:sshKeyName:UpdateInstance'] :: UpdateInstance -> Maybe Text

-- | The default AWS OpsWorks Stacks agent version. You have the following
--   options:
--   
--   <ul>
--   <li><tt>INHERIT</tt> - Use the stack's default agent version
--   setting.</li>
--   <li><i>version_number</i> - Use the specified agent version. This
--   value overrides the stack's default setting. To update the agent
--   version, you must edit the instance configuration and specify a new
--   version. AWS OpsWorks Stacks then automatically installs that version
--   on the instance.</li>
--   </ul>
--   
--   The default setting is <tt>INHERIT</tt>. To specify an agent version,
--   you must use the complete version number, not the abbreviated number
--   shown on the console. For a list of available agent version numbers,
--   call DescribeAgentVersions.
--   
--   AgentVersion cannot be set to Chef 12.2.
[$sel:agentVersion:UpdateInstance'] :: UpdateInstance -> Maybe Text

-- | The instance type, such as <tt>t2.micro</tt>. For a list of supported
--   instance types, open the stack in the console, choose
--   <b>Instances</b>, and choose <b>+ Instance</b>. The <b>Size</b> list
--   contains the currently supported types. For more information, see
--   <a>Instance Families and Types</a>. The parameter values that you use
--   to specify the various types are in the <b>API Name</b> column of the
--   <b>Available Instance Types</b> table.
[$sel:instanceType:UpdateInstance'] :: UpdateInstance -> Maybe Text

-- | This property cannot be updated.
[$sel:ebsOptimized:UpdateInstance'] :: UpdateInstance -> Maybe Bool

-- | The instance's operating system, which must be set to one of the
--   following. You cannot update an instance that is using a custom AMI.
--   
--   <ul>
--   <li>A supported Linux operating system: An Amazon Linux version, such
--   as <tt>Amazon Linux 2018.03</tt>, <tt>Amazon Linux 2017.09</tt>,
--   <tt>Amazon Linux 2017.03</tt>, <tt>Amazon Linux 2016.09</tt>,
--   <tt>Amazon Linux 2016.03</tt>, <tt>Amazon Linux 2015.09</tt>, or
--   <tt>Amazon Linux 2015.03</tt>.</li>
--   <li>A supported Ubuntu operating system, such as <tt>Ubuntu 16.04
--   LTS</tt>, <tt>Ubuntu 14.04 LTS</tt>, or <tt>Ubuntu 12.04
--   LTS</tt>.</li>
--   <li><pre>CentOS Linux 7</pre></li>
--   <li><pre>Red Hat Enterprise Linux 7</pre></li>
--   <li>A supported Windows operating system, such as <tt>Microsoft
--   Windows Server 2012 R2 Base</tt>, <tt>Microsoft Windows Server 2012 R2
--   with SQL Server Express</tt>, <tt>Microsoft Windows Server 2012 R2
--   with SQL Server Standard</tt>, or <tt>Microsoft Windows Server 2012 R2
--   with SQL Server Web</tt>.</li>
--   </ul>
--   
--   For more information about supported operating systems, see <a>AWS
--   OpsWorks Stacks Operating Systems</a>.
--   
--   The default option is the current Amazon Linux version. If you set
--   this parameter to <tt>Custom</tt>, you must use the AmiId parameter to
--   specify the custom AMI that you want to use. For more information
--   about supported operating systems, see <a>Operating Systems</a>. For
--   more information about how to use custom AMIs with OpsWorks, see
--   <a>Using Custom AMIs</a>.
--   
--   You can specify a different Linux operating system for the updated
--   stack, but you cannot change from Linux to Windows or Windows to
--   Linux.
[$sel:os:UpdateInstance'] :: UpdateInstance -> Maybe Text

-- | For load-based or time-based instances, the type. Windows stacks can
--   use only time-based instances.
[$sel:autoScalingType:UpdateInstance'] :: UpdateInstance -> Maybe AutoScalingType

-- | The instance's layer IDs.
[$sel:layerIds:UpdateInstance'] :: UpdateInstance -> Maybe [Text]

-- | The instance architecture. Instance types do not necessarily support
--   both architectures. For a list of the architectures that are supported
--   by the different instance types, see <a>Instance Families and
--   Types</a>.
[$sel:architecture:UpdateInstance'] :: UpdateInstance -> Maybe Architecture

-- | The ID of the AMI that was used to create the instance. The value of
--   this parameter must be the same AMI ID that the instance is already
--   using. You cannot apply a new AMI to an instance by running
--   UpdateInstance. UpdateInstance does not work on instances that are
--   using custom AMIs.
[$sel:amiId:UpdateInstance'] :: UpdateInstance -> Maybe Text

-- | The instance ID.
[$sel:instanceId:UpdateInstance'] :: UpdateInstance -> Text

-- | Create a value of <a>UpdateInstance</a> with all optional fields
--   omitted.
--   
--   Use <a>generic-lens</a> or <a>optics</a> to modify other optional
--   fields.
--   
--   The following record fields are available, with the corresponding
--   lenses provided for backwards compatibility:
--   
--   <a>$sel:installUpdatesOnBoot:UpdateInstance'</a>,
--   <a>updateInstance_installUpdatesOnBoot</a> - Whether to install
--   operating system and package updates when the instance boots. The
--   default value is <tt>true</tt>. To control when updates are installed,
--   set this value to <tt>false</tt>. You must then update your instances
--   manually by using CreateDeployment to run the
--   <tt>update_dependencies</tt> stack command or by manually running
--   <tt>yum</tt> (Amazon Linux) or <tt>apt-get</tt> (Ubuntu) on the
--   instances.
--   
--   We strongly recommend using the default value of <tt>true</tt>, to
--   ensure that your instances have the latest security updates.
--   
--   <a>$sel:hostname:UpdateInstance'</a>, <a>updateInstance_hostname</a> -
--   The instance host name.
--   
--   <a>$sel:sshKeyName:UpdateInstance'</a>,
--   <a>updateInstance_sshKeyName</a> - The instance's Amazon EC2 key name.
--   
--   <a>$sel:agentVersion:UpdateInstance'</a>,
--   <a>updateInstance_agentVersion</a> - The default AWS OpsWorks Stacks
--   agent version. You have the following options:
--   
--   <ul>
--   <li><tt>INHERIT</tt> - Use the stack's default agent version
--   setting.</li>
--   <li><i>version_number</i> - Use the specified agent version. This
--   value overrides the stack's default setting. To update the agent
--   version, you must edit the instance configuration and specify a new
--   version. AWS OpsWorks Stacks then automatically installs that version
--   on the instance.</li>
--   </ul>
--   
--   The default setting is <tt>INHERIT</tt>. To specify an agent version,
--   you must use the complete version number, not the abbreviated number
--   shown on the console. For a list of available agent version numbers,
--   call DescribeAgentVersions.
--   
--   AgentVersion cannot be set to Chef 12.2.
--   
--   <a>$sel:instanceType:UpdateInstance'</a>,
--   <a>updateInstance_instanceType</a> - The instance type, such as
--   <tt>t2.micro</tt>. For a list of supported instance types, open the
--   stack in the console, choose <b>Instances</b>, and choose <b>+
--   Instance</b>. The <b>Size</b> list contains the currently supported
--   types. For more information, see <a>Instance Families and Types</a>.
--   The parameter values that you use to specify the various types are in
--   the <b>API Name</b> column of the <b>Available Instance Types</b>
--   table.
--   
--   <a>$sel:ebsOptimized:UpdateInstance'</a>,
--   <a>updateInstance_ebsOptimized</a> - This property cannot be updated.
--   
--   <a>$sel:os:UpdateInstance'</a>, <a>updateInstance_os</a> - The
--   instance's operating system, which must be set to one of the
--   following. You cannot update an instance that is using a custom AMI.
--   
--   <ul>
--   <li>A supported Linux operating system: An Amazon Linux version, such
--   as <tt>Amazon Linux 2018.03</tt>, <tt>Amazon Linux 2017.09</tt>,
--   <tt>Amazon Linux 2017.03</tt>, <tt>Amazon Linux 2016.09</tt>,
--   <tt>Amazon Linux 2016.03</tt>, <tt>Amazon Linux 2015.09</tt>, or
--   <tt>Amazon Linux 2015.03</tt>.</li>
--   <li>A supported Ubuntu operating system, such as <tt>Ubuntu 16.04
--   LTS</tt>, <tt>Ubuntu 14.04 LTS</tt>, or <tt>Ubuntu 12.04
--   LTS</tt>.</li>
--   <li><pre>CentOS Linux 7</pre></li>
--   <li><pre>Red Hat Enterprise Linux 7</pre></li>
--   <li>A supported Windows operating system, such as <tt>Microsoft
--   Windows Server 2012 R2 Base</tt>, <tt>Microsoft Windows Server 2012 R2
--   with SQL Server Express</tt>, <tt>Microsoft Windows Server 2012 R2
--   with SQL Server Standard</tt>, or <tt>Microsoft Windows Server 2012 R2
--   with SQL Server Web</tt>.</li>
--   </ul>
--   
--   For more information about supported operating systems, see <a>AWS
--   OpsWorks Stacks Operating Systems</a>.
--   
--   The default option is the current Amazon Linux version. If you set
--   this parameter to <tt>Custom</tt>, you must use the AmiId parameter to
--   specify the custom AMI that you want to use. For more information
--   about supported operating systems, see <a>Operating Systems</a>. For
--   more information about how to use custom AMIs with OpsWorks, see
--   <a>Using Custom AMIs</a>.
--   
--   You can specify a different Linux operating system for the updated
--   stack, but you cannot change from Linux to Windows or Windows to
--   Linux.
--   
--   <a>$sel:autoScalingType:UpdateInstance'</a>,
--   <a>updateInstance_autoScalingType</a> - For load-based or time-based
--   instances, the type. Windows stacks can use only time-based instances.
--   
--   <a>$sel:layerIds:UpdateInstance'</a>, <a>updateInstance_layerIds</a> -
--   The instance's layer IDs.
--   
--   <a>$sel:architecture:UpdateInstance'</a>,
--   <a>updateInstance_architecture</a> - The instance architecture.
--   Instance types do not necessarily support both architectures. For a
--   list of the architectures that are supported by the different instance
--   types, see <a>Instance Families and Types</a>.
--   
--   <a>$sel:amiId:UpdateInstance'</a>, <a>updateInstance_amiId</a> - The
--   ID of the AMI that was used to create the instance. The value of this
--   parameter must be the same AMI ID that the instance is already using.
--   You cannot apply a new AMI to an instance by running UpdateInstance.
--   UpdateInstance does not work on instances that are using custom AMIs.
--   
--   <a>$sel:instanceId:UpdateInstance'</a>,
--   <a>updateInstance_instanceId</a> - The instance ID.
newUpdateInstance :: Text -> UpdateInstance

-- | Whether to install operating system and package updates when the
--   instance boots. The default value is <tt>true</tt>. To control when
--   updates are installed, set this value to <tt>false</tt>. You must then
--   update your instances manually by using CreateDeployment to run the
--   <tt>update_dependencies</tt> stack command or by manually running
--   <tt>yum</tt> (Amazon Linux) or <tt>apt-get</tt> (Ubuntu) on the
--   instances.
--   
--   We strongly recommend using the default value of <tt>true</tt>, to
--   ensure that your instances have the latest security updates.
updateInstance_installUpdatesOnBoot :: Lens' UpdateInstance (Maybe Bool)

-- | The instance host name.
updateInstance_hostname :: Lens' UpdateInstance (Maybe Text)

-- | The instance's Amazon EC2 key name.
updateInstance_sshKeyName :: Lens' UpdateInstance (Maybe Text)

-- | The default AWS OpsWorks Stacks agent version. You have the following
--   options:
--   
--   <ul>
--   <li><tt>INHERIT</tt> - Use the stack's default agent version
--   setting.</li>
--   <li><i>version_number</i> - Use the specified agent version. This
--   value overrides the stack's default setting. To update the agent
--   version, you must edit the instance configuration and specify a new
--   version. AWS OpsWorks Stacks then automatically installs that version
--   on the instance.</li>
--   </ul>
--   
--   The default setting is <tt>INHERIT</tt>. To specify an agent version,
--   you must use the complete version number, not the abbreviated number
--   shown on the console. For a list of available agent version numbers,
--   call DescribeAgentVersions.
--   
--   AgentVersion cannot be set to Chef 12.2.
updateInstance_agentVersion :: Lens' UpdateInstance (Maybe Text)

-- | The instance type, such as <tt>t2.micro</tt>. For a list of supported
--   instance types, open the stack in the console, choose
--   <b>Instances</b>, and choose <b>+ Instance</b>. The <b>Size</b> list
--   contains the currently supported types. For more information, see
--   <a>Instance Families and Types</a>. The parameter values that you use
--   to specify the various types are in the <b>API Name</b> column of the
--   <b>Available Instance Types</b> table.
updateInstance_instanceType :: Lens' UpdateInstance (Maybe Text)

-- | This property cannot be updated.
updateInstance_ebsOptimized :: Lens' UpdateInstance (Maybe Bool)

-- | The instance's operating system, which must be set to one of the
--   following. You cannot update an instance that is using a custom AMI.
--   
--   <ul>
--   <li>A supported Linux operating system: An Amazon Linux version, such
--   as <tt>Amazon Linux 2018.03</tt>, <tt>Amazon Linux 2017.09</tt>,
--   <tt>Amazon Linux 2017.03</tt>, <tt>Amazon Linux 2016.09</tt>,
--   <tt>Amazon Linux 2016.03</tt>, <tt>Amazon Linux 2015.09</tt>, or
--   <tt>Amazon Linux 2015.03</tt>.</li>

--   more information about how to use custom AMIs with OpsWorks, see
--   <a>Using Custom AMIs</a>.
--   
--   You can specify a different Linux operating system for the updated
--   stack, but you cannot change from Linux to Windows or Windows to
--   Linux.
updateInstance_os :: Lens' UpdateInstance (Maybe Text)

--   use only time-based instances.
updateInstance_autoScalingType :: Lens' UpdateInstance (Maybe AutoScalingType)

-- | Updates a specified layer.
--   
--   <b>Required Permissions</b>: To use this action, an IAM user must have
--   a Manage permissions level for the stack, or an attached policy that
--   explicitly grants permissions. For more information on user
--   permissions, see <a>Managing User Permissions</a>.
module Network.AWS.OpsWorks.UpdateLayer

-- | <i>See:</i> <a>newUpdateLayer</a> smart constructor.
data UpdateLayer
UpdateLayer' :: Maybe Text -> Maybe [Text] -> Maybe Bool -> Maybe CloudWatchLogsConfiguration -> Maybe LifecycleEventConfiguration -> Maybe Text -> Maybe Recipes -> Maybe Text -> Maybe [VolumeConfiguration] -> Maybe Bool -> Maybe [Text] -> Maybe (HashMap LayerAttributesKeys (Maybe Text)) -> Maybe Text -> Maybe Bool -> Maybe Bool -> Maybe Bool -> Text -> UpdateLayer

-- | The ARN of an IAM profile to be used for all of the layer's EC2
--   instances. For more information about IAM ARNs, see <a>Using
--   Identifiers</a>.
[$sel:customInstanceProfileArn:UpdateLayer'] :: UpdateLayer -> Maybe Text

-- | An array containing the layer's custom security group IDs.
[$sel:customSecurityGroupIds:UpdateLayer'] :: UpdateLayer -> Maybe [Text]

-- | Whether to install operating system and package updates when the
--   instance boots. The default value is <tt>true</tt>. To control when
--   updates are installed, set this value to <tt>false</tt>. You must then
--   update your instances manually by using CreateDeployment to run the
--   <tt>update_dependencies</tt> stack command or manually running
--   <tt>yum</tt> (Amazon Linux) or <tt>apt-get</tt> (Ubuntu) on the
--   instances.
--   
--   We strongly recommend using the default value of <tt>true</tt>, to
--   ensure that your instances have the latest security updates.
[$sel:installUpdatesOnBoot:UpdateLayer'] :: UpdateLayer -> Maybe Bool

-- | Specifies CloudWatch Logs configuration options for the layer. For
--   more information, see CloudWatchLogsLogStream.
[$sel:cloudWatchLogsConfiguration:UpdateLayer'] :: UpdateLayer -> Maybe CloudWatchLogsConfiguration
[$sel:lifecycleEventConfiguration:UpdateLayer'] :: UpdateLayer -> Maybe LifecycleEventConfiguration

-- | For custom layers only, use this parameter to specify the layer's
--   short name, which is used internally by AWS OpsWorks Stacks and by
--   Chef. The short name is also used as the name for the directory where
--   your app files are installed. It can have a maximum of 200 characters
--   and must be in the following format: /\A[a-z0-9\-\_\.]+\Z/.
--   
--   The built-in layers' short names are defined by AWS OpsWorks Stacks.
--   For more information, see the <a>Layer Reference</a>
[$sel:shortname:UpdateLayer'] :: UpdateLayer -> Maybe Text

-- | A <tt>LayerCustomRecipes</tt> object that specifies the layer's custom
--   recipes.
[$sel:customRecipes:UpdateLayer'] :: UpdateLayer -> Maybe Recipes

-- | A JSON-formatted string containing custom stack configuration and
--   deployment attributes to be installed on the layer's instances. For
--   more information, see <a>Using Custom JSON</a>.
[$sel:customJson:UpdateLayer'] :: UpdateLayer -> Maybe Text

-- | A <tt>VolumeConfigurations</tt> object that describes the layer's
--   Amazon EBS volumes.
[$sel:volumeConfigurations:UpdateLayer'] :: UpdateLayer -> Maybe [VolumeConfiguration]

-- | Whether to disable auto healing for the layer.
[$sel:enableAutoHealing:UpdateLayer'] :: UpdateLayer -> Maybe Bool

-- | An array of <tt>Package</tt> objects that describe the layer's
--   packages.
[$sel:packages:UpdateLayer'] :: UpdateLayer -> Maybe [Text]

-- | One or more user-defined key/value pairs to be added to the stack
--   attributes.
[$sel:attributes:UpdateLayer'] :: UpdateLayer -> Maybe (HashMap LayerAttributesKeys (Maybe Text))

-- | The layer name, which is used by the console.
[$sel:name:UpdateLayer'] :: UpdateLayer -> Maybe Text

-- | For stacks that are running in a VPC, whether to automatically assign
--   a public IP address to the layer's instances. For more information,
--   see <a>How to Edit a Layer</a>.
[$sel:autoAssignPublicIps:UpdateLayer'] :: UpdateLayer -> Maybe Bool

-- | Whether to use Amazon EBS-optimized instances.
[$sel:useEbsOptimizedInstances:UpdateLayer'] :: UpdateLayer -> Maybe Bool

-- | Whether to automatically assign an <a>Elastic IP address</a> to the
--   layer's instances. For more information, see <a>How to Edit a
--   Layer</a>.
[$sel:autoAssignElasticIps:UpdateLayer'] :: UpdateLayer -> Maybe Bool

-- | The layer ID.
[$sel:layerId:UpdateLayer'] :: UpdateLayer -> Text

-- | Create a value of <a>UpdateLayer</a> with all optional fields omitted.
--   
--   Use <a>generic-lens</a> or <a>optics</a> to modify other optional
--   fields.
--   
--   The following record fields are available, with the corresponding
--   lenses provided for backwards compatibility:
--   
--   <a>$sel:customInstanceProfileArn:UpdateLayer'</a>,
--   <a>updateLayer_customInstanceProfileArn</a> - The ARN of an IAM
--   profile to be used for all of the layer's EC2 instances. For more
--   information about IAM ARNs, see <a>Using Identifiers</a>.
--   
--   <a>$sel:customSecurityGroupIds:UpdateLayer'</a>,
--   <a>updateLayer_customSecurityGroupIds</a> - An array containing the
--   layer's custom security group IDs.
--   
--   <a>$sel:installUpdatesOnBoot:UpdateLayer'</a>,
--   <a>updateLayer_installUpdatesOnBoot</a> - Whether to install operating
--   system and package updates when the instance boots. The default value
--   is <tt>true</tt>. To control when updates are installed, set this
--   value to <tt>false</tt>. You must then update your instances manually
--   by using CreateDeployment to run the <tt>update_dependencies</tt>
--   stack command or manually running <tt>yum</tt> (Amazon Linux) or
--   <tt>apt-get</tt> (Ubuntu) on the instances.
--   
--   We strongly recommend using the default value of <tt>true</tt>, to
--   ensure that your instances have the latest security updates.
--   
--   <a>$sel:cloudWatchLogsConfiguration:UpdateLayer'</a>,
--   <a>updateLayer_cloudWatchLogsConfiguration</a> - Specifies CloudWatch
--   Logs configuration options for the layer. For more information, see
--   CloudWatchLogsLogStream.
--   
--   <a>$sel:lifecycleEventConfiguration:UpdateLayer'</a>,
--   <a>updateLayer_lifecycleEventConfiguration</a> -
--   
--   <a>$sel:shortname:UpdateLayer'</a>, <a>updateLayer_shortname</a> - For
--   custom layers only, use this parameter to specify the layer's short
--   name, which is used internally by AWS OpsWorks Stacks and by Chef. The
--   short name is also used as the name for the directory where your app
--   files are installed. It can have a maximum of 200 characters and must
--   be in the following format: /\A[a-z0-9\-\_\.]+\Z/.
--   
--   The built-in layers' short names are defined by AWS OpsWorks Stacks.
--   For more information, see the <a>Layer Reference</a>
--   
--   <a>$sel:customRecipes:UpdateLayer'</a>,
--   <a>updateLayer_customRecipes</a> - A <tt>LayerCustomRecipes</tt>
--   object that specifies the layer's custom recipes.
--   
--   <a>$sel:customJson:UpdateLayer'</a>, <a>updateLayer_customJson</a> - A
--   JSON-formatted string containing custom stack configuration and
--   deployment attributes to be installed on the layer's instances. For
--   more information, see <a>Using Custom JSON</a>.
--   
--   <a>$sel:volumeConfigurations:UpdateLayer'</a>,
--   <a>updateLayer_volumeConfigurations</a> - A
--   <tt>VolumeConfigurations</tt> object that describes the layer's Amazon
--   EBS volumes.
--   
--   <a>$sel:enableAutoHealing:UpdateLayer'</a>,
--   <a>updateLayer_enableAutoHealing</a> - Whether to disable auto healing
--   for the layer.
--   
--   <a>$sel:packages:UpdateLayer'</a>, <a>updateLayer_packages</a> - An
--   array of <tt>Package</tt> objects that describe the layer's packages.
--   
--   <a>$sel:attributes:UpdateLayer'</a>, <a>updateLayer_attributes</a> -
--   One or more user-defined key/value pairs to be added to the stack
--   attributes.
--   
--   <a>$sel:name:UpdateLayer'</a>, <a>updateLayer_name</a> - The layer
--   name, which is used by the console.
--   
--   <a>$sel:autoAssignPublicIps:UpdateLayer'</a>,
--   <a>updateLayer_autoAssignPublicIps</a> - For stacks that are running
--   in a VPC, whether to automatically assign a public IP address to the
--   layer's instances. For more information, see <a>How to Edit a
--   Layer</a>.
--   
--   <a>$sel:useEbsOptimizedInstances:UpdateLayer'</a>,
--   <a>updateLayer_useEbsOptimizedInstances</a> - Whether to use Amazon
--   EBS-optimized instances.
--   
--   <a>$sel:autoAssignElasticIps:UpdateLayer'</a>,
--   <a>updateLayer_autoAssignElasticIps</a> - Whether to automatically
--   assign an <a>Elastic IP address</a> to the layer's instances. For more
--   information, see <a>How to Edit a Layer</a>.
--   
--   <a>$sel:layerId:UpdateLayer'</a>, <a>updateLayer_layerId</a> - The
--   layer ID.
newUpdateLayer :: Text -> UpdateLayer

-- | The ARN of an IAM profile to be used for all of the layer's EC2
--   instances. For more information about IAM ARNs, see <a>Using
--   Identifiers</a>.
updateLayer_customInstanceProfileArn :: Lens' UpdateLayer (Maybe Text)

-- | An array containing the layer's custom security group IDs.
updateLayer_customSecurityGroupIds :: Lens' UpdateLayer (Maybe [Text])

-- | Whether to install operating system and package updates when the
--   instance boots. The default value is <tt>true</tt>. To control when
--   updates are installed, set this value to <tt>false</tt>. You must then
--   update your instances manually by using CreateDeployment to run the
--   <tt>update_dependencies</tt> stack command or manually running
--   <tt>yum</tt> (Amazon Linux) or <tt>apt-get</tt> (Ubuntu) on the
--   instances.
--   
--   We strongly recommend using the default value of <tt>true</tt>, to
--   ensure that your instances have the latest security updates.
updateLayer_installUpdatesOnBoot :: Lens' UpdateLayer (Maybe Bool)

-- | Specifies CloudWatch Logs configuration options for the layer. For
--   more information, see CloudWatchLogsLogStream.
updateLayer_cloudWatchLogsConfiguration :: Lens' UpdateLayer (Maybe CloudWatchLogsConfiguration)

updateLayer_lifecycleEventConfiguration :: Lens' UpdateLayer (Maybe LifecycleEventConfiguration)

-- | For custom layers only, use this parameter to specify the layer's
--   short name, which is used internally by AWS OpsWorks Stacks and by
--   Chef. The short name is also used as the name for the directory where
--   your app files are installed. It can have a maximum of 200 characters
--   and must be in the following format: /\A[a-z0-9\-\_\.]+\Z/.
--   
--   The built-in layers' short names are defined by AWS OpsWorks Stacks.
--   For more information, see the <a>Layer Reference</a>
updateLayer_shortname :: Lens' UpdateLayer (Maybe Text)

-- | A <tt>LayerCustomRecipes</tt> object that specifies the layer's custom
--   recipes.
updateLayer_customRecipes :: Lens' UpdateLayer (Maybe Recipes)

-- | A JSON-formatted string containing custom stack configuration and
--   deployment attributes to be installed on the layer's instances. For
--   more information, see <a>Using Custom JSON</a>.
updateLayer_customJson :: Lens' UpdateLayer (Maybe Text)

-- | A <tt>VolumeConfigurations</tt> object that describes the layer's
--   Amazon EBS volumes.
updateLayer_volumeConfigurations :: Lens' UpdateLayer (Maybe [VolumeConfiguration])

-- | Whether to disable auto healing for the layer.
updateLayer_enableAutoHealing :: Lens' UpdateLayer (Maybe Bool)

-- | An array of <tt>Package</tt> objects that describe the layer's
--   packages.
updateLayer_packages :: Lens' UpdateLayer (Maybe [Text])

-- | One or more user-defined key/value pairs to be added to the stack
--   attributes.
updateLayer_attributes :: Lens' UpdateLayer (Maybe (HashMap LayerAttributesKeys (Maybe Text)))

-- | The layer name, which is used by the console.
updateLayer_name :: Lens' UpdateLayer (Maybe Text)

-- | For stacks that are running in a VPC, whether to automatically assign
--   a public IP address to the layer's instances. For more information,
--   see <a>How to Edit a Layer</a>.
updateLayer_autoAssignPublicIps :: Lens' UpdateLayer (Maybe Bool)

-- | Whether to use Amazon EBS-optimized instances.
updateLayer_useEbsOptimizedInstances :: Lens' UpdateLayer (Maybe Bool)

-- | Whether to automatically assign an <a>Elastic IP address</a> to the
--   layer's instances. For more information, see <a>How to Edit a
--   Layer</a>.
updateLayer_autoAssignElasticIps :: Lens' UpdateLayer (Maybe Bool)

-- | The layer ID.
updateLayer_layerId :: Lens' UpdateLayer Text

-- | Updates an Amazon RDS instance.

-- | Updates a specified stack.
--   
--   <b>Required Permissions</b>: To use this action, an IAM user must have
--   a Manage permissions level for the stack, or an attached policy that
--   explicitly grants permissions. For more information on user
--   permissions, see <a>Managing User Permissions</a>.
module Network.AWS.OpsWorks.UpdateStack

-- | <i>See:</i> <a>newUpdateStack</a> smart constructor.
data UpdateStack
UpdateStack' :: Maybe Text -> Maybe Text -> Maybe RootDeviceType -> Maybe ChefConfiguration -> Maybe Text -> Maybe Text -> Maybe Text -> Maybe Source -> Maybe Text -> Maybe (HashMap StackAttributesKeys (Maybe Text)) -> Maybe Text -> Maybe Text -> Maybe Bool -> Maybe Bool -> Maybe Text -> Maybe StackConfigurationManager -> Maybe Text -> Text -> UpdateStack

-- | The ARN of an IAM profile that is the default profile for all of the
--   stack's EC2 instances. For more information about IAM ARNs, see
--   <a>Using Identifiers</a>.
[$sel:defaultInstanceProfileArn:UpdateStack'] :: UpdateStack -> Maybe Text

-- | Do not use this parameter. You cannot update a stack's service role.
[$sel:serviceRoleArn:UpdateStack'] :: UpdateStack -> Maybe Text

-- | The default root device type. This value is used by default for all
--   instances in the stack, but you can override it when you create an
--   instance. For more information, see <a>Storage for the Root
--   Device</a>.
[$sel:defaultRootDeviceType:UpdateStack'] :: UpdateStack -> Maybe RootDeviceType

-- | A <tt>ChefConfiguration</tt> object that specifies whether to enable
--   Berkshelf and the Berkshelf version on Chef 11.10 stacks. For more
--   information, see <a>Create a New Stack</a>.
[$sel:chefConfiguration:UpdateStack'] :: UpdateStack -> Maybe ChefConfiguration

-- | The default AWS OpsWorks Stacks agent version. You have the following
--   options:
--   
--   <ul>
--   <li>Auto-update - Set this parameter to <tt>LATEST</tt>. AWS OpsWorks
--   Stacks automatically installs new agent versions on the stack's
--   instances as soon as they are available.</li>
--   <li>Fixed version - Set this parameter to your preferred agent
--   version. To update the agent version, you must edit the stack
--   configuration and specify a new version. AWS OpsWorks Stacks then
--   automatically installs that version on the stack's instances.</li>
--   </ul>
--   
--   The default setting is <tt>LATEST</tt>. To specify an agent version,
--   you must use the complete version number, not the abbreviated number
--   shown on the console. For a list of available agent version numbers,
--   call DescribeAgentVersions. AgentVersion cannot be set to Chef 12.2.
--   
--   You can also specify an agent version when you create or update an
--   instance, which overrides the stack's default setting.
[$sel:agentVersion:UpdateStack'] :: UpdateStack -> Maybe Text

-- | A default Amazon EC2 key-pair name. The default value is
--   <tt>none</tt>. If you specify a key-pair name, AWS OpsWorks Stacks
--   installs the public key on the instance and you can use the private
--   key with an SSH client to log in to the instance. For more
--   information, see <a>Using SSH to Communicate with an Instance</a> and
--   <a>Managing SSH Access</a>. You can override this setting by
--   specifying a different key pair, or no key pair, when you <a>create an
--   instance</a>.
[$sel:defaultSshKeyName:UpdateStack'] :: UpdateStack -> Maybe Text

-- | A string that contains user-defined, custom JSON. It can be used to
--   override the corresponding default stack configuration JSON values or
--   to pass data to recipes. The string should be in the following format:
--   
--   <pre>
--   "{\"key1\": \"value1\", \"key2\": \"value2\",...}"
--   </pre>
--   
--   For more information about custom JSON, see <a>Use Custom JSON to
--   Modify the Stack Configuration Attributes</a>.
[$sel:customJson:UpdateStack'] :: UpdateStack -> Maybe Text

-- | Contains the information required to retrieve an app or cookbook from
--   a repository. For more information, see <a>Adding Apps</a> or
--   <a>Cookbooks and Recipes</a>.
[$sel:customCookbooksSource:UpdateStack'] :: UpdateStack -> Maybe Source

-- | The stack's default Availability Zone, which must be in the stack's
--   region. For more information, see <a>Regions and Endpoints</a>. If you
--   also specify a value for <tt>DefaultSubnetId</tt>, the subnet must be
--   in the same zone. For more information, see CreateStack.
[$sel:defaultAvailabilityZone:UpdateStack'] :: UpdateStack -> Maybe Text

-- | One or more user-defined key-value pairs to be added to the stack
--   attributes.
[$sel:attributes:UpdateStack'] :: UpdateStack -> Maybe (HashMap StackAttributesKeys (Maybe Text))

-- | The stack's new name.
[$sel:name:UpdateStack'] :: UpdateStack -> Maybe Text

-- | The stack's operating system, which must be set to one of the
--   following:
--   
--   <ul>
--   <li>A supported Linux operating system: An Amazon Linux version, such
--   as <tt>Amazon Linux 2018.03</tt>, <tt>Amazon Linux 2017.09</tt>,
--   <tt>Amazon Linux 2017.03</tt>, <tt>Amazon Linux 2016.09</tt>,
--   <tt>Amazon Linux 2016.03</tt>, <tt>Amazon Linux 2015.09</tt>, or
--   <tt>Amazon Linux 2015.03</tt>.</li>
--   <li>A supported Ubuntu operating system, such as <tt>Ubuntu 16.04
--   LTS</tt>, <tt>Ubuntu 14.04 LTS</tt>, or <tt>Ubuntu 12.04
--   LTS</tt>.</li>
--   <li><pre>CentOS Linux 7</pre></li>
--   <li><pre>Red Hat Enterprise Linux 7</pre></li>
--   <li>A supported Windows operating system, such as <tt>Microsoft
--   Windows Server 2012 R2 Base</tt>, <tt>Microsoft Windows Server 2012 R2
--   with SQL Server Express</tt>, <tt>Microsoft Windows Server 2012 R2
--   with SQL Server Standard</tt>, or <tt>Microsoft Windows Server 2012 R2
--   with SQL Server Web</tt>.</li>
--   <li>A custom AMI: <tt>Custom</tt>. You specify the custom AMI you want
--   to use when you create instances. For more information about how to
--   use custom AMIs with OpsWorks, see <a>Using Custom AMIs</a>.</li>
--   </ul>
--   
--   The default option is the stack's current operating system. For more
--   information about supported operating systems, see <a>AWS OpsWorks
--   Stacks Operating Systems</a>.
[$sel:defaultOs:UpdateStack'] :: UpdateStack -> Maybe Text

-- | Whether to associate the AWS OpsWorks Stacks built-in security groups
--   with the stack's layers.
--   
--   AWS OpsWorks Stacks provides a standard set of built-in security
--   groups, one for each layer, which are associated with layers by
--   default. <tt>UseOpsworksSecurityGroups</tt> allows you to provide your
--   own custom security groups instead of using the built-in groups.
--   <tt>UseOpsworksSecurityGroups</tt> has the following settings:
--   
--   <ul>
--   <li>True - AWS OpsWorks Stacks automatically associates the
--   appropriate built-in security group with each layer (default setting).
--   You can associate additional security groups with a layer after you
--   create it, but you cannot delete the built-in security group.</li>
--   <li>False - AWS OpsWorks Stacks does not associate built-in security
--   groups with layers. You must create appropriate EC2 security groups
--   and associate a security group with each layer that you create.
--   However, you can still manually associate a built-in security group
--   with a layer on. Custom security groups are required only for those
--   layers that need custom settings.</li>
--   </ul>
--   
--   For more information, see <a>Create a New Stack</a>.
[$sel:useOpsworksSecurityGroups:UpdateStack'] :: UpdateStack -> Maybe Bool

-- | Whether the stack uses custom cookbooks.
[$sel:useCustomCookbooks:UpdateStack'] :: UpdateStack -> Maybe Bool

-- | The stack's default VPC subnet ID. This parameter is required if you
--   specify a value for the <tt>VpcId</tt> parameter. All instances are
--   launched into this subnet unless you specify otherwise when you create
--   the instance. If you also specify a value for
--   <tt>DefaultAvailabilityZone</tt>, the subnet must be in that zone. For
--   information on default values and when this parameter is required, see
--   the <tt>VpcId</tt> parameter description.
[$sel:defaultSubnetId:UpdateStack'] :: UpdateStack -> Maybe Text

-- | The configuration manager. When you update a stack, we recommend that
--   you use the configuration manager to specify the Chef version: 12,
--   11.10, or 11.4 for Linux stacks, or 12.2 for Windows stacks. The
--   default value for Linux stacks is currently 12.
[$sel:configurationManager:UpdateStack'] :: UpdateStack -> Maybe StackConfigurationManager

-- | The stack's new host name theme, with spaces replaced by underscores.
--   The theme is used to generate host names for the stack's instances. By
--   default, <tt>HostnameTheme</tt> is set to <tt>Layer_Dependent</tt>,
--   which creates host names by appending integers to the layer's short
--   name. The other themes are:
--   
--   <ul>
--   <li><pre>Baked_Goods</pre></li>
--   <li><pre>Clouds</pre></li>
--   <li><pre>Europe_Cities</pre></li>
--   <li><pre>Fruits</pre></li>
--   <li><pre>Greek_Deities_and_Titans</pre></li>
--   <li><pre>Legendary_creatures_from_Japan</pre></li>
--   <li><pre>Planets_and_Moons</pre></li>
--   <li><pre>Roman_Deities</pre></li>
--   <li><pre>Scottish_Islands</pre></li>
--   <li><pre>US_Cities</pre></li>
--   <li><pre>Wild_Cats</pre></li>
--   </ul>
--   
--   To obtain a generated host name, call <tt>GetHostNameSuggestion</tt>,
--   which returns a host name based on the current theme.
[$sel:hostnameTheme:UpdateStack'] :: UpdateStack -> Maybe Text

-- | The stack ID.
[$sel:stackId:UpdateStack'] :: UpdateStack -> Text

-- | Create a value of <a>UpdateStack</a> with all optional fields omitted.
--   
--   Use <a>generic-lens</a> or <a>optics</a> to modify other optional
--   fields.
--   
--   The following record fields are available, with the corresponding
--   lenses provided for backwards compatibility:
--   
--   <a>$sel:defaultInstanceProfileArn:UpdateStack'</a>,
--   <a>updateStack_defaultInstanceProfileArn</a> - The ARN of an IAM
--   profile that is the default profile for all of the stack's EC2
--   instances. For more information about IAM ARNs, see <a>Using
--   Identifiers</a>.
--   
--   <a>$sel:serviceRoleArn:UpdateStack'</a>,
--   <a>updateStack_serviceRoleArn</a> - Do not use this parameter. You
--   cannot update a stack's service role.
--   
--   <a>$sel:defaultRootDeviceType:UpdateStack'</a>,
--   <a>updateStack_defaultRootDeviceType</a> - The default root device
--   type. This value is used by default for all instances in the stack,
--   but you can override it when you create an instance. For more
--   information, see <a>Storage for the Root Device</a>.
--   
--   <a>$sel:chefConfiguration:UpdateStack'</a>,
--   <a>updateStack_chefConfiguration</a> - A <tt>ChefConfiguration</tt>
--   object that specifies whether to enable Berkshelf and the Berkshelf
--   version on Chef 11.10 stacks. For more information, see <a>Create a
--   New Stack</a>.
--   
--   <a>$sel:agentVersion:UpdateStack'</a>, <a>updateStack_agentVersion</a>
--   - The default AWS OpsWorks Stacks agent version. You have the
--   following options:
--   
--   <ul>
--   <li>Auto-update - Set this parameter to <tt>LATEST</tt>. AWS OpsWorks
--   Stacks automatically installs new agent versions on the stack's
--   instances as soon as they are available.</li>
--   <li>Fixed version - Set this parameter to your preferred agent
--   version. To update the agent version, you must edit the stack
--   configuration and specify a new version. AWS OpsWorks Stacks then
--   automatically installs that version on the stack's instances.</li>
--   </ul>
--   
--   The default setting is <tt>LATEST</tt>. To specify an agent version,
--   you must use the complete version number, not the abbreviated number
--   shown on the console. For a list of available agent version numbers,
--   call DescribeAgentVersions. AgentVersion cannot be set to Chef 12.2.
--   
--   You can also specify an agent version when you create or update an
--   instance, which overrides the stack's default setting.
--   
--   <a>$sel:defaultSshKeyName:UpdateStack'</a>,
--   <a>updateStack_defaultSshKeyName</a> - A default Amazon EC2 key-pair
--   name. The default value is <tt>none</tt>. If you specify a key-pair
--   name, AWS OpsWorks Stacks installs the public key on the instance and
--   you can use the private key with an SSH client to log in to the
--   instance. For more information, see <a>Using SSH to Communicate with
--   an Instance</a> and <a>Managing SSH Access</a>. You can override this
--   setting by specifying a different key pair, or no key pair, when you
--   <a>create an instance</a>.
--   
--   <a>$sel:customJson:UpdateStack'</a>, <a>updateStack_customJson</a> - A
--   string that contains user-defined, custom JSON. It can be used to
--   override the corresponding default stack configuration JSON values or
--   to pass data to recipes. The string should be in the following format:
--   
--   <pre>
--   "{\"key1\": \"value1\", \"key2\": \"value2\",...}"
--   </pre>
--   
--   For more information about custom JSON, see <a>Use Custom JSON to
--   Modify the Stack Configuration Attributes</a>.
--   
--   <a>$sel:customCookbooksSource:UpdateStack'</a>,
--   <a>updateStack_customCookbooksSource</a> - Contains the information
--   required to retrieve an app or cookbook from a repository. For more
--   information, see <a>Adding Apps</a> or <a>Cookbooks and Recipes</a>.
--   
--   <a>$sel:defaultAvailabilityZone:UpdateStack'</a>,
--   <a>updateStack_defaultAvailabilityZone</a> - The stack's default
--   Availability Zone, which must be in the stack's region. For more
--   information, see <a>Regions and Endpoints</a>. If you also specify a
--   value for <tt>DefaultSubnetId</tt>, the subnet must be in the same
--   zone. For more information, see CreateStack.
--   
--   <a>$sel:attributes:UpdateStack'</a>, <a>updateStack_attributes</a> -
--   One or more user-defined key-value pairs to be added to the stack
--   attributes.
--   
--   <a>$sel:name:UpdateStack'</a>, <a>updateStack_name</a> - The stack's
--   new name.
--   
--   <a>$sel:defaultOs:UpdateStack'</a>, <a>updateStack_defaultOs</a> - The
--   stack's operating system, which must be set to one of the following:
--   
--   <ul>
--   <li>A supported Linux operating system: An Amazon Linux version, such
--   as <tt>Amazon Linux 2018.03</tt>, <tt>Amazon Linux 2017.09</tt>,
--   <tt>Amazon Linux 2017.03</tt>, <tt>Amazon Linux 2016.09</tt>,
--   <tt>Amazon Linux 2016.03</tt>, <tt>Amazon Linux 2015.09</tt>, or
--   <tt>Amazon Linux 2015.03</tt>.</li>
--   <li>A supported Ubuntu operating system, such as <tt>Ubuntu 16.04
--   LTS</tt>, <tt>Ubuntu 14.04 LTS</tt>, or <tt>Ubuntu 12.04
--   LTS</tt>.</li>
--   <li><pre>CentOS Linux 7</pre></li>
--   <li><pre>Red Hat Enterprise Linux 7</pre></li>
--   <li>A supported Windows operating system, such as <tt>Microsoft
--   Windows Server 2012 R2 Base</tt>, <tt>Microsoft Windows Server 2012 R2
--   with SQL Server Express</tt>, <tt>Microsoft Windows Server 2012 R2
--   with SQL Server Standard</tt>, or <tt>Microsoft Windows Server 2012 R2
--   with SQL Server Web</tt>.</li>
--   <li>A custom AMI: <tt>Custom</tt>. You specify the custom AMI you want
--   to use when you create instances. For more information about how to
--   use custom AMIs with OpsWorks, see <a>Using Custom AMIs</a>.</li>
--   </ul>
--   
--   The default option is the stack's current operating system. For more
--   information about supported operating systems, see <a>AWS OpsWorks
--   Stacks Operating Systems</a>.
--   
--   <a>$sel:useOpsworksSecurityGroups:UpdateStack'</a>,
--   <a>updateStack_useOpsworksSecurityGroups</a> - Whether to associate
--   the AWS OpsWorks Stacks built-in security groups with the stack's
--   layers.
--   
--   AWS OpsWorks Stacks provides a standard set of built-in security
--   groups, one for each layer, which are associated with layers by
--   default. <tt>UseOpsworksSecurityGroups</tt> allows you to provide your
--   own custom security groups instead of using the built-in groups.
--   <tt>UseOpsworksSecurityGroups</tt> has the following settings:
--   
--   <ul>
--   <li>True - AWS OpsWorks Stacks automatically associates the
--   appropriate built-in security group with each layer (default setting).
--   You can associate additional security groups with a layer after you
--   create it, but you cannot delete the built-in security group.</li>
--   <li>False - AWS OpsWorks Stacks does not associate built-in security
--   groups with layers. You must create appropriate EC2 security groups
--   and associate a security group with each layer that you create.
--   However, you can still manually associate a built-in security group
--   with a layer on. Custom security groups are required only for those
--   layers that need custom settings.</li>
--   </ul>
--   
--   For more information, see <a>Create a New Stack</a>.
--   
--   <a>$sel:useCustomCookbooks:UpdateStack'</a>,
--   <a>updateStack_useCustomCookbooks</a> - Whether the stack uses custom
--   cookbooks.
--   
--   <a>$sel:defaultSubnetId:UpdateStack'</a>,
--   <a>updateStack_defaultSubnetId</a> - The stack's default VPC subnet
--   ID. This parameter is required if you specify a value for the
--   <tt>VpcId</tt> parameter. All instances are launched into this subnet
--   unless you specify otherwise when you create the instance. If you also
--   specify a value for <tt>DefaultAvailabilityZone</tt>, the subnet must
--   be in that zone. For information on default values and when this
--   parameter is required, see the <tt>VpcId</tt> parameter description.
--   
--   <a>$sel:configurationManager:UpdateStack'</a>,
--   <a>updateStack_configurationManager</a> - The configuration manager.
--   When you update a stack, we recommend that you use the configuration
--   manager to specify the Chef version: 12, 11.10, or 11.4 for Linux
--   stacks, or 12.2 for Windows stacks. The default value for Linux stacks
--   is currently 12.
--   
--   <a>$sel:hostnameTheme:UpdateStack'</a>,
--   <a>updateStack_hostnameTheme</a> - The stack's new host name theme,
--   with spaces replaced by underscores. The theme is used to generate
--   host names for the stack's instances. By default,
--   <tt>HostnameTheme</tt> is set to <tt>Layer_Dependent</tt>, which
--   creates host names by appending integers to the layer's short name.
--   The other themes are:
--   
--   <ul>
--   <li><pre>Baked_Goods</pre></li>
--   <li><pre>Clouds</pre></li>
--   <li><pre>Europe_Cities</pre></li>
--   <li><pre>Fruits</pre></li>
--   <li><pre>Greek_Deities_and_Titans</pre></li>
--   <li><pre>Legendary_creatures_from_Japan</pre></li>
--   <li><pre>Planets_and_Moons</pre></li>
--   <li><pre>Roman_Deities</pre></li>
--   <li><pre>Scottish_Islands</pre></li>
--   <li><pre>US_Cities</pre></li>
--   <li><pre>Wild_Cats</pre></li>
--   </ul>
--   
--   To obtain a generated host name, call <tt>GetHostNameSuggestion</tt>,
--   which returns a host name based on the current theme.
--   
--   <a>$sel:stackId:UpdateStack'</a>, <a>updateStack_stackId</a> - The
--   stack ID.
newUpdateStack :: Text -> UpdateStack

-- | The ARN of an IAM profile that is the default profile for all of the
--   stack's EC2 instances. For more information about IAM ARNs, see
--   <a>Using Identifiers</a>.
updateStack_defaultInstanceProfileArn :: Lens' UpdateStack (Maybe Text)

-- | Do not use this parameter. You cannot update a stack's service role.
updateStack_serviceRoleArn :: Lens' UpdateStack (Maybe Text)

-- | The default root device type. This value is used by default for all
--   instances in the stack, but you can override it when you create an
--   instance. For more information, see <a>Storage for the Root
--   Device</a>.
updateStack_defaultRootDeviceType :: Lens' UpdateStack (Maybe RootDeviceType)

-- | A <tt>ChefConfiguration</tt> object that specifies whether to enable
--   Berkshelf and the Berkshelf version on Chef 11.10 stacks. For more
--   information, see <a>Create a New Stack</a>.
updateStack_chefConfiguration :: Lens' UpdateStack (Maybe ChefConfiguration)

-- | The default AWS OpsWorks Stacks agent version. You have the following
--   options:
--   
--   <ul>
--   <li>Auto-update - Set this parameter to <tt>LATEST</tt>. AWS OpsWorks
--   Stacks automatically installs new agent versions on the stack's
--   instances as soon as they are available.</li>
--   <li>Fixed version - Set this parameter to your preferred agent
--   version. To update the agent version, you must edit the stack
--   configuration and specify a new version. AWS OpsWorks Stacks then
--   automatically installs that version on the stack's instances.</li>
--   </ul>
--   
--   The default setting is <tt>LATEST</tt>. To specify an agent version,
--   you must use the complete version number, not the abbreviated number
--   shown on the console. For a list of available agent version numbers,
--   call DescribeAgentVersions. AgentVersion cannot be set to Chef 12.2.
--   
--   You can also specify an agent version when you create or update an
--   instance, which overrides the stack's default setting.
updateStack_agentVersion :: Lens' UpdateStack (Maybe Text)

-- | A default Amazon EC2 key-pair name. The default value is
--   <tt>none</tt>. If you specify a key-pair name, AWS OpsWorks Stacks
--   installs the public key on the instance and you can use the private
--   key with an SSH client to log in to the instance. For more
--   information, see <a>Using SSH to Communicate with an Instance</a> and
--   <a>Managing SSH Access</a>. You can override this setting by
--   specifying a different key pair, or no key pair, when you <a>create an
--   instance</a>.
updateStack_defaultSshKeyName :: Lens' UpdateStack (Maybe Text)

-- | A string that contains user-defined, custom JSON. It can be used to
--   override the corresponding default stack configuration JSON values or
--   to pass data to recipes. The string should be in the following format:
--   
--   <pre>
--   "{\"key1\": \"value1\", \"key2\": \"value2\",...}"
--   </pre>
--   
--   For more information about custom JSON, see <a>Use Custom JSON to
--   Modify the Stack Configuration Attributes</a>.
updateStack_customJson :: Lens' UpdateStack (Maybe Text)

-- | Contains the information required to retrieve an app or cookbook from
--   a repository. For more information, see <a>Adding Apps</a> or
--   <a>Cookbooks and Recipes</a>.
updateStack_customCookbooksSource :: Lens' UpdateStack (Maybe Source)

-- | The stack's default Availability Zone, which must be in the stack's
--   region. For more information, see <a>Regions and Endpoints</a>. If you
--   also specify a value for <tt>DefaultSubnetId</tt>, the subnet must be
--   in the same zone. For more information, see CreateStack.
updateStack_defaultAvailabilityZone :: Lens' UpdateStack (Maybe Text)

-- | One or more user-defined key-value pairs to be added to the stack
--   attributes.
updateStack_attributes :: Lens' UpdateStack (Maybe (HashMap StackAttributesKeys (Maybe Text)))

-- | The stack's new name.
updateStack_name :: Lens' UpdateStack (Maybe Text)

-- | The stack's operating system, which must be set to one of the
--   following:
--   
--   <ul>
--   <li>A supported Linux operating system: An Amazon Linux version, such
--   as <tt>Amazon Linux 2018.03</tt>, <tt>Amazon Linux 2017.09</tt>,
--   <tt>Amazon Linux 2017.03</tt>, <tt>Amazon Linux 2016.09</tt>,
--   <tt>Amazon Linux 2016.03</tt>, <tt>Amazon Linux 2015.09</tt>, or
--   <tt>Amazon Linux 2015.03</tt>.</li>
--   <li>A supported Ubuntu operating system, such as <tt>Ubuntu 16.04
--   LTS</tt>, <tt>Ubuntu 14.04 LTS</tt>, or <tt>Ubuntu 12.04
--   LTS</tt>.</li>
--   <li><pre>CentOS Linux 7</pre></li>
--   <li><pre>Red Hat Enterprise Linux 7</pre></li>
--   <li>A supported Windows operating system, such as <tt>Microsoft
--   Windows Server 2012 R2 Base</tt>, <tt>Microsoft Windows Server 2012 R2
--   with SQL Server Express</tt>, <tt>Microsoft Windows Server 2012 R2
--   with SQL Server Standard</tt>, or <tt>Microsoft Windows Server 2012 R2
--   with SQL Server Web</tt>.</li>
--   <li>A custom AMI: <tt>Custom</tt>. You specify the custom AMI you want
--   to use when you create instances. For more information about how to
--   use custom AMIs with OpsWorks, see <a>Using Custom AMIs</a>.</li>
--   </ul>
--   
--   The default option is the stack's current operating system. For more
--   information about supported operating systems, see <a>AWS OpsWorks
--   Stacks Operating Systems</a>.
updateStack_defaultOs :: Lens' UpdateStack (Maybe Text)

-- | Whether to associate the AWS OpsWorks Stacks built-in security groups
--   with the stack's layers.
--   
--   AWS OpsWorks Stacks provides a standard set of built-in security
--   groups, one for each layer, which are associated with layers by
--   default. <tt>UseOpsworksSecurityGroups</tt> allows you to provide your
--   own custom security groups instead of using the built-in groups.
--   <tt>UseOpsworksSecurityGroups</tt> has the following settings:
--   
--   <ul>
--   <li>True - AWS OpsWorks Stacks automatically associates the
--   appropriate built-in security group with each layer (default setting).
--   You can associate additional security groups with a layer after you
--   create it, but you cannot delete the built-in security group.</li>
--   <li>False - AWS OpsWorks Stacks does not associate built-in security
--   groups with layers. You must create appropriate EC2 security groups
--   and associate a security group with each layer that you create.
--   However, you can still manually associate a built-in security group
--   with a layer on. Custom security groups are required only for those
--   layers that need custom settings.</li>
--   </ul>
--   
--   For more information, see <a>Create a New Stack</a>.
updateStack_useOpsworksSecurityGroups :: Lens' UpdateStack (Maybe Bool)

-- | Whether the stack uses custom cookbooks.
updateStack_useCustomCookbooks :: Lens' UpdateStack (Maybe Bool)

-- | The stack's default VPC subnet ID. This parameter is required if you
--   specify a value for the <tt>VpcId</tt> parameter. All instances are
--   launched into this subnet unless you specify otherwise when you create
--   the instance. If you also specify a value for
--   <tt>DefaultAvailabilityZone</tt>, the subnet must be in that zone. For
--   information on default values and when this parameter is required, see
--   the <tt>VpcId</tt> parameter description.
updateStack_defaultSubnetId :: Lens' UpdateStack (Maybe Text)

-- | The configuration manager. When you update a stack, we recommend that
--   you use the configuration manager to specify the Chef version: 12,
--   11.10, or 11.4 for Linux stacks, or 12.2 for Windows stacks. The
--   default value for Linux stacks is currently 12.
updateStack_configurationManager :: Lens' UpdateStack (Maybe StackConfigurationManager)

-- | The stack's new host name theme, with spaces replaced by underscores.
--   The theme is used to generate host names for the stack's instances. By
--   default, <tt>HostnameTheme</tt> is set to <tt>Layer_Dependent</tt>,
--   which creates host names by appending integers to the layer's short
--   name. The other themes are:
--   
--   <ul>
--   <li><pre>Baked_Goods</pre></li>
--   <li><pre>Clouds</pre></li>
--   <li><pre>Europe_Cities</pre></li>
--   <li><pre>Fruits</pre></li>
--   <li><pre>Greek_Deities_and_Titans</pre></li>
--   <li><pre>Legendary_creatures_from_Japan</pre></li>
--   <li><pre>Planets_and_Moons</pre></li>
--   <li><pre>Roman_Deities</pre></li>
--   <li><pre>Scottish_Islands</pre></li>
--   <li><pre>US_Cities</pre></li>
--   <li><pre>Wild_Cats</pre></li>
--   </ul>
--   
--   To obtain a generated host name, call <tt>GetHostNameSuggestion</tt>,
--   which returns a host name based on the current theme.
updateStack_hostnameTheme :: Lens' UpdateStack (Maybe Text)

-- | The stack ID.
updateStack_stackId :: Lens' UpdateStack Text

UpdateStackResponse' :: UpdateStackResponse
