-- | <i>See:</i> <a>newCreateStack</a> smart constructor.
data CreateStack
CreateStack' :: Maybe RootDeviceType -> Maybe Text -> Maybe ChefConfiguration -> Maybe Text -> Maybe Text -> Maybe Text -> Maybe Source -> Maybe Text -> Maybe (HashMap StackAttributesKeys (Maybe Text)) -> Maybe Text -> Maybe Bool -> Maybe Bool -> Maybe Text -> Maybe StackConfigurationManager -> Maybe Text -> Text -> Text -> Text -> Text -> CreateStack

-- | Create a value of <a>CreateStack</a> with all optional fields omitted.
--   
--   Use <a>generic-lens</a> or <a>optics</a> to modify other optional
--   fields.
--   
--   The following record fields are available, with the corresponding
--   lenses provided for backwards compatibility:
--   
--   <a>$sel:defaultRootDeviceType:CreateStack'</a>,
--   <a>createStack_defaultRootDeviceType</a> - The default root device
--   type. This value is the default for all instances in the stack, but
--   you can override it when you create an instance. The default option is
--   <tt>instance-store</tt>. For more information, see <a>Storage for the
--   Root Device</a>.
--   
--   <a>$sel:vpcId:CreateStack'</a>, <a>createStack_vpcId</a> - The ID of
--   the VPC that the stack is to be launched into. The VPC must be in the
--   stack's region. All instances are launched into this VPC. You cannot
--   change the ID later.
--   
--   <ul>
--   <li>If your account supports EC2-Classic, the default value is <tt>no
--   VPC</tt>.</li>
--   <li>If your account does not support EC2-Classic, the default value is
--   the default VPC for the specified region.</li>
--   </ul>
--   
--   If the VPC ID corresponds to a default VPC and you have specified
--   either the <tt>DefaultAvailabilityZone</tt> or the
--   <tt>DefaultSubnetId</tt> parameter only, AWS OpsWorks Stacks infers
--   the value of the other parameter. If you specify neither parameter,
--   AWS OpsWorks Stacks sets these parameters to the first valid
--   Availability Zone for the specified region and the corresponding
--   default VPC subnet ID, respectively.
--   
--   If you specify a nondefault VPC ID, note the following:
--   
--   <ul>
--   <li>It must belong to a VPC in your account that is in the specified
--   region.</li>
--   <li>You must specify a value for <tt>DefaultSubnetId</tt>.</li>
--   </ul>
--   
--   For more information about how to use AWS OpsWorks Stacks with a VPC,
--   see <a>Running a Stack in a VPC</a>. For more information about
--   default VPC and EC2-Classic, see <a>Supported Platforms</a>.
--   
--   <a>$sel:chefConfiguration:CreateStack'</a>,
--   <a>createStack_chefConfiguration</a> - A <tt>ChefConfiguration</tt>
--   object that specifies whether to enable Berkshelf and the Berkshelf
--   version on Chef 11.10 stacks. For more information, see <a>Create a
--   New Stack</a>.
--   
--   <a>$sel:agentVersion:CreateStack'</a>, <a>createStack_agentVersion</a>
--   - The default AWS OpsWorks Stacks agent version. You have the
--   following options:
--   
--   <ul>
--   <li>Auto-update - Set this parameter to <tt>LATEST</tt>. AWS OpsWorks
--   Stacks automatically installs new agent versions on the stack's
--   instances as soon as they are available.</li>
--   <li>Fixed version - Set this parameter to your preferred agent
--   version. To update the agent version, you must edit the stack
--   configuration and specify a new version. AWS OpsWorks Stacks then
--   automatically installs that version on the stack's instances.</li>
--   </ul>
--   
--   The default setting is the most recent release of the agent. To
--   specify an agent version, you must use the complete version number,
--   not the abbreviated number shown on the console. For a list of
--   available agent version numbers, call DescribeAgentVersions.
--   AgentVersion cannot be set to Chef 12.2.
--   
--   You can also specify an agent version when you create or update an
--   instance, which overrides the stack's default setting.
--   
--   <a>$sel:defaultSshKeyName:CreateStack'</a>,
--   <a>createStack_defaultSshKeyName</a> - A default Amazon EC2 key pair
--   name. The default value is none. If you specify a key pair name, AWS
--   OpsWorks installs the public key on the instance and you can use the
--   private key with an SSH client to log in to the instance. For more
--   information, see <a>Using SSH to Communicate with an Instance</a> and
--   <a>Managing SSH Access</a>. You can override this setting by
--   specifying a different key pair, or no key pair, when you <a>create an
--   instance</a>.
--   
--   <a>$sel:customJson:CreateStack'</a>, <a>createStack_customJson</a> - A
--   string that contains user-defined, custom JSON. It can be used to
--   override the corresponding default stack configuration attribute
--   values or to pass data to recipes. The string should be in the
--   following format:
--   
--   <pre>
--   "{\"key1\": \"value1\", \"key2\": \"value2\",...}"
--   </pre>
--   
--   For more information about custom JSON, see <a>Use Custom JSON to
--   Modify the Stack Configuration Attributes</a>.
--   
--   <a>$sel:customCookbooksSource:CreateStack'</a>,
--   <a>createStack_customCookbooksSource</a> - Contains the information
--   required to retrieve an app or cookbook from a repository. For more
--   information, see <a>Adding Apps</a> or <a>Cookbooks and Recipes</a>.
--   
--   <a>$sel:defaultAvailabilityZone:CreateStack'</a>,
--   <a>createStack_defaultAvailabilityZone</a> - The stack's default
--   Availability Zone, which must be in the specified region. For more
--   information, see <a>Regions and Endpoints</a>. If you also specify a
--   value for <tt>DefaultSubnetId</tt>, the subnet must be in the same
--   zone. For more information, see the <tt>VpcId</tt> parameter
--   description.
--   
--   <a>$sel:attributes:CreateStack'</a>, <a>createStack_attributes</a> -
--   One or more user-defined key-value pairs to be added to the stack
--   attributes.
--   
--   <a>$sel:defaultOs:CreateStack'</a>, <a>createStack_defaultOs</a> - The
--   stack's default operating system, which is installed on every instance
--   unless you specify a different operating system when you create the
--   instance. You can specify one of the following.
--   
--   <ul>
--   <li>A supported Linux operating system: An Amazon Linux version, such
--   as <tt>Amazon Linux 2018.03</tt>, <tt>Amazon Linux 2017.09</tt>,
--   <tt>Amazon Linux 2017.03</tt>, <tt>Amazon Linux 2016.09</tt>,
--   <tt>Amazon Linux 2016.03</tt>, <tt>Amazon Linux 2015.09</tt>, or
--   <tt>Amazon Linux 2015.03</tt>.</li>
--   <li>A supported Ubuntu operating system, such as <tt>Ubuntu 16.04
--   LTS</tt>, <tt>Ubuntu 14.04 LTS</tt>, or <tt>Ubuntu 12.04
--   LTS</tt>.</li>
--   <li><pre>CentOS Linux 7</pre></li>
--   <li><pre>Red Hat Enterprise Linux 7</pre></li>
--   <li>A supported Windows operating system, such as <tt>Microsoft
--   Windows Server 2012 R2 Base</tt>, <tt>Microsoft Windows Server 2012 R2
--   with SQL Server Express</tt>, <tt>Microsoft Windows Server 2012 R2
--   with SQL Server Standard</tt>, or <tt>Microsoft Windows Server 2012 R2
--   with SQL Server Web</tt>.</li>
--   <li>A custom AMI: <tt>Custom</tt>. You specify the custom AMI you want
--   to use when you create instances. For more information, see <a>Using
--   Custom AMIs</a>.</li>
--   </ul>
--   
--   The default option is the current Amazon Linux version. For more
--   information about supported operating systems, see <a>AWS OpsWorks
--   Stacks Operating Systems</a>.
--   
--   <a>$sel:useOpsworksSecurityGroups:CreateStack'</a>,
--   <a>createStack_useOpsworksSecurityGroups</a> - Whether to associate
--   the AWS OpsWorks Stacks built-in security groups with the stack's
--   layers.
--   
--   AWS OpsWorks Stacks provides a standard set of built-in security
--   groups, one for each layer, which are associated with layers by
--   default. With <tt>UseOpsworksSecurityGroups</tt> you can instead
--   provide your own custom security groups.
--   <tt>UseOpsworksSecurityGroups</tt> has the following settings:
--   
--   <ul>
--   <li>True - AWS OpsWorks Stacks automatically associates the
--   appropriate built-in security group with each layer (default setting).
--   You can associate additional security groups with a layer after you
--   create it, but you cannot delete the built-in security group.</li>
--   <li>False - AWS OpsWorks Stacks does not associate built-in security
--   groups with layers. You must create appropriate EC2 security groups
--   and associate a security group with each layer that you create.
--   However, you can still manually associate a built-in security group
--   with a layer on creation; custom security groups are required only for
--   those layers that need custom settings.</li>
--   </ul>
--   
--   For more information, see <a>Create a New Stack</a>.
--   
--   <a>$sel:useCustomCookbooks:CreateStack'</a>,
--   <a>createStack_useCustomCookbooks</a> - Whether the stack uses custom
--   cookbooks.
--   
--   <a>$sel:defaultSubnetId:CreateStack'</a>,
--   <a>createStack_defaultSubnetId</a> - The stack's default VPC subnet
--   ID. This parameter is required if you specify a value for the
--   <tt>VpcId</tt> parameter. All instances are launched into this subnet
--   unless you specify otherwise when you create the instance. If you also
--   specify a value for <tt>DefaultAvailabilityZone</tt>, the subnet must
--   be in that zone. For information on default values and when this
--   parameter is required, see the <tt>VpcId</tt> parameter description.
--   
--   <a>$sel:configurationManager:CreateStack'</a>,
--   <a>createStack_configurationManager</a> - The configuration manager.
--   When you create a stack we recommend that you use the configuration
--   manager to specify the Chef version: 12, 11.10, or 11.4 for Linux
--   stacks, or 12.2 for Windows stacks. The default value for Linux stacks
--   is currently 12.
--   
--   <a>$sel:hostnameTheme:CreateStack'</a>,
--   <a>createStack_hostnameTheme</a> - The stack's host name theme, with
--   spaces replaced by underscores. The theme is used to generate host
--   names for the stack's instances. By default, <tt>HostnameTheme</tt> is
--   set to <tt>Layer_Dependent</tt>, which creates host names by appending
--   integers to the layer's short name. The other themes are:
--   
--   <ul>
--   <li><pre>Baked_Goods</pre></li>
--   <li><pre>Clouds</pre></li>
--   <li><pre>Europe_Cities</pre></li>
--   <li><pre>Fruits</pre></li>
--   <li><pre>Greek_Deities_and_Titans</pre></li>
--   <li><pre>Legendary_creatures_from_Japan</pre></li>
--   <li><pre>Planets_and_Moons</pre></li>
--   <li><pre>Roman_Deities</pre></li>
--   <li><pre>Scottish_Islands</pre></li>
--   <li><pre>US_Cities</pre></li>
--   <li><pre>Wild_Cats</pre></li>
--   </ul>
--   
--   To obtain a generated host name, call <tt>GetHostNameSuggestion</tt>,
--   which returns a host name based on the current theme.
--   
--   <a>$sel:name:CreateStack'</a>, <a>createStack_name</a> - The stack
--   name.
--   
--   <a>$sel:region:CreateStack'</a>, <a>createStack_region</a> - The
--   stack's AWS region, such as <tt>ap-south-1</tt>. For more information
--   about Amazon regions, see <a>Regions and Endpoints</a>.
--   
--   In the AWS CLI, this API maps to the <tt>--stack-region</tt>
--   parameter. If the <tt>--stack-region</tt> parameter and the AWS CLI
--   common parameter <tt>--region</tt> are set to the same value, the
--   stack uses a <i>regional</i> endpoint. If the <tt>--stack-region</tt>
--   parameter is not set, but the AWS CLI <tt>--region</tt> parameter is,
--   this also results in a stack with a <i>regional</i> endpoint. However,
--   if the <tt>--region</tt> parameter is set to <tt>us-east-1</tt>, and
--   the <tt>--stack-region</tt> parameter is set to one of the following,
--   then the stack uses a legacy or <i>classic</i> region: <tt>us-west-1,
--   us-west-2, sa-east-1, eu-central-1, eu-west-1, ap-northeast-1,
--   ap-southeast-1, ap-southeast-2</tt>. In this case, the actual API
--   endpoint of the stack is in <tt>us-east-1</tt>. Only the preceding
--   regions are supported as classic regions in the <tt>us-east-1</tt> API
--   endpoint. Because it is a best practice to choose the regional
--   endpoint that is closest to where you manage AWS, we recommend that
--   you use regional endpoints for new stacks. The AWS CLI common
--   <tt>--region</tt> parameter always specifies a regional API endpoint;
--   it cannot be used to specify a classic AWS OpsWorks Stacks region.
--   
--   <a>$sel:serviceRoleArn:CreateStack'</a>,
--   <a>createStack_serviceRoleArn</a> - The stack's AWS Identity and
--   Access Management (IAM) role, which allows AWS OpsWorks Stacks to work
--   with AWS resources on your behalf. You must set this parameter to the
--   Amazon Resource Name (ARN) for an existing IAM role. For more
--   information about IAM ARNs, see <a>Using Identifiers</a>.
--   
--   <a>$sel:defaultInstanceProfileArn:CreateStack'</a>,
--   <a>createStack_defaultInstanceProfileArn</a> - The Amazon Resource
--   Name (ARN) of an IAM profile that is the default profile for all of
--   the stack's EC2 instances. For more information about IAM ARNs, see
--   <a>Using Identifiers</a>.
newCreateStack :: Text -> Text -> Text -> Text -> CreateStack

-- | Contains the response to a <tt>CreateStack</tt> request.
--   
--   <i>See:</i> <a>newCreateStackResponse</a> smart constructor.

--   string that you use to identify the stack when performing actions such
--   as <tt>DescribeStacks</tt>.
--   
--   <a>$sel:httpStatus:CreateStackResponse'</a>,
--   <a>createStackResponse_httpStatus</a> - The response's http status
--   code.

-- | <i>See:</i> <a>newCreateApp</a> smart constructor.
data CreateApp
CreateApp' :: Maybe SslConfiguration -> Maybe [EnvironmentVariable] -> Maybe Bool -> Maybe Text -> Maybe [DataSource] -> Maybe Source -> Maybe (HashMap AppAttributesKeys Text) -> Maybe [Text] -> Maybe Text -> Text -> Text -> AppType -> CreateApp

-- | Create a value of <a>CreateApp</a> with all optional fields omitted.
--   
--   Use <a>generic-lens</a> or <a>optics</a> to modify other optional
--   fields.
--   
--   The following record fields are available, with the corresponding
--   lenses provided for backwards compatibility:
--   
--   <a>$sel:sslConfiguration:CreateApp'</a>,
--   <a>createApp_sslConfiguration</a> - An <tt>SslConfiguration</tt>
--   object with the SSL configuration.
--   
--   <a>$sel:environment:CreateApp'</a>, <a>createApp_environment</a> - An
--   array of <tt>EnvironmentVariable</tt> objects that specify environment
--   variables to be associated with the app. After you deploy the app,
--   these variables are defined on the associated app server instance. For
--   more information, see <a>Environment Variables</a>.
--   
--   There is no specific limit on the number of environment variables.
--   However, the size of the associated data structure - which includes
--   the variables' names, values, and protected flag values - cannot
--   exceed 20 KB. This limit should accommodate most if not all use cases.
--   Exceeding it will cause an exception with the message, "Environment:
--   is too large (maximum is 20KB)."
--   
--   If you have specified one or more environment variables, you cannot
--   modify the stack's Chef version.
--   
--   <a>$sel:enableSsl:CreateApp'</a>, <a>createApp_enableSsl</a> - Whether
--   to enable SSL for the app.
--   
--   <a>$sel:shortname:CreateApp'</a>, <a>createApp_shortname</a> - The
--   app's short name.
--   
--   <a>$sel:dataSources:CreateApp'</a>, <a>createApp_dataSources</a> - The
--   app's data source.
--   
--   <a>$sel:appSource:CreateApp'</a>, <a>createApp_appSource</a> - A
--   <tt>Source</tt> object that specifies the app repository.
--   
--   <a>$sel:attributes:CreateApp'</a>, <a>createApp_attributes</a> - One
--   or more user-defined key/value pairs to be added to the stack
--   attributes.
--   
--   <a>$sel:domains:CreateApp'</a>, <a>createApp_domains</a> - The app
--   virtual host settings, with multiple domains separated by commas. For
--   example: <tt>'www.example.com, example.com'</tt>
--   
--   <a>$sel:description:CreateApp'</a>, <a>createApp_description</a> - A
--   description of the app.
--   
--   <a>$sel:stackId:CreateApp'</a>, <a>createApp_stackId</a> - The stack
--   ID.
--   
--   <a>$sel:name:CreateApp'</a>, <a>createApp_name</a> - The app name.
--   
--   <a>$sel:type':CreateApp'</a>, <a>createApp_type</a> - The app type.
--   Each supported type is associated with a particular layer. For
--   example, PHP applications are associated with a PHP layer. AWS
--   OpsWorks Stacks deploys an application to those instances that are
--   members of the corresponding layer. If your app isn't one of the
--   standard types, or you prefer to implement your own Deploy recipes,
--   specify <tt>other</tt>.
newCreateApp :: Text -> Text -> AppType -> CreateApp

-- | <i>See:</i> <a>newCloneStack</a> smart constructor.
data CloneStack
CloneStack' :: Maybe Text -> Maybe [Text] -> Maybe RootDeviceType -> Maybe Text -> Maybe ChefConfiguration -> Maybe Text -> Maybe Text -> Maybe Text -> Maybe Bool -> Maybe Source -> Maybe Text -> Maybe (HashMap StackAttributesKeys (Maybe Text)) -> Maybe Text -> Maybe Text -> Maybe Bool -> Maybe Bool -> Maybe Text -> Maybe Text -> Maybe StackConfigurationManager -> Maybe Text -> Text -> Text -> CloneStack

-- | Create a value of <a>CloneStack</a> with all optional fields omitted.
--   
--   Use <a>generic-lens</a> or <a>optics</a> to modify other optional
--   fields.
--   
--   The following record fields are available, with the corresponding
--   lenses provided for backwards compatibility:
--   
--   <a>$sel:defaultInstanceProfileArn:CloneStack'</a>,
--   <a>cloneStack_defaultInstanceProfileArn</a> - The Amazon Resource Name
--   (ARN) of an IAM profile that is the default profile for all of the
--   stack's EC2 instances. For more information about IAM ARNs, see
--   <a>Using Identifiers</a>.
--   
--   <a>$sel:cloneAppIds:CloneStack'</a>, <a>cloneStack_cloneAppIds</a> - A
--   list of source stack app IDs to be included in the cloned stack.
--   
--   <a>$sel:defaultRootDeviceType:CloneStack'</a>,
--   <a>cloneStack_defaultRootDeviceType</a> - The default root device
--   type. This value is used by default for all instances in the cloned
--   stack, but you can override it when you create an instance. For more
--   information, see <a>Storage for the Root Device</a>.
--   
--   <a>$sel:vpcId:CloneStack'</a>, <a>cloneStack_vpcId</a> - The ID of the
--   VPC that the cloned stack is to be launched into. It must be in the
--   specified region. All instances are launched into this VPC, and you
--   cannot change the ID later.
--   
--   <ul>
--   <li>If your account supports EC2 Classic, the default value is no
--   VPC.</li>
--   <li>If your account does not support EC2 Classic, the default value is
--   the default VPC for the specified region.</li>
--   </ul>
--   
--   If the VPC ID corresponds to a default VPC and you have specified
--   either the <tt>DefaultAvailabilityZone</tt> or the
--   <tt>DefaultSubnetId</tt> parameter only, AWS OpsWorks Stacks infers
--   the value of the other parameter. If you specify neither parameter,
--   AWS OpsWorks Stacks sets these parameters to the first valid
--   Availability Zone for the specified region and the corresponding
--   default VPC subnet ID, respectively.
--   
--   If you specify a nondefault VPC ID, note the following:
--   
--   <ul>
--   <li>It must belong to a VPC in your account that is in the specified
--   region.</li>
--   <li>You must specify a value for <tt>DefaultSubnetId</tt>.</li>
--   </ul>
--   
--   For more information about how to use AWS OpsWorks Stacks with a VPC,
--   see <a>Running a Stack in a VPC</a>. For more information about
--   default VPC and EC2 Classic, see <a>Supported Platforms</a>.
--   
--   <a>$sel:chefConfiguration:CloneStack'</a>,
--   <a>cloneStack_chefConfiguration</a> - A <tt>ChefConfiguration</tt>
--   object that specifies whether to enable Berkshelf and the Berkshelf
--   version on Chef 11.10 stacks. For more information, see <a>Create a
--   New Stack</a>.
--   
--   <a>$sel:agentVersion:CloneStack'</a>, <a>cloneStack_agentVersion</a> -
--   The default AWS OpsWorks Stacks agent version. You have the following
--   options:
--   
--   <ul>
--   <li>Auto-update - Set this parameter to <tt>LATEST</tt>. AWS OpsWorks
--   Stacks automatically installs new agent versions on the stack's
--   instances as soon as they are available.</li>
--   <li>Fixed version - Set this parameter to your preferred agent
--   version. To update the agent version, you must edit the stack
--   configuration and specify a new version. AWS OpsWorks Stacks then
--   automatically installs that version on the stack's instances.</li>
--   </ul>
--   
--   The default setting is <tt>LATEST</tt>. To specify an agent version,
--   you must use the complete version number, not the abbreviated number
--   shown on the console. For a list of available agent version numbers,
--   call DescribeAgentVersions. AgentVersion cannot be set to Chef 12.2.
--   
--   You can also specify an agent version when you create or update an
--   instance, which overrides the stack's default setting.
--   
--   <a>$sel:defaultSshKeyName:CloneStack'</a>,
--   <a>cloneStack_defaultSshKeyName</a> - A default Amazon EC2 key pair
--   name. The default value is none. If you specify a key pair name, AWS
--   OpsWorks installs the public key on the instance and you can use the
--   private key with an SSH client to log in to the instance. For more
--   information, see <a>Using SSH to Communicate with an Instance</a> and
--   <a>Managing SSH Access</a>. You can override this setting by
--   specifying a different key pair, or no key pair, when you <a>create an
--   instance</a>.
--   
--   <a>$sel:customJson:CloneStack'</a>, <a>cloneStack_customJson</a> - A
--   string that contains user-defined, custom JSON. It is used to override
--   the corresponding default stack configuration JSON values. The string
--   should be in the following format:
--   
--   <pre>
--   "{\"key1\": \"value1\", \"key2\": \"value2\",...}"
--   </pre>
--   
--   For more information about custom JSON, see <a>Use Custom JSON to
--   Modify the Stack Configuration Attributes</a>
--   
--   <a>$sel:clonePermissions:CloneStack'</a>,
--   <a>cloneStack_clonePermissions</a> - Whether to clone the source
--   stack's permissions.
--   
--   <a>$sel:customCookbooksSource:CloneStack'</a>,
--   <a>cloneStack_customCookbooksSource</a> - Contains the information
--   required to retrieve an app or cookbook from a repository. For more
--   information, see <a>Adding Apps</a> or <a>Cookbooks and Recipes</a>.
--   
--   <a>$sel:defaultAvailabilityZone:CloneStack'</a>,
--   <a>cloneStack_defaultAvailabilityZone</a> - The cloned stack's default
--   Availability Zone, which must be in the specified region. For more
--   information, see <a>Regions and Endpoints</a>. If you also specify a
--   value for <tt>DefaultSubnetId</tt>, the subnet must be in the same
--   zone. For more information, see the <tt>VpcId</tt> parameter
--   description.
--   
--   <a>$sel:attributes:CloneStack'</a>, <a>cloneStack_attributes</a> - A
--   list of stack attributes and values as key/value pairs to be added to
--   the cloned stack.
--   
--   <a>$sel:name:CloneStack'</a>, <a>cloneStack_name</a> - The cloned
--   stack name.
--   
--   <a>$sel:defaultOs:CloneStack'</a>, <a>cloneStack_defaultOs</a> - The
--   stack's operating system, which must be set to one of the following.
--   
--   <ul>
--   <li>A supported Linux operating system: An Amazon Linux version, such
--   as <tt>Amazon Linux 2018.03</tt>, <tt>Amazon Linux 2017.09</tt>,
--   <tt>Amazon Linux 2017.03</tt>, <tt>Amazon Linux 2016.09</tt>,
--   <tt>Amazon Linux 2016.03</tt>, <tt>Amazon Linux 2015.09</tt>, or
--   <tt>Amazon Linux 2015.03</tt>.</li>
--   <li>A supported Ubuntu operating system, such as <tt>Ubuntu 16.04
--   LTS</tt>, <tt>Ubuntu 14.04 LTS</tt>, or <tt>Ubuntu 12.04
--   LTS</tt>.</li>
--   <li><pre>CentOS Linux 7</pre></li>
--   <li><pre>Red Hat Enterprise Linux 7</pre></li>
--   <li><tt>Microsoft Windows Server 2012 R2 Base</tt>, <tt>Microsoft
--   Windows Server 2012 R2 with SQL Server Express</tt>, <tt>Microsoft
--   Windows Server 2012 R2 with SQL Server Standard</tt>, or <tt>Microsoft
--   Windows Server 2012 R2 with SQL Server Web</tt>.</li>
--   <li>A custom AMI: <tt>Custom</tt>. You specify the custom AMI you want
--   to use when you create instances. For more information about how to
--   use custom AMIs with OpsWorks, see <a>Using Custom AMIs</a>.</li>
--   </ul>
--   
--   The default option is the parent stack's operating system. For more
--   information about supported operating systems, see <a>AWS OpsWorks
--   Stacks Operating Systems</a>.
--   
--   You can specify a different Linux operating system for the cloned
--   stack, but you cannot change from Linux to Windows or Windows to
--   Linux.
--   
--   <a>$sel:useOpsworksSecurityGroups:CloneStack'</a>,
--   <a>cloneStack_useOpsworksSecurityGroups</a> - Whether to associate the
--   AWS OpsWorks Stacks built-in security groups with the stack's layers.
--   
--   AWS OpsWorks Stacks provides a standard set of built-in security
--   groups, one for each layer, which are associated with layers by
--   default. With <tt>UseOpsworksSecurityGroups</tt> you can instead
--   provide your own custom security groups.
--   <tt>UseOpsworksSecurityGroups</tt> has the following settings:
--   
--   <ul>
--   <li>True - AWS OpsWorks Stacks automatically associates the
--   appropriate built-in security group with each layer (default setting).
--   You can associate additional security groups with a layer after you
--   create it but you cannot delete the built-in security group.</li>
--   <li>False - AWS OpsWorks Stacks does not associate built-in security
--   groups with layers. You must create appropriate Amazon Elastic Compute
--   Cloud (Amazon EC2) security groups and associate a security group with
--   each layer that you create. However, you can still manually associate
--   a built-in security group with a layer on creation; custom security
--   groups are required only for those layers that need custom
--   settings.</li>
--   </ul>
--   
--   For more information, see <a>Create a New Stack</a>.
--   
--   <a>$sel:useCustomCookbooks:CloneStack'</a>,
--   <a>cloneStack_useCustomCookbooks</a> - Whether to use custom
--   cookbooks.
--   
--   <a>$sel:defaultSubnetId:CloneStack'</a>,
--   <a>cloneStack_defaultSubnetId</a> - The stack's default VPC subnet ID.
--   This parameter is required if you specify a value for the
--   <tt>VpcId</tt> parameter. All instances are launched into this subnet
--   unless you specify otherwise when you create the instance. If you also
--   specify a value for <tt>DefaultAvailabilityZone</tt>, the subnet must
--   be in that zone. For information on default values and when this
--   parameter is required, see the <tt>VpcId</tt> parameter description.
--   
--   <a>$sel:region:CloneStack'</a>, <a>cloneStack_region</a> - The cloned
--   stack AWS region, such as "ap-northeast-2". For more information about
--   AWS regions, see <a>Regions and Endpoints</a>.
--   
--   <a>$sel:configurationManager:CloneStack'</a>,
--   <a>cloneStack_configurationManager</a> - The configuration manager.
--   When you clone a stack we recommend that you use the configuration
--   manager to specify the Chef version: 12, 11.10, or 11.4 for Linux
--   stacks, or 12.2 for Windows stacks. The default value for Linux stacks
--   is currently 12.
--   
--   <a>$sel:hostnameTheme:CloneStack'</a>, <a>cloneStack_hostnameTheme</a>
--   - The stack's host name theme, with spaces are replaced by
--   underscores. The theme is used to generate host names for the stack's
--   instances. By default, <tt>HostnameTheme</tt> is set to
--   <tt>Layer_Dependent</tt>, which creates host names by appending
--   integers to the layer's short name. The other themes are:
--   
--   <ul>
--   <li><pre>Baked_Goods</pre></li>
--   <li><pre>Clouds</pre></li>
--   <li><pre>Europe_Cities</pre></li>
--   <li><pre>Fruits</pre></li>
--   <li><pre>Greek_Deities_and_Titans</pre></li>
--   <li><pre>Legendary_creatures_from_Japan</pre></li>
--   <li><pre>Planets_and_Moons</pre></li>
--   <li><pre>Roman_Deities</pre></li>
--   <li><pre>Scottish_Islands</pre></li>
--   <li><pre>US_Cities</pre></li>
--   <li><pre>Wild_Cats</pre></li>
--   </ul>
--   
--   To obtain a generated host name, call <tt>GetHostNameSuggestion</tt>,
--   which returns a host name based on the current theme.
--   
--   <a>$sel:sourceStackId:CloneStack'</a>, <a>cloneStack_sourceStackId</a>
--   - The source stack ID.
--   
--   <a>$sel:serviceRoleArn:CloneStack'</a>,
--   <a>cloneStack_serviceRoleArn</a> - The stack AWS Identity and Access
--   Management (IAM) role, which allows AWS OpsWorks Stacks to work with
--   AWS resources on your behalf. You must set this parameter to the
--   Amazon Resource Name (ARN) for an existing IAM role. If you create a
--   stack by using the AWS OpsWorks Stacks console, it creates the role
--   for you. You can obtain an existing stack's IAM ARN programmatically
--   by calling DescribePermissions. For more information about IAM ARNs,
--   see <a>Using Identifiers</a>.
--   
--   You must set this parameter to a valid service role ARN or the action
--   will fail; there is no default value. You can specify the source
--   stack's service role ARN, if you prefer, but you must do so
--   explicitly.
newCloneStack :: Text -> Text -> CloneStack

-- | Contains the response to a <tt>CloneStack</tt> request.
--   
--   <i>See:</i> <a>newCloneStackResponse</a> smart constructor.
data CloneStackResponse
CloneStackResponse' :: Maybe Text -> Int -> CloneStackResponse

-- | Create a value of <a>CloneStackResponse</a> with all optional fields
--   omitted.
--   
--   Use <a>generic-lens</a> or <a>optics</a> to modify other optional
--   fields.
--   
--   The following record fields are available, with the corresponding
--   lenses provided for backwards compatibility:
--   
--   <a>$sel:stackId:CloneStackResponse'</a>,
--   <a>cloneStackResponse_stackId</a> - The cloned stack ID.
--   
--   <a>$sel:httpStatus:CloneStackResponse'</a>,
--   <a>cloneStackResponse_httpStatus</a> - The response's http status
--   code.
newCloneStackResponse :: Int -> CloneStackResponse

-- | <i>See:</i> <a>newDescribePermissions</a> smart constructor.
data DescribePermissions
DescribePermissions' :: Maybe Text -> Maybe Text -> DescribePermissions

-- | Create a value of <a>DescribePermissions</a> with all optional fields
--   omitted.
--   
--   Use <a>generic-lens</a> or <a>optics</a> to modify other optional
--   fields.
--   
--   The following record fields are available, with the corresponding
--   lenses provided for backwards compatibility:
--

--   also be a federated user's ARN. For more information about IAM ARNs,
--   see <a>Using Identifiers</a>.
--   
--   <a>$sel:stackId:DescribePermissions'</a>,
--   <a>describePermissions_stackId</a> - The stack ID.
newDescribePermissions :: DescribePermissions

data DescribePermissionsResponse
DescribePermissionsResponse' :: Maybe [Permission] -> Int -> DescribePermissionsResponse

-- | Create a value of <a>DescribePermissionsResponse</a> with all optional
--   fields omitted.
--   
--   Use <a>generic-lens</a> or <a>optics</a> to modify other optional
--   fields.
--   
--   The following record fields are available, with the corresponding
--   lenses provided for backwards compatibility:
--   
--   <a>$sel:permissions:DescribePermissionsResponse'</a>,
--   <a>describePermissionsResponse_permissions</a> - An array of
--   <tt>Permission</tt> objects that describe the stack permissions.
--   
--   <ul>
--   <li>If the request object contains only a stack ID, the array contains
--   a <tt>Permission</tt> object with permissions for each of the stack
--   IAM ARNs.</li>
--   <li>If the request object contains only an IAM ARN, the array contains
--   a <tt>Permission</tt> object with permissions for each of the user's
--   stack IDs.</li>
--   <li>If the request contains a stack ID and an IAM ARN, the array
--   contains a single <tt>Permission</tt> object with permissions for the
--   specified stack and IAM ARN.</li>
--   </ul>
--   
--   <a>$sel:httpStatus:DescribePermissionsResponse'</a>,
--   <a>describePermissionsResponse_httpStatus</a> - The response's http
--   status code.

--   fields.
--   
--   The following record fields are available, with the corresponding
--   lenses provided for backwards compatibility:
--   
--   <a>$sel:resourceArn:TagResource'</a>, <a>tagResource_resourceArn</a> -
--   The stack or layer's Amazon Resource Number (ARN).
--   
--   <a>$sel:tags:TagResource'</a>, <a>tagResource_tags</a> - A map that
--   contains tag keys and tag values that are attached to a stack or
--   layer.
--   
--   <ul>
--   <li>The key cannot be empty.</li>
--   <li>The key can be a maximum of 127 characters, and can contain only
--   Unicode letters, numbers, or separators, or the following special
--   characters: <tt>+ - = . _ : /</tt></li>
--   <li>The value can be a maximum 255 characters, and contain only
--   Unicode letters, numbers, or separators, or the following special
--   characters: <tt>+ - = . _ : /</tt></li>
--   <li>Leading and trailing white spaces are trimmed from both the key
--   and value.</li>
--   <li>A maximum of 40 tags is allowed for any resource.</li>
--   </ul>
newTagResource :: Text -> TagResource

--   removes them. For example, <tt>my.name</tt> will be changed to

-- | Specifies the encoding of the log file so that the file can be read
--   correctly. The default is <tt>utf_8</tt>. Encodings supported by
--   Python <tt>codecs.decode()</tt> can be used here.
newtype CloudWatchLogsEncoding
CloudWatchLogsEncoding' :: Text -> CloudWatchLogsEncoding
[fromCloudWatchLogsEncoding] :: CloudWatchLogsEncoding -> Text
pattern CloudWatchLogsEncoding_Ascii :: CloudWatchLogsEncoding
pattern CloudWatchLogsEncoding_Big5 :: CloudWatchLogsEncoding
pattern CloudWatchLogsEncoding_Big5hkscs :: CloudWatchLogsEncoding
pattern CloudWatchLogsEncoding_Cp037 :: CloudWatchLogsEncoding
pattern CloudWatchLogsEncoding_Cp1006 :: CloudWatchLogsEncoding
pattern CloudWatchLogsEncoding_Cp1026 :: CloudWatchLogsEncoding
pattern CloudWatchLogsEncoding_Cp1140 :: CloudWatchLogsEncoding
pattern CloudWatchLogsEncoding_Cp1250 :: CloudWatchLogsEncoding
pattern CloudWatchLogsEncoding_Cp1251 :: CloudWatchLogsEncoding
pattern CloudWatchLogsEncoding_Cp1252 :: CloudWatchLogsEncoding
pattern CloudWatchLogsEncoding_Cp1253 :: CloudWatchLogsEncoding
pattern CloudWatchLogsEncoding_Cp1254 :: CloudWatchLogsEncoding
pattern CloudWatchLogsEncoding_Cp1255 :: CloudWatchLogsEncoding
pattern CloudWatchLogsEncoding_Cp1256 :: CloudWatchLogsEncoding
pattern CloudWatchLogsEncoding_Cp1257 :: CloudWatchLogsEncoding
pattern CloudWatchLogsEncoding_Cp1258 :: CloudWatchLogsEncoding
pattern CloudWatchLogsEncoding_Cp424 :: CloudWatchLogsEncoding
pattern CloudWatchLogsEncoding_Cp437 :: CloudWatchLogsEncoding
pattern CloudWatchLogsEncoding_Cp500 :: CloudWatchLogsEncoding
pattern CloudWatchLogsEncoding_Cp720 :: CloudWatchLogsEncoding
pattern CloudWatchLogsEncoding_Cp737 :: CloudWatchLogsEncoding
pattern CloudWatchLogsEncoding_Cp775 :: CloudWatchLogsEncoding
pattern CloudWatchLogsEncoding_Cp850 :: CloudWatchLogsEncoding

pattern CloudWatchLogsEncoding_Cp855 :: CloudWatchLogsEncoding

-- | Specifies where to start to read data (start_of_file or end_of_file).
--   The default is start_of_file. It's only used if there is no state
--   persisted for that log stream.
newtype CloudWatchLogsInitialPosition
CloudWatchLogsInitialPosition' :: Text -> CloudWatchLogsInitialPosition
[fromCloudWatchLogsInitialPosition] :: CloudWatchLogsInitialPosition -> Text
pattern CloudWatchLogsInitialPosition_End_of_file :: CloudWatchLogsInitialPosition
pattern CloudWatchLogsInitialPosition_Start_of_file :: CloudWatchLogsInitialPosition

--   values are <tt>LOCAL</tt> and <tt>UTC</tt>, for Coordinated Universal
--   Time.

pattern CloudWatchLogsTimeZone_LOCAL :: CloudWatchLogsTimeZone
pattern CloudWatchLogsTimeZone_UTC :: CloudWatchLogsTimeZone

--   
--   <i>See:</i> <a>newAgentVersion</a> smart constructor.
data AgentVersion

-- | Create a value of <a>AgentVersion</a> with all optional fields
--   omitted.
--   
--   Use <a>generic-lens</a> or <a>optics</a> to modify other optional
--   fields.
--   
--   The following record fields are available, with the corresponding
--   lenses provided for backwards compatibility:
--

newAgentVersion :: AgentVersion

-- | A description of the app.
--   
--   <i>See:</i> <a>newApp</a> smart constructor.
data App
App' :: Maybe SslConfiguration -> Maybe [EnvironmentVariable] -> Maybe Bool -> Maybe Text -> Maybe Text -> Maybe [DataSource] -> Maybe Source -> Maybe Text -> Maybe (HashMap AppAttributesKeys Text) -> Maybe Text -> Maybe AppType -> Maybe Text -> Maybe [Text] -> Maybe Text -> App

-- | Create a value of <a>App</a> with all optional fields omitted.
--   
--   Use <a>generic-lens</a> or <a>optics</a> to modify other optional
--   fields.
--   
--   The following record fields are available, with the corresponding
--   lenses provided for backwards compatibility:
--   
--   <a>$sel:sslConfiguration:App'</a>, <a>app_sslConfiguration</a> - An
--   <tt>SslConfiguration</tt> object with the SSL configuration.
--   
--   <a>$sel:environment:App'</a>, <a>app_environment</a> - An array of
--   <tt>EnvironmentVariable</tt> objects that specify environment
--   variables to be associated with the app. After you deploy the app,
--   these variables are defined on the associated app server instances.
--   For more information, see <a>Environment Variables</a>.
--   
--   There is no specific limit on the number of environment variables.
--   However, the size of the associated data structure - which includes
--   the variable names, values, and protected flag values - cannot exceed
--   20 KB. This limit should accommodate most if not all use cases, but if
--   you do exceed it, you will cause an exception (API) with an
--   "Environment: is too large (maximum is 20 KB)" message.
--   
--   <a>$sel:enableSsl:App'</a>, <a>app_enableSsl</a> - Whether to enable
--   SSL for the app.
--   
--   <a>$sel:createdAt:App'</a>, <a>app_createdAt</a> - When the app was
--   created.
--   
--   <a>$sel:shortname:App'</a>, <a>app_shortname</a> - The app's short
--   name.
--   
--   <a>$sel:dataSources:App'</a>, <a>app_dataSources</a> - The app's data
--   sources.
--   
--   <a>$sel:appSource:App'</a>, <a>app_appSource</a> - A <tt>Source</tt>
--   object that describes the app repository.
--   
--   <a>$sel:appId:App'</a>, <a>app_appId</a> - The app ID.
--   
--   <a>$sel:attributes:App'</a>, <a>app_attributes</a> - The stack
--   attributes.
--   
--   <a>$sel:name:App'</a>, <a>app_name</a> - The app name.
--   
--   <a>$sel:type':App'</a>, <a>app_type</a> - The app type.
--   
--   <a>$sel:stackId:App'</a>, <a>app_stackId</a> - The app stack ID.
--   
--   <a>$sel:domains:App'</a>, <a>app_domains</a> - The app vhost settings
--   with multiple domains separated by commas. For example:
--   <tt>'www.example.com, example.com'</tt>
--   
--   <a>$sel:description:App'</a>, <a>app_description</a> - A description
--   of the app.
newApp :: App

-- | Describes a load-based auto scaling upscaling or downscaling threshold
--   configuration, which specifies when AWS OpsWorks Stacks starts or
--   stops load-based instances.
--   
--   <i>See:</i> <a>newAutoScalingThresholds</a> smart constructor.
data AutoScalingThresholds
AutoScalingThresholds' :: Maybe Int -> Maybe Natural -> Maybe Double -> Maybe Natural -> Maybe [Text] -> Maybe Double -> Maybe Double -> AutoScalingThresholds

-- | Create a value of <a>AutoScalingThresholds</a> with all optional
--   fields omitted.
--   
--   Use <a>generic-lens</a> or <a>optics</a> to modify other optional
--   fields.
--   
--   The following record fields are available, with the corresponding
--   lenses provided for backwards compatibility:
--   
--   <a>$sel:instanceCount:AutoScalingThresholds'</a>,
--   <a>autoScalingThresholds_instanceCount</a> - The number of instances
--   to add or remove when the load exceeds a threshold.
--   
--   <a>$sel:ignoreMetricsTime:AutoScalingThresholds'</a>,
--   <a>autoScalingThresholds_ignoreMetricsTime</a> - The amount of time
--   (in minutes) after a scaling event occurs that AWS OpsWorks Stacks
--   should ignore metrics and suppress additional scaling events. For
--   example, AWS OpsWorks Stacks adds new instances following an upscaling
--   event but the instances won't start reducing the load until they have
--   been booted and configured. There is no point in raising additional
--   scaling events during that operation, which typically takes several
--   minutes. <tt>IgnoreMetricsTime</tt> allows you to direct AWS OpsWorks
--   Stacks to suppress scaling events long enough to get the new instances
--   online.
--   
--   <a>$sel:loadThreshold:AutoScalingThresholds'</a>,
--   <a>autoScalingThresholds_loadThreshold</a> - The load threshold. A
--   value of -1 disables the threshold. For more information about how
--   load is computed, see <a>Load (computing)</a>.
--   
--   <a>$sel:thresholdsWaitTime:AutoScalingThresholds'</a>,
--   <a>autoScalingThresholds_thresholdsWaitTime</a> - The amount of time,
--   in minutes, that the load must exceed a threshold before more
--   instances are added or removed.
--   
--   <a>$sel:alarms:AutoScalingThresholds'</a>,
--   <a>autoScalingThresholds_alarms</a> - Custom Cloudwatch auto scaling
--   alarms, to be used as thresholds. This parameter takes a list of up to
--   five alarm names, which are case sensitive and must be in the same
--   region as the stack.
--   
--   To use custom alarms, you must update your service role to allow
--   <tt>cloudwatch:DescribeAlarms</tt>. You can either have AWS OpsWorks
--   Stacks update the role for you when you first use this feature or you
--   can edit the role manually. For more information, see <a>Allowing AWS
--   OpsWorks Stacks to Act on Your Behalf</a>.
--   
--   <a>$sel:memoryThreshold:AutoScalingThresholds'</a>,
--   <a>autoScalingThresholds_memoryThreshold</a> - The memory utilization
--   threshold, as a percent of the available memory. A value of -1
--   disables the threshold.
--   
--   <a>$sel:cpuThreshold:AutoScalingThresholds'</a>,
--   <a>autoScalingThresholds_cpuThreshold</a> - The CPU utilization
--   threshold, as a percent of the available CPU. A value of -1 disables
--   the threshold.
newAutoScalingThresholds :: AutoScalingThresholds

-- | Describes a block device mapping. This data type maps directly to the
--   Amazon EC2 <a>BlockDeviceMapping</a> data type.
--   
--   <i>See:</i> <a>newBlockDeviceMapping</a> smart constructor.
data BlockDeviceMapping
BlockDeviceMapping' :: Maybe Text -> Maybe Text -> Maybe EbsBlockDevice -> Maybe Text -> BlockDeviceMapping

-- | Create a value of <a>BlockDeviceMapping</a> with all optional fields
--   omitted.
--   
--   Use <a>generic-lens</a> or <a>optics</a> to modify other optional
--   fields.
--   
--   The following record fields are available, with the corresponding
--   lenses provided for backwards compatibility:
--   
--   <a>$sel:virtualName:BlockDeviceMapping'</a>,
--   <a>blockDeviceMapping_virtualName</a> - The virtual device name. For
--   more information, see <a>BlockDeviceMapping</a>.
--   
--   <a>$sel:noDevice:BlockDeviceMapping'</a>,
--   <a>blockDeviceMapping_noDevice</a> - Suppresses the specified device
--   included in the AMI's block device mapping.
--   
--   <a>$sel:ebs:BlockDeviceMapping'</a>, <a>blockDeviceMapping_ebs</a> -
--   An <tt>EBSBlockDevice</tt> that defines how to configure an Amazon EBS
--   volume when the instance is launched.
--   
--   <a>$sel:deviceName:BlockDeviceMapping'</a>,
--   <a>blockDeviceMapping_deviceName</a> - The device name that is exposed
--   to the instance, such as <tt>/dev/sdh</tt>. For the root device, you
--   can use the explicit device name or you can set this parameter to
--   <tt>ROOT_DEVICE</tt> and AWS OpsWorks Stacks will provide the correct
--   device name.
newBlockDeviceMapping :: BlockDeviceMapping

-- | Describes the Amazon CloudWatch logs configuration for a layer.
--   
--   <i>See:</i> <a>newCloudWatchLogsConfiguration</a> smart constructor.
data CloudWatchLogsConfiguration
CloudWatchLogsConfiguration' :: Maybe Bool -> Maybe [CloudWatchLogsLogStream] -> CloudWatchLogsConfiguration

-- | Create a value of <a>CloudWatchLogsConfiguration</a> with all optional
--   fields omitted.
--   
--   Use <a>generic-lens</a> or <a>optics</a> to modify other optional
--   fields.
--   
--   The following record fields are available, with the corresponding
--   lenses provided for backwards compatibility:
--   
--   <a>$sel:enabled:CloudWatchLogsConfiguration'</a>,
--   <a>cloudWatchLogsConfiguration_enabled</a> - Whether CloudWatch Logs
--   is enabled for a layer.
--   
--   <a>$sel:logStreams:CloudWatchLogsConfiguration'</a>,
--   <a>cloudWatchLogsConfiguration_logStreams</a> - A list of
--   configuration options for CloudWatch Logs.
newCloudWatchLogsConfiguration :: CloudWatchLogsConfiguration

-- | Describes the Amazon CloudWatch logs configuration for a layer. For
--   detailed information about members of this data type, see the
--   <a>CloudWatch Logs Agent Reference</a>.
--   
--   <i>See:</i> <a>newCloudWatchLogsLogStream</a> smart constructor.
data CloudWatchLogsLogStream
CloudWatchLogsLogStream' :: Maybe Int -> Maybe Text -> Maybe Int -> Maybe Int -> Maybe Text -> Maybe Text -> Maybe CloudWatchLogsInitialPosition -> Maybe Text -> Maybe CloudWatchLogsEncoding -> Maybe CloudWatchLogsTimeZone -> Maybe Text -> CloudWatchLogsLogStream

-- | Create a value of <a>CloudWatchLogsLogStream</a> with all optional
--   fields omitted.
--   
--   Use <a>generic-lens</a> or <a>optics</a> to modify other optional
--   fields.
--   
--   The following record fields are available, with the corresponding
--   lenses provided for backwards compatibility:
--   
--   <a>$sel:batchCount:CloudWatchLogsLogStream'</a>,
--   <a>cloudWatchLogsLogStream_batchCount</a> - Specifies the max number
--   of log events in a batch, up to 10000. The default value is 1000.
--   
--   <a>$sel:fileFingerprintLines:CloudWatchLogsLogStream'</a>,
--   <a>cloudWatchLogsLogStream_fileFingerprintLines</a> - Specifies the
--   range of lines for identifying a file. The valid values are one
--   number, or two dash-delimited numbers, such as '1', '2-5'. The default
--   value is '1', meaning the first line is used to calculate the
--   fingerprint. Fingerprint lines are not sent to CloudWatch Logs unless
--   all specified lines are available.
--   
--   <a>$sel:bufferDuration:CloudWatchLogsLogStream'</a>,
--   <a>cloudWatchLogsLogStream_bufferDuration</a> - Specifies the time
--   duration for the batching of log events. The minimum value is 5000ms
--   and default value is 5000ms.
--   
--   <a>$sel:batchSize:CloudWatchLogsLogStream'</a>,
--   <a>cloudWatchLogsLogStream_batchSize</a> - Specifies the maximum size
--   of log events in a batch, in bytes, up to 1048576 bytes. The default
--   value is 32768 bytes. This size is calculated as the sum of all event
--   messages in UTF-8, plus 26 bytes for each log event.
--   
--   <a>$sel:logGroupName:CloudWatchLogsLogStream'</a>,
--   <a>cloudWatchLogsLogStream_logGroupName</a> - Specifies the
--   destination log group. A log group is created automatically if it
--   doesn't already exist. Log group names can be between 1 and 512
--   characters long. Allowed characters include a-z, A-Z, 0-9, '_'
--   (underscore), '-' (hyphen), '/' (forward slash), and '.' (period).
--   
--   <a>$sel:multiLineStartPattern:CloudWatchLogsLogStream'</a>,
--   <a>cloudWatchLogsLogStream_multiLineStartPattern</a> - Specifies the
--   pattern for identifying the start of a log message.
--   
--   <a>$sel:initialPosition:CloudWatchLogsLogStream'</a>,
--   <a>cloudWatchLogsLogStream_initialPosition</a> - Specifies where to
--   start to read data (start_of_file or end_of_file). The default is
--   start_of_file. This setting is only used if there is no state
--   persisted for that log stream.
--   
--   <a>$sel:datetimeFormat:CloudWatchLogsLogStream'</a>,
--   <a>cloudWatchLogsLogStream_datetimeFormat</a> - Specifies how the time
--   stamp is extracted from logs. For more information, see the
--   <a>CloudWatch Logs Agent Reference</a>.
--   
--   <a>$sel:encoding:CloudWatchLogsLogStream'</a>,
--   <a>cloudWatchLogsLogStream_encoding</a> - Specifies the encoding of
--   the log file so that the file can be read correctly. The default is
--   <tt>utf_8</tt>. Encodings supported by Python <tt>codecs.decode()</tt>
--   can be used here.
--   
--   <a>$sel:timeZone:CloudWatchLogsLogStream'</a>,
--   <a>cloudWatchLogsLogStream_timeZone</a> - Specifies the time zone of
--   log event time stamps.
--   
--   <a>$sel:file:CloudWatchLogsLogStream'</a>,
--   <a>cloudWatchLogsLogStream_file</a> - Specifies log files that you
--   want to push to CloudWatch Logs.
--   
--   <tt>File</tt> can point to a specific file or multiple files (by using
--   wild card characters such as <tt>/var/log/system.log*</tt>). Only the
--   latest file is pushed to CloudWatch Logs, based on file modification
--   time. We recommend that you use wild card characters to specify a
--   series of files of the same type, such as
--   <tt>access_log.2014-06-01-01</tt>, <tt>access_log.2014-06-01-02</tt>,
--   and so on by using a pattern like <tt>access_log.*</tt>. Don't use a
--   wildcard to match multiple file types, such as <tt>access_log_80</tt>
--   and <tt>access_log_443</tt>. To specify multiple, different file
--   types, add another log stream entry to the configuration file, so that
--   each log file type is stored in a different log group.
--   
--   Zipped files are not supported.
newCloudWatchLogsLogStream :: CloudWatchLogsLogStream

-- | Describes a command.
--   
--   <i>See:</i> <a>newCommand</a> smart constructor.
data Command
Command' :: Maybe Text -> Maybe Text -> Maybe Text -> Maybe Text -> Maybe Text -> Maybe Text -> Maybe Int -> Maybe Text -> Maybe Text -> Maybe Text -> Command

-- | Create a value of <a>Command</a> with all optional fields omitted.
--   
--   Use <a>generic-lens</a> or <a>optics</a> to modify other optional
--   fields.
--   
--   The following record fields are available, with the corresponding
--   lenses provided for backwards compatibility:
--   
--   <a>$sel:deploymentId:Command'</a>, <a>command_deploymentId</a> - The
--   command deployment ID.
--   
--   <a>$sel:instanceId:Command'</a>, <a>command_instanceId</a> - The ID of
--   the instance where the command was executed.
--   
--   <a>$sel:status:Command'</a>, <a>command_status</a> - The command
--   status:
--   
--   <ul>
--   <li>failed</li>
--   <li>successful</li>
--   <li>skipped</li>
--   <li>pending</li>
--   </ul>
--   
--   <a>$sel:logUrl:Command'</a>, <a>command_logUrl</a> - The URL of the
--   command log.
--   
--   <a>$sel:createdAt:Command'</a>, <a>command_createdAt</a> - Date and
--   time when the command was run.
--   
--   <a>$sel:commandId:Command'</a>, <a>command_commandId</a> - The command
--   ID.
--   
--   <a>$sel:exitCode:Command'</a>, <a>command_exitCode</a> - The command
--   exit code.
--   
--   <a>$sel:type':Command'</a>, <a>command_type</a> - The command type:
--   
--   <ul>
--   <li><pre>configure</pre></li>
--   <li><pre>deploy</pre></li>
--   <li><pre>execute_recipes</pre></li>
--   <li><pre>install_dependencies</pre></li>
--   <li><pre>restart</pre></li>
--   <li><pre>rollback</pre></li>
--   <li><pre>setup</pre></li>
--   <li><pre>start</pre></li>
--   <li><pre>stop</pre></li>
--   <li><pre>undeploy</pre></li>
--   <li><pre>update_custom_cookbooks</pre></li>
--   <li><pre>update_dependencies</pre></li>
--   </ul>
--   
--   <a>$sel:completedAt:Command'</a>, <a>command_completedAt</a> - Date
--   when the command completed.
--   
--   <a>$sel:acknowledgedAt:Command'</a>, <a>command_acknowledgedAt</a> -
--   Date and time when the command was acknowledged.
newCommand :: Command

-- | Describes an app's data source.
--   
--   <i>See:</i> <a>newDataSource</a> smart constructor.
data DataSource
DataSource' :: Maybe Text -> Maybe Text -> Maybe Text -> DataSource

-- | Create a value of <a>DataSource</a> with all optional fields omitted.
--   
--   Use <a>generic-lens</a> or <a>optics</a> to modify other optional
--   fields.
--   
--   The following record fields are available, with the corresponding
--   lenses provided for backwards compatibility:
--   
--   <a>$sel:arn:DataSource'</a>, <a>dataSource_arn</a> - The data source's
--   ARN.
--   
--   <a>$sel:databaseName:DataSource'</a>, <a>dataSource_databaseName</a> -
--   The database name.
--   
--   <a>$sel:type':DataSource'</a>, <a>dataSource_type</a> - The data
--   source's type, <tt>AutoSelectOpsworksMysqlInstance</tt>,
--   <tt>OpsworksMysqlInstance</tt>, <tt>RdsDbInstance</tt>, or
--   <tt>None</tt>.
newDataSource :: DataSource

-- | Describes a deployment of a stack or app.
--   
--   <i>See:</i> <a>newDeployment</a> smart constructor.
data Deployment
Deployment' :: Maybe Text -> Maybe Text -> Maybe DeploymentCommand -> Maybe Text -> Maybe Text -> Maybe Text -> Maybe Text -> Maybe [Text] -> Maybe Text -> Maybe Text -> Maybe Text -> Maybe Int -> Deployment

-- | Create a value of <a>Deployment</a> with all optional fields omitted.
--   
--   Use <a>generic-lens</a> or <a>optics</a> to modify other optional
--   fields.
--   
--   The following record fields are available, with the corresponding
--   lenses provided for backwards compatibility:
--   
--   <a>$sel:deploymentId:Deployment'</a>, <a>deployment_deploymentId</a> -
--   The deployment ID.
--   
--   <a>$sel:status:Deployment'</a>, <a>deployment_status</a> - The
--   deployment status:
--   
--   <ul>
--   <li>running</li>
--   <li>successful</li>
--   <li>failed</li>
--   </ul>
--   
--   <a>$sel:command:Deployment'</a>, <a>deployment_command</a> - Used to
--   specify a stack or deployment command.
--   
--   <a>$sel:createdAt:Deployment'</a>, <a>deployment_createdAt</a> - Date
--   when the deployment was created.
--   
--   <a>$sel:customJson:Deployment'</a>, <a>deployment_customJson</a> - A
--   string that contains user-defined custom JSON. It can be used to
--   override the corresponding default stack configuration attribute
--   values for stack or to pass data to recipes. The string should be in
--   the following format:
--   
--   <pre>
--   "{\"key1\": \"value1\", \"key2\": \"value2\",...}"
--   </pre>
--   
--   For more information on custom JSON, see <a>Use Custom JSON to Modify
--   the Stack Configuration Attributes</a>.
--   
--   <a>$sel:iamUserArn:Deployment'</a>, <a>deployment_iamUserArn</a> - The
--   user's IAM ARN.
--   
--   <a>$sel:appId:Deployment'</a>, <a>deployment_appId</a> - The app ID.
--   
--   <a>$sel:instanceIds:Deployment'</a>, <a>deployment_instanceIds</a> -
--   The IDs of the target instances.
--   
--   <a>$sel:completedAt:Deployment'</a>, <a>deployment_completedAt</a> -
--   Date when the deployment completed.
--   
--   <a>$sel:stackId:Deployment'</a>, <a>deployment_stackId</a> - The stack
--   ID.
--   
--   <a>$sel:comment:Deployment'</a>, <a>deployment_comment</a> - A
--   user-defined comment.
--   
--   <a>$sel:duration:Deployment'</a>, <a>deployment_duration</a> - The
--   deployment duration.
newDeployment :: Deployment

-- | Used to specify a stack or deployment command.
--   
--   <i>See:</i> <a>newDeploymentCommand</a> smart constructor.
data DeploymentCommand
DeploymentCommand' :: Maybe (HashMap Text [Text]) -> DeploymentCommandName -> DeploymentCommand

-- | Create a value of <a>DeploymentCommand</a> with all optional fields
--   omitted.
--   
--   Use <a>generic-lens</a> or <a>optics</a> to modify other optional
--   fields.
--   
--   The following record fields are available, with the corresponding
--   lenses provided for backwards compatibility:
--   
--   <a>$sel:args:DeploymentCommand'</a>, <a>deploymentCommand_args</a> -
--   The arguments of those commands that take arguments. It should be set
--   to a JSON object with the following format:
--   
--   <pre>
--   {"arg_name1" : ["value1", "value2", ...], "arg_name2" : ["value1", "value2", ...], ...}
--   </pre>
--   
--   The <tt>update_dependencies</tt> command takes two arguments:
--   
--   <ul>
--   <li><tt>upgrade_os_to</tt> - Specifies the desired Amazon Linux
--   version for instances whose OS you want to upgrade, such as <tt>Amazon
--   Linux 2016.09</tt>. You must also set the <tt>allow_reboot</tt>
--   argument to true.</li>
--   <li><tt>allow_reboot</tt> - Specifies whether to allow AWS OpsWorks
--   Stacks to reboot the instances if necessary, after installing the
--   updates. This argument can be set to either <tt>true</tt> or
--   <tt>false</tt>. The default value is <tt>false</tt>.</li>
--   </ul>
--   
--   For example, to upgrade an instance to Amazon Linux 2016.09, set
--   <tt>Args</tt> to the following.
--   
--   <pre>
--   { "upgrade_os_to":["Amazon Linux 2016.09"], "allow_reboot":["true"] }
--   </pre>
--   
--   <a>$sel:name:DeploymentCommand'</a>, <a>deploymentCommand_name</a> -
--   Specifies the operation. You can specify only one command.
--   
--   For stacks, the following commands are available:
--   
--   <ul>
--   <li><tt>execute_recipes</tt>: Execute one or more recipes. To specify
--   the recipes, set an <tt>Args</tt> parameter named <tt>recipes</tt> to
--   the list of recipes to be executed. For example, to execute
--   <tt>phpapp::appsetup</tt>, set <tt>Args</tt> to
--   <tt>{"recipes":["phpapp::appsetup"]}</tt>.</li>
--   <li><tt>install_dependencies</tt>: Install the stack's
--   dependencies.</li>
--   <li><tt>update_custom_cookbooks</tt>: Update the stack's custom
--   cookbooks.</li>
--   <li><tt>update_dependencies</tt>: Update the stack's
--   dependencies.</li>
--   </ul>
--   
--   The update_dependencies and install_dependencies commands are
--   supported only for Linux instances. You can run the commands
--   successfully on Windows instances, but they do nothing.
--   
--   For apps, the following commands are available:
--   
--   <ul>
--   <li><tt>deploy</tt>: Deploy an app. Ruby on Rails apps have an
--   optional <tt>Args</tt> parameter named <tt>migrate</tt>. Set
--   <tt>Args</tt> to {"migrate":["true"]} to migrate the database. The
--   default setting is {"migrate":["false"]}.</li>
--   <li><tt>rollback</tt> Roll the app back to the previous version. When
--   you update an app, AWS OpsWorks Stacks stores the previous version, up
--   to a maximum of five versions. You can use this command to roll an app
--   back as many as four versions.</li>
--   <li><tt>start</tt>: Start the app's web or application server.</li>
--   <li><tt>stop</tt>: Stop the app's web or application server.</li>
--   <li><tt>restart</tt>: Restart the app's web or application
--   server.</li>
--   <li><tt>undeploy</tt>: Undeploy the app.</li>
--   </ul>
newDeploymentCommand :: DeploymentCommandName -> DeploymentCommand

-- | Describes an Amazon EBS volume. This data type maps directly to the
--   Amazon EC2 <a>EbsBlockDevice</a> data type.
--   
--   <i>See:</i> <a>newEbsBlockDevice</a> smart constructor.
data EbsBlockDevice
EbsBlockDevice' :: Maybe Bool -> Maybe Int -> Maybe Int -> Maybe VolumeType -> Maybe Text -> EbsBlockDevice

-- | Create a value of <a>EbsBlockDevice</a> with all optional fields
--   omitted.
--   
--   Use <a>generic-lens</a> or <a>optics</a> to modify other optional
--   fields.
--   
--   The following record fields are available, with the corresponding
--   lenses provided for backwards compatibility:
--   
--   <a>$sel:deleteOnTermination:EbsBlockDevice'</a>,
--   <a>ebsBlockDevice_deleteOnTermination</a> - Whether the volume is
--   deleted on instance termination.
--   
--   <a>$sel:volumeSize:EbsBlockDevice'</a>,
--   <a>ebsBlockDevice_volumeSize</a> - The volume size, in GiB. For more
--   information, see <a>EbsBlockDevice</a>.
--   
--   <a>$sel:iops:EbsBlockDevice'</a>, <a>ebsBlockDevice_iops</a> - The
--   number of I/O operations per second (IOPS) that the volume supports.
--   For more information, see <a>EbsBlockDevice</a>.
--   
--   <a>$sel:volumeType:EbsBlockDevice'</a>,
--   <a>ebsBlockDevice_volumeType</a> - The volume type. <tt>gp2</tt> for
--   General Purpose (SSD) volumes, <tt>io1</tt> for Provisioned IOPS (SSD)
--   volumes, <tt>st1</tt> for Throughput Optimized hard disk drives (HDD),
--   <tt>sc1</tt> for Cold HDD,and <tt>standard</tt> for Magnetic volumes.
--   
--   If you specify the <tt>io1</tt> volume type, you must also specify a
--   value for the <tt>Iops</tt> attribute. The maximum ratio of
--   provisioned IOPS to requested volume size (in GiB) is 50:1. AWS uses
--   the default volume size (in GiB) specified in the AMI attributes to
--   set IOPS to 50 x (volume size).
--   
--   <a>$sel:snapshotId:EbsBlockDevice'</a>,
--   <a>ebsBlockDevice_snapshotId</a> - The snapshot ID.
newEbsBlockDevice :: EbsBlockDevice

--   The time and date that the cluster was registered with the stack.

newEcsCluster :: EcsCluster

--   instances that the Elastic Load Balancing instance is managing traffic
--   for.

newElasticLoadBalancer :: ElasticLoadBalancer

-- | Represents an app's environment variable.
--   
--   <i>See:</i> <a>newEnvironmentVariable</a> smart constructor.
data EnvironmentVariable
EnvironmentVariable' :: Maybe Bool -> Text -> Text -> EnvironmentVariable

-- | Create a value of <a>EnvironmentVariable</a> with all optional fields
--   omitted.
--   
--   Use <a>generic-lens</a> or <a>optics</a> to modify other optional
--   fields.
--   
--   The following record fields are available, with the corresponding
--   lenses provided for backwards compatibility:
--   
--   <a>$sel:secure:EnvironmentVariable'</a>,
--   <a>environmentVariable_secure</a> - (Optional) Whether the variable's
--   value will be returned by the DescribeApps action. To conceal an
--   environment variable's value, set <tt>Secure</tt> to <tt>true</tt>.
--   <tt>DescribeApps</tt> then returns <tt>*****FILTERED*****</tt> instead
--   of the actual value. The default value for <tt>Secure</tt> is
--   <tt>false</tt>.
--   
--   <a>$sel:key:EnvironmentVariable'</a>, <a>environmentVariable_key</a> -
--   (Required) The environment variable's name, which can consist of up to
--   64 characters and must be specified. The name can contain upper- and
--   lowercase letters, numbers, and underscores (_), but it must start
--   with a letter or underscore.
--   
--   <a>$sel:value:EnvironmentVariable'</a>,
--   <a>environmentVariable_value</a> - (Optional) The environment
--   variable's value, which can be left empty. If you specify a value, it
--   can contain up to 256 characters, which must all be printable.
newEnvironmentVariable :: Text -> Text -> EnvironmentVariable

-- | Describes an instance.
--   
--   <i>See:</i> <a>newInstance</a> smart constructor.
data Instance
Instance' :: Maybe Text -> Maybe Text -> Maybe Text -> Maybe Text -> Maybe Text -> Maybe Bool -> Maybe VirtualizationType -> Maybe Text -> Maybe Text -> Maybe Text -> Maybe Text -> Maybe [Text] -> Maybe Text -> Maybe Text -> Maybe Text -> Maybe Text -> Maybe Text -> Maybe Text -> Maybe Text -> Maybe Text -> Maybe Text -> Maybe Text -> Maybe Text -> Maybe Bool -> Maybe Text -> Maybe Text -> Maybe Text -> Maybe Text -> Maybe Text -> Maybe AutoScalingType -> Maybe [Text] -> Maybe Architecture -> Maybe Text -> Maybe Text -> Maybe Text -> Maybe ReportedOs -> Maybe Text -> Maybe Text -> Maybe RootDeviceType -> Maybe Text -> Maybe [BlockDeviceMapping] -> Instance

-- | Create a value of <a>Instance</a> with all optional fields omitted.
--   
--   Use <a>generic-lens</a> or <a>optics</a> to modify other optional
--   fields.
--   
--   The following record fields are available, with the corresponding
--   lenses provided for backwards compatibility:
--   
--   <a>$sel:privateDns:Instance'</a>, <a>instance_privateDns</a> - The
--   instance's private DNS name.
--   
--   <a>$sel:reportedAgentVersion:Instance'</a>,
--   <a>instance_reportedAgentVersion</a> - The instance's reported AWS
--   OpsWorks Stacks agent version.
--   
--   <a>$sel:instanceId:Instance'</a>, <a>instance_instanceId</a> - The
--   instance ID.
--   
--   <a>$sel:status:Instance'</a>, <a>instance_status</a> - The instance
--   status:
--   
--   <ul>
--   <li><pre>booting</pre></li>
--   <li><pre>connection_lost</pre></li>
--   <li><pre>online</pre></li>
--   <li><pre>pending</pre></li>
--   <li><pre>rebooting</pre></li>
--   <li><pre>requested</pre></li>
--   <li><pre>running_setup</pre></li>
--   <li><pre>setup_failed</pre></li>
--   <li><pre>shutting_down</pre></li>
--   <li><pre>start_failed</pre></li>
--   <li><pre>stop_failed</pre></li>
--   <li><pre>stopped</pre></li>
--   <li><pre>stopping</pre></li>
--   <li><pre>terminated</pre></li>
--   <li><pre>terminating</pre></li>
--   </ul>
--   
--   <a>$sel:privateIp:Instance'</a>, <a>instance_privateIp</a> - The
--   instance's private IP address.
--   
--   <a>$sel:installUpdatesOnBoot:Instance'</a>,
--   <a>instance_installUpdatesOnBoot</a> - Whether to install operating
--   system and package updates when the instance boots. The default value
--   is <tt>true</tt>. If this value is set to <tt>false</tt>, you must
--   then update your instances manually by using CreateDeployment to run
--   the <tt>update_dependencies</tt> stack command or by manually running
--   <tt>yum</tt> (Amazon Linux) or <tt>apt-get</tt> (Ubuntu) on the
--   instances.
--   
--   We strongly recommend using the default value of <tt>true</tt>, to
--   ensure that your instances have the latest security updates.
--   
--   <a>$sel:virtualizationType:Instance'</a>,
--   <a>instance_virtualizationType</a> - The instance's virtualization
--   type: <tt>paravirtual</tt> or <tt>hvm</tt>.
--   
--   <a>$sel:instanceProfileArn:Instance'</a>,
--   <a>instance_instanceProfileArn</a> - The ARN of the instance's IAM
--   profile. For more information about IAM ARNs, see <a>Using
--   Identifiers</a>.
--   
--   <a>$sel:platform:Instance'</a>, <a>instance_platform</a> - The
--   instance's platform.
--   
--   <a>$sel:hostname:Instance'</a>, <a>instance_hostname</a> - The
--   instance host name.
--   
--   <a>$sel:sshHostRsaKeyFingerprint:Instance'</a>,
--   <a>instance_sshHostRsaKeyFingerprint</a> - The SSH key's RSA
--   fingerprint.
--   
--   <a>$sel:securityGroupIds:Instance'</a>,
--   <a>instance_securityGroupIds</a> - An array containing the instance
--   security group IDs.
--   
--   <a>$sel:ecsClusterArn:Instance'</a>, <a>instance_ecsClusterArn</a> -
--   For container instances, the Amazon ECS cluster's ARN.
--   
--   <a>$sel:arn:Instance'</a>, <a>instance_arn</a> - The instance's Amazon
--   Resource Number (ARN).
--   
--   <a>$sel:createdAt:Instance'</a>, <a>instance_createdAt</a> - The time
--   that the instance was created.
--   
--   <a>$sel:ec2InstanceId:Instance'</a>, <a>instance_ec2InstanceId</a> -
--   The ID of the associated Amazon EC2 instance.
--   
--   <a>$sel:sshKeyName:Instance'</a>, <a>instance_sshKeyName</a> - The
--   instance's Amazon EC2 key-pair name.
--   
--   <a>$sel:agentVersion:Instance'</a>, <a>instance_agentVersion</a> - The
--   agent version. This parameter is set to <tt>INHERIT</tt> if the
--   instance inherits the default stack setting or to a a version number
--   for a fixed agent version.
--   
--   <a>$sel:rootDeviceVolumeId:Instance'</a>,
--   <a>instance_rootDeviceVolumeId</a> - The root device volume ID.
--   
--   <a>$sel:subnetId:Instance'</a>, <a>instance_subnetId</a> - The
--   instance's subnet ID; applicable only if the stack is running in a
--   VPC.
--   
--   <a>$sel:infrastructureClass:Instance'</a>,
--   <a>instance_infrastructureClass</a> - For registered instances, the
--   infrastructure class: <tt>ec2</tt> or <tt>on-premises</tt>.
--   
--   <a>$sel:sshHostDsaKeyFingerprint:Instance'</a>,
--   <a>instance_sshHostDsaKeyFingerprint</a> - The SSH key's Deep Security
--   Agent (DSA) fingerprint.
--   
--   <a>$sel:instanceType:Instance'</a>, <a>instance_instanceType</a> - The
--   instance type, such as <tt>t2.micro</tt>.
--   
--   <a>$sel:ebsOptimized:Instance'</a>, <a>instance_ebsOptimized</a> -
--   Whether this is an Amazon EBS-optimized instance.
--   
--   <a>$sel:elasticIp:Instance'</a>, <a>instance_elasticIp</a> - The
--   instance <a>Elastic IP address</a> .
--   
--   <a>$sel:os:Instance'</a>, <a>instance_os</a> - The instance's
--   operating system.
--   
--   <a>$sel:availabilityZone:Instance'</a>,
--   <a>instance_availabilityZone</a> - The instance Availability Zone. For
--   more information, see <a>Regions and Endpoints</a>.
--   
--   <a>$sel:lastServiceErrorId:Instance'</a>,
--   <a>instance_lastServiceErrorId</a> - The ID of the last service error.
--   For more information, call DescribeServiceErrors.
--   
--   <a>$sel:tenancy:Instance'</a>, <a>instance_tenancy</a> - The
--   instance's tenancy option, such as <tt>dedicated</tt> or
--   <tt>host</tt>.
--   
--   <a>$sel:autoScalingType:Instance'</a>, <a>instance_autoScalingType</a>
--   - For load-based or time-based instances, the type.
--   
--   <a>$sel:layerIds:Instance'</a>, <a>instance_layerIds</a> - An array
--   containing the instance layer IDs.
--   
--   <a>$sel:architecture:Instance'</a>, <a>instance_architecture</a> - The
--   instance architecture: "i386" or "x86_64".
--   
--   <a>$sel:publicDns:Instance'</a>, <a>instance_publicDns</a> - The
--   instance public DNS name.
--   
--   <a>$sel:amiId:Instance'</a>, <a>instance_amiId</a> - A custom AMI ID
--   to be used to create the instance. For more information, see
--   <a>Instances</a>
--   
--   <a>$sel:publicIp:Instance'</a>, <a>instance_publicIp</a> - The
--   instance public IP address.
--   
--   <a>$sel:reportedOs:Instance'</a>, <a>instance_reportedOs</a> - For
--   registered instances, the reported operating system.
--   
--   <a>$sel:registeredBy:Instance'</a>, <a>instance_registeredBy</a> - For
--   registered instances, who performed the registration.
--   
--   <a>$sel:stackId:Instance'</a>, <a>instance_stackId</a> - The stack ID.
--   
--   <a>$sel:rootDeviceType:Instance'</a>, <a>instance_rootDeviceType</a> -
--   The instance's root device type. For more information, see <a>Storage
--   for the Root Device</a>.
--   
--   <a>$sel:ecsContainerInstanceArn:Instance'</a>,
--   <a>instance_ecsContainerInstanceArn</a> - For container instances, the
--   instance's ARN.
--   
--   <a>$sel:blockDeviceMappings:Instance'</a>,
--   <a>instance_blockDeviceMappings</a> - An array of
--   <tt>BlockDeviceMapping</tt> objects that specify the instance's block
--   device mappings.
newInstance :: Instance

-- | Contains a description of an Amazon EC2 instance from the Amazon EC2
--   metadata service. For more information, see <a>Instance Metadata and
--   User Data</a>.
--   
--   <i>See:</i> <a>newInstanceIdentity</a> smart constructor.
data InstanceIdentity
